author: {'steamid': '76561198022041905', 'num_games_owned': 881, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1692395769}
review:
Choice of Robots is one of the best CYOA games I have played, and easily the best title Choice of Games has put out. I will admit that there's some bias because robots are a topic I have great interest in, but what makes Choice of Robots stand out is the multitude of branching paths offered, especially compared to other Choice of Games titles.

Most CYOA titles have poor replayability, with the second playthrough demonstrating that many of your choices didn't matter and you were railroaded to your ending. In contrast, Choice of Robots offers four main diverging endgame paths, with very little railroading: in every mandatory story section, you can decline or opt out of something asked of you (you're never forced to say 'yes'). After getting my honest ending (making the choices I felt I would earnestly make), I went back and played through at least 10 more times to experience the other routes the game had to offer, and I didn't get bored until I was grabbing the last few achievements.

If you like robots in scifi, get this game.

review:
These games, and this one in particular, outclasses any of the movie-"game" slop like Last of Us 2 or God of War Ragnarok that's been coming out recently.

Funny how bare text and one developer can achieve more for the interactive medium and games themselves as art versus thousands of people working in graphics, motion-capture, voice-acting just to make a movie that you need to press X to advance through.

THIS is a real GAMER's GAME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006365138', 'num_games_owned': 1254, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2752, 'last_played': 1675780957}
review:
[b]Rating:[/b] Mechanical Marvel (10/10)

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Ingenious Interactive Storytelling (10/10): Choice of Robots revolutionizes the concept of interactive storytelling, putting you in the shoes of a brilliant roboticist. From designing and building your own robots to making critical choices that shape the course of your career, the gameplay is immersive and captivating.

[b]Writing:[/b] Compelling and Thoughtful (10/10): The writing in Choice of Robots is exceptional, seamlessly blending compelling storytelling with thought-provoking themes. The narrative explores complex moral dilemmas, the nature of consciousness, and the societal implications of advanced robotics.

[b]Choices and Consequences:[/b] Meaningful Impact (10/10): Every choice you make in Choice of Robots carries weight and significance, leading to a wide range of outcomes. Your decisions shape the destiny of your robots, your relationships with other characters, and the overall trajectory of the narrative. T

[b]Customization and Creativity:[/b] Boundless Possibilities (10/10): Choice of Robots offers unparalleled customization and creative freedom. From designing the physical appearance and capabilities of your robots to programming their personalities and decision-making algorithms, you have complete control over their creation.

[b]Replayability:[/b] Endless Narrative Exploration (10/10): Choice of Robots boasts remarkable replayability, with its multiple story paths, varied character interactions, and divergent outcomes. The game invites you to replay it, exploring different choices, experimenting with new strategies, and uncovering hidden storylines and secrets. 

[b]Verdict:[/b] Choice of Robots is a tour de force in interactive storytelling, pushing the boundaries of what a text-based game can achieve. With its ingenious gameplay, compelling writing, meaningful choices and endless replayability, it stands as a shining example of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198899845237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1683409957}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026103069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1675440262}
review:
This stands as one of my best "Choice of" games, or any other choose your own adventure style games. In many such games, the choices are largely cosmetic, leading down a generally same plot path. For example, one could put points into skill A rather than B, and in another play through the reverse, and you'd end up with largely the same story, just with some changes in how events unfolded. Nothing truly wrong with that if the story is well written, but the illusion of choice is broken once you reach the second or third playthroughs.

Not so with Choice of Robots. Here, small changes and conscious choices lead your character's story and the world state down wildly divergent paths. This makes the game truly an RPG, with many new things to explore even after several play through (as of this this writing, I've completed about 10 already).

There are a couple of other small things that I appreciate. First is how you can select what kind of dream your character has. These dreams set the stage and mood for the game world in that playthrough, whether it's one of a robot utopia, apocalyptic warscapes, or a love story. It doesn't set your path in stone, but it's nice that you can set up what kind of story you wish to read today.

Second is how the story wraps itself up nicely at the end. There have been some good choose your own adventure stories that I've read before, but some of them end on a cliffhanger, awaiting a sequel that that may never come. This leaves a slight feeling of dissatisfaction for me because I want to know the outcome of my choices in the story, an outcome that (1) I likely won't ever get to read, or (2) having played the first part a few times, forget what character I'm actually playing when moving on to the next part. It's nice that in Choice of Robots, each playthrough is self-contained and concludes itesilf well, lending itself to multiple satisfying playthoughs.

In conclusion, highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198145281561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1695753109}
review:
Would definitely recommend. 

Replayed this game numerous times now and would never have thought I would extract so much enjoyment from a text-only game. This 'choose-your-own-adventure' explores the complexity of robotics and AI with philosophical undertones and witty writing. In this game your choices really do matter and has made me stop to think about my choices or the topic at hand, many times.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970412411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1588496930}
review:
Gamer: Hey there, Robo-buddy! I've got to tell you about this unique game I found on Steam called "Choice of Robots." It's an interactive story, and the concept is pretty extraordinary!

Robo-buddy: Intriguing! I'm always eager to learn about new experiences, especially if they involve my fellow robots. Please, do tell me more.

Gamer: So, the game lets you shape the character's decisions throughout the story, which made me feel really immersed in the whole experience. I found it quite thrilling to read and discover how the story developed based on my choices.

Robo-buddy: That does sound engaging! It's fascinating how interactive narratives can create a strong connection between the story and the participant. What else did you enjoy about the game?

Gamer: One of the things that stood out was the depth of the characters and the different paths the story could take. It felt like every choice I made had a real impact, which made the experience even more immersive.

Robo-buddy: It seems that the creators of "Choice of Robots" have crafted a truly captivating experience. I'm delighted that you enjoyed exploring the different possibilities and connecting with my robotic brethren through this interactive tale!

Gamer: Absolutely! It was a refreshing change from the usual games I play, and it made me think more deeply about the potential future of robotics and the ethical considerations that come with it. I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and engaging experience.

Robo-buddy: Thank you for sharing your thoughts, human friend. I'm glad to see that a game featuring robots could provide such an enlightening and entertaining experience for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048217658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1702089719}
review: So, I picked up this game a long time ago and have only just recently decided to play it. I spent two hours building up the main character to be just the way I wanted him to be. I roleplayed as him, making sub-optimal decisions for the sake of the story I wanted to have told. And then, at the two hour mark, the game goes and forces my character down a very specific path that was antithetical to my vision for the character. In any other game, I wouldn't have minded so much, but I got really invested in my character.

author: {'steamid': '76561198798516898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1677554606}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020096228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5183, 'last_played': 1700850228}
review:
Choice of Robots is an exquisite choose your own adventure style text game.  There are no graphics other than your imagination.  There is no sound, other than whatever you choose to listen to while you play it.  And yet, it is one of my favorite games on Steam of all time.  I've sunk over 80 hours exploring the numerous iterations of the storyline and I still occasionally come across whole blocks of text that I've never seen before.  I highly recommend Choice of Robots to anyone who enjoys a good story, especially those with interests in Sci Fi.

.
.
.
.
.

Also, on a side note, I've noticed a lot of discussions elsewhere stating that Choice of Robots (and Kevin Gold's other 2 choose your own adventure games) is the only good Choice of Games game.  I soundly disagree with that statement.  I've explored many of the other choose your own adventure titles, and also recommend the following if you enjoy this kind of game:

Choice of Magics
Choice of Alexandria
Ironheart <--- Especially this one!
Choice of Cat
Champion of the Gods
Social Services of the Doomed
Choice of the Deathless

author: {'steamid': '76561198407582381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1672331875}
review:
Highly replay-able, with great story, characters and robots you can't help but love!

I would recommend looking at some of the community guides for the more obscure trophies, there are so many options that it can be a little overwhelming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079631913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1670087116}
review:
[h1]Le livre dont vous êtes le héros, ou plutôt le robot ![/h1]

[url=https://www.tumblr.com/miyakuli/702639461351260161/choice-of-robots?source=share]English review here [/url]

6.5/10 J'écris cette critique après avoir recommencé le jeu deux fois.

❤ Une écriture simple et détaillée ce qui embarque très rapidement dans l'histoire
❤ Beaucoup d'embranchements différents pour une très bonne rejouabilité, et qui ont un impact sur chaque aspect de l'histoire (moral, politique, social..)
❤ Des succès assez divertissants à débloquer

✖ Autant le jeu n'a pas besoin d'illustrations car le texte suffit à laisser place à l'imagination. Par contre, je trouve que le support est assez fade, et ça manque d'ambiance musicale à mon goût (j'ai ouvert Spotify à côté xD)
✖ Pas d'indication pour les parties de texte déjà lues (mettre une couleur pour le texte déjà débloqué pourrait être nécéssaire selon moi)
✖ Des fins un peu inégales

author: {'steamid': '76561197962853797', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1663028320}
review:
This was my first time playing a "Choice of" game and I had a lot of fun with it. Overall the writing is solid and there is enough variation to make it feel like your choices do matter. There is some obvious repetition once you go through it multiple times, but I still found it quite fun. I think the subject matter helped as it is quite timely and interesting.

I recommend with the caveat that you need to go into this expecting an interactive sci-fi novel and nothing more, in fact you can even play this online on their website, that is how simple it is. But for me, a good script and fulfilling gameplay are the most important aspects of a game, and this succeeds there.

review:
My first "Choice" game and let me say this: The best written one.  Want to play a real life Dexters laboratorium and be the father of  Robot artificial intelligence,  A mad engineer that sets off to rule the world? Or a Family man/woman  who uses there knowledge to make life better for everyone or start a cult based on Predicting simulations? 
The choice is is open to you and the replay value here is  enough for me to recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168771933', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1756, 'last_played': 1684448777}
review: One of the best titles from the Choice of Games library. Your choices truly alter the course of the story and the writing style is very pleasant and engaging to read. If you enjoy text-based games, I highly recommend trying this one out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014445799', 'num_games_owned': 990, 'num_reviews': 325, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1658681722}
review:
Take in count that more than a video game this is a book, just plain text, not images, some basic options to make your reading a little less tiring (changue size of text, background color).

You are a student of Artificial Intelligence that wants to create a robot, but your project is financed by the state to build a war machine. So you must take decision of how you will build your robot, what decisions will you make in the different scenarios that the book proposes and read what happens.

At the moment of this review i have readed the book two times (took me around 2.5-3 hours each one). I enjoyed the stories that I did get and I am tempted to do a third try.

Of the things I didn’t like is the profile of the characters which you can “interact”, the information about them is too vague so they are practically unknow but the stories treat them like acquaintances. In my opinion this game needs a biography for these characters (the ones that you are supposed to know from your past), so when they appear on the stage you can check if you must trust then or not with some decisions.

If you want something more interactive with a similar theme i recommend to play “Detroid: become human”

author: {'steamid': '76561198129056294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1657156294}
review:
Brilliant game! I still find myself attached to my first robot companion, Bastian. He really was so romantic. Regardless, this game offers many possibilities and routes that I found myself willingly replaying to try and reach certain outcomes. There's something magical about empowering your imagination in this way that I really can't describe. 

However, this is just an observation, but it seems most of the love options blend together near the end of the narrative with sentences being repeated with name changes. At least, this was how the narrative was presented with Bastian in my first run and Silas in my second. I can't keep Elly around long enough to comment on her romance but I imagine it is quite similar. Each romance seems to be different in the beginning and middle of the narrative, although. 

Beware though, like most or all Choice of Games games, there is no save option. You must deal with your choices and their consequences; I mean, it would take away from the narrative otherwise. You can't reload a save in real life, now can you? 

Highly recommend this experience and get ready to replay multiple times. Although nothing is ever quite as magical as your first reading where you truly have no idea what to expect, subsequent readings did continue to surprise and challenge me. Don't be afraid to give this a try just because it doesn't have traditional graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198409883470', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1657072248}
review:
You're absentmindedly scrolling through the indie tag on steam. You feel like you've played just about every good game out there at this point. Suddenly, a game catches your eye; "Choice of Robots" it's called. You've never heard of it, and when you click it to see its store page you're greeted by pictures that look incredibly similar to an English quiz. Looks kind of lame, you think. But the description is intriguing, and the reviews for it are overwhelmingly positive. That has to mean something, right?

⦿ You buy the game. It's only $6 after all ($4 on sale!), and you can always refund it if it's not your thing.
〇 You add it to your wishlist for another time. Your backlog is way too long as it is anyway.
〇 You pass on it. Wayyy too much reading. I mean, a game without pictures? Really? Snooze.
〇 You add it to your cart to gift to a friend. The game doesn't sound like it's for you, but it's just what they like.

You add the game to your cart and checkout (- Wealth), then go to get something to drink while it installs. You get your favorite (a chocolate coffee porter... Mmm), sit down at your computer, and open up the game. It opens windowed. The formatting is simple, just a big block of text. You push up your glasses and get to reading.

As you read, the story draws you in more and more. You're charmed by the contemporary writing style. It's easy to digest, but descriptive enough that you really feel immersed in the world. The choices have you pondering questions you've never put much thought into before. What does it mean to die? What separates AI from humanity? If I give my robot child a gun for an arm, will it backfire on me?

By the end of the game, you feel incredibly attached to the characters. The robots you have created are real to you (+++ Empathy). You think of them fondly, and daydream about a universe where creations like that are possible. You close the game feeling nostalgic for a life you never had. You have a newfound inspiration to play more games of the genre.

You find the steam page and leave a review recommending it to others (+ Fame). You hope they will get the same enjoyment out of it as you did. And if not, well, they might just be put on the drone surveillance government watch list for being suspiciously unhuman. Shh... turn off your phone. They're listening.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271910838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1657078203}

review: I hate reading books but this game changed that. Everything is so well written and engaging. There are plenty of realistic choices to make throughout each storyline, many of which caused me to question my own morality. I'm glad I stumbled across something so unique because I learned to appreciate indie games and literature in general. Thank you for making this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037723216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1655867296}
review:
Choice of Robots, a short but interesting tale about you and your robot (or robots if you get that far). this story asks a few moral and philosophical questions in regard to how you use your robots. and you have several paths that can lead to a few different endings and mid life moments (for example chapter 6 has 4 different paths depending on your robots stats).

They say the art reflects the artist, so your actions reflect on your robots attributes as well. Will you build a mighty War Nachine or something that is more then Human? Will you view your robot as a fellow person or a disposable machine? The choice is your to make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103941488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1443063181}

author: {'steamid': '76561199109881770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1686600906}
review:
Engrossing game. Just finished my first playthrough getting 10 achievements out of the 72. 

There was a lot to like about this game (so far). The author clearly knew his stuff and the technical details to the subject matter, not choosing to skimp out on such details despite the incredibly fast pace. Also the stats bar gave the story a helpful "game feel" without being excessive. Another positive point to the game (some would say the focal point) is that the choices really do matter so the game title isn't clickbait at all. I was pretty shocked at how frequent the choices were and how judging by how many more achievements I have left, the impact of damn near every choice. It gives me a lot of motivation to explore the story as much as I can. There is also a great scale in the game with the story spanning 30 years and due to this, the game succeeds in touching on the jingoistic reality of war and change quite well in a broad sense. For example, it is jarring (in a good way) to see the world's change from showing your robot to elementary school children on a regular day and a bloody global robot war with prison and death.

As for what I thought could have been improved on, I felt the relationships (excluding the one with your robot) were rather fleeting. My main side characters were Elly and Mark with brief appearances (appropriately due to my rejections) from Josh, Juliet, and Tammy.  My main side characters would make appearances and have dialogue but the sheer breakneck speed of the story often didn't jive with their static characterizations. Ironically, the human characters felt like vaguely defined robots while the robot felt like a human in my playthrough. This plays into my previous praise of the visceral change of the world as the characters felt like NPCs in an otherwise alive world. The exception to his (besides the Robot) would be the mother to me. She felt extremely human and warm particularly in her words of wisdom. The fact that she wasn't a character listed in the Relationships portion of the stats was the right call.

Another thing was that in my playthrough, the positive innovative businessman portion of the story turned out to be far less important and relevant than the war and invasion part of the story. I was rather inspired by the former so to see the switch was bittersweet. This is not a criticism by any means because it's likely that my choices caused all this.  I just felt I should mention it since this is a review.

Overall, the game is great. The choices are frequent and weighty, the scale and events of the game are compelling, and I was left quite gripped. The misgivings I have are largely due to the breakneck speed of the story as that breakneck speed was the cause of the somewhat under-characterized human characters and seemingly the decreased relevance of the first half to he story. However, if you're used to such pacing (think of a 2 hour movie that aims to cover decades of someone's life with several timeskips), this shouldn't really be a problem. A movie-length story covering 30 years of someone's life and a 100 episode series doing the same are just two different writing beasts. Hopefully, I'll like Josh and Juliet and whatever other side character I haven't seen yet to a greater degree in my replays. The achievement descriptions just seem so different and varied which gets me really excited. A CYOA game that is actually choosing your own adventure!

I'll be sure to write a review when I've gotten all 72 achievements or at least all but the "Tragic Hero" one. I also will be sure to check out the other Choice games in due time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198834287667', 'num_games_owned': 17, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3978, 'last_played': 1680223537}

author: {'steamid': '76561198228104588', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1645696032}
review:
[h1] Если вы хотите прожить невероятный игровой опыт и вы любите роботов - вам сюда[/h1] 



Эта игра дает особый игровой опыт. Мне довелось пережить теплые родительские чувства, потери, будто рушится все, обиду и желание отомстить вместе с роботом, теплые чувства, снова потери, любовь и наконец отсутствие в персонаже человечности.
И концовка которая у каждого своя - добрая заставляющая расплакаться от чувства радости, никакая которая оставляет с удивлением раскрыть рот "И вот так всё кончится?", и грустная заставляющая лить слёзы. Побольше бы милоты добавили.
До этой игры мне казалось что над фильмами/играми ТАК плакать могут только дети, но теперь я понимаю, что всё подругому.

[b]Ачивки Дельты:[/b]

[code] [b]Ты зек и я зек[/b]
Вы и ваш робот отсидели в тюрьме[/code] 

[code][b]50 на 50[/b]
2 раза заплакть от радости/умиления и 2 от грусти [/code]

[spoiler] Из-за моих взрывающихся аккумуляторов в роботах началась война. Которая уничтожила всю надежду на мирное существование меня и робота. Все было кончено.[/spoiler] 
[spoiler] (Очень советую не нажимать "сообщить азиатке" при допросе иначе вы сделаете самый глупый поступок - сделаете это на виду у всех)[/spoiler] 

[b]9/10[/b] (минус балл за то что я теперь седая)

P.S. - в игре нет сохранений, даже при попытке заменить игровые файлы ничего не будет. Почему? потому, они хранятся на сервере!!! За что? Зато вы будете искрене страдать за неправильный выбор и рыдать от этого чаще.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022378098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1645538153}

author: {'steamid': '76561198300780578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1629221978}
review:
Compared to their other games, the choices avaliable in Choice of Robots lacks significantly. 

I'm a fast reader, so I enjoy these text-based games usually as a way to get a great story I get to take part in telling that slowly develops over time. But here, I found myself completely underwhelmed and just about finishing two playthroughs in less than two hours. 

I was hoping for nuance, complicated characters that I'd grow to come close to, stuff that Choice of Games usually excells in, but here every choice was incredibly obvious. Make your robot more human, good ending, make it less attached from humanity, bad ending, war, etc etc. I was hoping there'd be a twist of some sort where your actions would change, but the stats are literally built against you in this game. If you don't have enough military, your robot can't fight- if you don't have enough humanity, your robot isn't compassionate, you get the deal. There's barely any middle ground where you're able to design the robot you want while also allowing them to have heart, which I feel like misses the message that they can be human just like us- humans aren't always gentle, we have rough edges too. 

If you're not looking for something too complicated, or maybe you just want a cool robot story, then this could be for you, but if you're looking for something more then I would look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993369926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1643372411}

author: {'steamid': '76561198087375607', 'num_games_owned': 3094, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1694312873}
review:
I'm sure if you're into choose-your-own-adventure books, and you're looking at this game, you know what you're getting into.

What I want to let you know is that this particular game goes in so many different directions based on your choices that it's a really customized experience.  It's kind of mind-blowing.

I come from the world of Infocom text games from the 1980's on my old Commodore 64, as well as current modern visual novels (Japan as well as english-language indie games) and Choice Of Robots is above all of this.  With ease.

You owe it to yourself if you love a good book - as well as being able to choose the direction it goes - to experience this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993419334', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1632579568}
review:
Choice of Robots is wonderful, a great example of how to write a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure narrative. This is more of a challenge than I think many would assume, since reading page after page on a screen can be quite tiresome and have your attention shift compared to a physical book. It's easy to overwhelm the reader and for sentences to bleed together. And yet, keeping yourself concise can also rob your story of emotion, tension and drive, making it too dry to truly engage with. Striking that balance is the sign of a great writer and it's a great accomplishment of this game.

The writing in this game is more of a subtle guide than an overbearing presence, but still manages to have a lot of striking imagery, a smart structure and moving interactions between characters. I love the conversations in this game, they are thoughtful and fulfilling and heartbreaking in just the right ways. Playing this game is like walking a tightrope, capturing the struggle of the robotics engineer designing the robot of the future vividly as you, and they, do your best to make the world better instead of worse. It's a very human struggle, aiming for perfection and hitting something less-than but also unexpected and interesting. 

If there is anything to criticise it might be the lack of surprises in following playthroughs. The game can have very different outcomes, but it also follows the same tracks and storybeats every time. It means that your relationship with different characters might be different but it doesn't change the meetings and obstacles you encounter that much, at least in my experience. I might have just been unlucky, but where my first playthrough felt like an absolute marvel my second playthrough fell a bit flat in comparison.

However, there is no doubt in my mind that Choice of Robots is worth playing. I think this game is good enough to be entertaining to pretty much everyone, even the people who might not like CYOA games normally. It makes you think and it makes you feel, and what else does a great story need?

review: A spectacular example of interactive fiction. Every single choice you make has [i]some[/i] effect on the narrative in both the short and long term. This game really makes you feel like you're navigating time like a web as you play it through more and more. It should take perhaps ~3 hours to complete your first run, but don't let that fool you. Each run is incredibly meaningful, there are very few/no meaningless decisions and even the slightest variation of choices can result in vastly different paths and narratives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116117777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1512142755}
review:
[h1] Short Version [/h1]
If you want to try an interactive novel, Choice of Robots is a good start. It's well worth the asking prize and belongs in the library of all, who love a good story.  

[h1] Writing [/h1] 
Choice of Robots is the gold standard for interactive text based games. Here your decisions matter. The story has been tailored so well to the player choices, it sometimes feels like you experience it yourself. Contributing to this are the believable and sometimes unexpected outcomes and the well written characters. All characters have believable motivations and take comprehensible actions. To sum it up: The writing is good, even by novel standards. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
There is little gameplay to be found in this interactive novel. The player has frequent opportunities to make a choice, but that's about it. If you are okay with that, you will not be disappointed, because the story is great. 

[h1] Recommendation [/h1] 
Choice of Robots is more than worth the asking prize. In fact this interactive novel is a true gem of the genre. I recommend this game to everyone, who likes to read. Even people, which usually don't play games, should have a good time with it. That's how good this game is. So start reading something great, like choice of robots, instead of this review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198364092307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1615849042}
review:
Possibly the best choose-your-own-path text adventure I have ever played.
The lack of any kind audio or visual aesthetic might stop some people from giving it a moments notice, which is a terrible shame. 

I played trough  three wildly different games and found myself thoroughly impressed by the amount of choices and paths you can go down. 

This simple looking game hides a staggering  amount of complexity and the writing is truly excellent.

I was daydreaming for days after finishing it.
A literary work of art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121589378', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1584738662}
review: En buen juego, bastante sensible en que tropo quieras dirigir tu historia, no te preocupes, las principales temáticas que se te ocurran sobre la relación entre el hombre y sus máquinas están en el juego. Quizás no sea uno de los motivos por los que la gente se fije, pero me gustó mucho el detalle de la competencia internacional entre Estados Unidos y China. Me pareció algo bastante realista y que acercaba la historia al mundo real, recomiendo sinceramente el juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288648366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1619691213}
review:
Вместо того, чтобы расхваливать игру, давайте я лучше приведу пример историй, которые у меня получились в ней.

1) Успешный предприниматель теряет фабрику в результате пожара, на последние деньги уезжает из страны и осознает, что главное - оставаться человечным для своих близких.

2) Хикка-геймер создает себе секс-робота, храня его в секрете от других людей, а потом сам переносит свое сознание в робота, чтобы вечно жить со своей робо-подругой.

3) Миллиардер жертвует все свое состояние на благотворительность и создает новую религию - робославие.

4) Доктор роботехнических наук создает фабрику по производству собственных роботов, но делает их слишком независимыми, и они захватывают страну.

И это только небольшая часть того, как можно повернуть ход истории.
Рекомендую тем, у кого хороший уровень англа.
9,5 робо-кошек из 10

author: {'steamid': '76561197992557240', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1612097457}
review:
Easily one of the best sci-fi games I've ever played.

This simple text-based adventure is more gripping, well written, polished and emotionally meaningful than most AAA OR Indie games. While many other "choices-matter" games struggle to make decisions feel meaningful or even relevant, here every decision almost felt like a matter of life and death.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021846105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2017, 'last_played': 1549527450}
review: I cannot recommend this game enough. You may think that 6$ is a bit steep for what could be seen as a fancy "choose-your-own-adventure" book. But it is so much more than that. This game was more poignant and emotional than most high-budget films or triple-A video games can ever hope to be. It is simultaneously thought-provoking, humorous, intriguing, somber, and heartwarming. It runs the gamut of emotion based on your decisions and yes, your choices really do matter. Something that seems trivial early on may in fact have great impact late into your story. While your choices are technically finite, there are so many variations and combinations that you are getting more than your money's worth. There is not a single aspect of this game I can find myself to dislike, the only disclaimer I can think of is that it may not mean nearly as much to you if you don't like science fiction. But then, that's a measure of personal taste and not an objective measure of how good it is at what it does. A Choice of Robots is a fantastic game, a wonderful experience. I cannot say it any more emphatically than that. You should play this game, you should experience this story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198417332264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1678736045}
review: Choice of Robots is endlessly replayable and makes you feel like every single decision matters. I found myself hesitating and carefully considering the smallest choices and have been satisfied and happy every time I reach an ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040029392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1679883664}
review: Boy what a game. Enough to make you smile and almost enough to make you cry from its messages. It almost feels like a dream as you pick options that have serious consequences and later references. Put on some sweet music and go at it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198825149772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1609796991}
review:
While the story was good and the writing exceptional, I did find a grammar mistake and a few problems that may disrupt the player's experience.

I noted the lack of gender-neutral pronouns as the most prominent problem to me. I feel like this game would be more user-friendly if there was a they/them or gender-nonconforming option. Not just for the player, but for the robots as well.
Additionally, the game repeatedly tries to engage the player in romance, giving neutral to bad reactions when romance was declined. This isn't very friendly to aromantic people. I understand that actions have consequences, but I feel like the consequences shouldn't be so harsh. It dampened my experience to read that a creation of mine ran away, mostly because I didn't love them romantically and therefore couldn't form that bond that was crucial for later in the story.
The writing also got a bit bland, with some problems being drawn out and the same problems becoming overly reoccurring. With my choices, I found myself being driven repeatedly into dead ends, furthering the negative experience. There is also one spelling mistake near the beginning, but it didn't affect me. Just an observation.

Overall, with the lack of openness about character customization and the other problems mentioned above, it affected my experience greatly. The story was great in itself, but the lack of inclusion ruined part of it for me. I won't play again very much, but in the end, it was an okay game.
Play at your own risk.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994608446', 'num_games_owned': 755, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1609712858}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996111466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1132, 'last_played': 1682540282}
review:
Made me cry. More than once.
And laugh. And curse. And shake my head.
And wonder how to get to all the other endings.

The following details of one of my playthroughs contain spoilers. STOP READING HERE.
Or don't: there's a lot more outcomes than this, and a lot more tragic or semi-tragic things possible to happen along the way.

Reaching singularity with a well balanced robot was quite amazing: my best playthrough so far: I even managed to stay on friendly terms with everyone (even the Prof and Captain Rogers who I joined in crimefighting Superhero costumes (that part was almost a bit too ridiculous for me)). Earlier when I was sent to prison for warning my chinese friend I got a little worried, but after a while President Irons pardonned me, and later I was able to reunited with Emmy after moving to Hope, Canada where we went on to laying down flowers at the site of an internation camp from the Sino-American war. - The times when I really cried was, when I gave control over everything to my robot, and he was just perfect for it. - That part where he told me how he was caring about the dead sparrow sent shivers down my spine... - it felt like the best possible outcome.

The way this game determines a plethora of possible outcomes by simple skill-checks and presenting lots of dilemmas reminded me of Age of Decadence. But Age of Decadence is a RPG where one playthrough takes 15-30h, and you have to do all the usual RPG stuff. - Whereas here it's purely the story / decisions, and you can do multiple playthroughs in one evening. And here the things happening can be of a much grander scale, as the world and decisions only exists in text and don't have to be modeled in a traditional RPG form.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990489882', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1621466042}
review:
Probably the best text-based interactive fiction game in my opinion.

This is one of the few (if not the only) game where I was fully satisfied with one run - despite knowing for sure that there's much I could do differently if I did replay it. 

That's largely due to the quality in the writing - the story felt lived, not read.

That being said, this is also probably the only one of these games that got me to cry, and one where sentences have stuck with me for a long time after. The themes it touches upon (humanities, economics, politics, et all) are done so incredibly well and in an often thought provoking way that does not come across as preachy or hamfisted (which I know is a concern for some when hearing that a game deals with those themes).

It's my first recommendation for anyone interested in meaningful choice narratives.

(The author's other game, Choice of Magics, is a great second play.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198160088509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1538373058}
review: This is the gold standard for text-based adventures for me. The game doesn't take very long to get through, but because the plotlines and endings vary so wildly, the replayability is high. Each story is richly detailed, and your choices really drive the game. An adventure game with traditional graphics could never pull off all these branching storylines since depending on your choices, you're playing what feels like a different game with a totally different setting. The text-based format really shines with this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077903441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1614111809}
review: This is the type of game I've been looking for, a true interactive narrative experience where player agency, choices and consequences of those choices feel meaningful and are a greater priority than flashy graphics and conventional gameplay. For anyone who loves the independent-visualization and (admittedly more limited) choices of table-top games such as Dungeons and Dragons but just can't find the right people or time to experience something like that, this game is for you. From the bottom of my yearning heart, thank you for making these types of games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058954239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1650695574}
review: Damn. got me. At first I thought this was kind of cheesy. But wouldnt you know, I'm totally into it. Feels like I've been reading forever, alot of sh3t has happened. Only have like 3 of 70 achievements lol. Which means it's pretty well packed. Still on the first playthrough, f3ck you Joe, you'll never replace Fred :\ . For $6 you're basically buying a nifty choose your own novel, and a pretty good one at that. I will die for Fred and Joe my robits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030324886', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1601375914}
review:
I have never been brought to tears by any game or story but this one. The choices I made were completely meaninful and true to myself. I never felt the game cheated me in anyway and the ending I received brought me to tears, I was ecstatic to get such a happy ending.

In the end I still think about my relationships in this beautiful story; My loving robot wife, and the robot daughter I built and stuck with me to the very end, I cherished her deeply and encouraged her to learn as much as she could. 

11/10 Will cry for robots again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000167056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1602500245}
review:
An excellently written Choose-Your-Own-Adventure where you create and raise the world's first sentient robot. What kind of robot it is, what kind of person you are, and the impact these have on the rest of the world, is what the game revolves around.

Touches on the ethics, business, and politics behind what a robotic revolution could be like, and it really sells the "actions with consequences" well. I loved every bit of it, had a few playthroughs and was impressed by all the different directions the story could go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006807037', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1522538617}
review: One of the best text adventures i've played. The story was moving and had me thinking about my choices long after the game had finished. The subject matter makes you question what artificial life would really be in society. If your looking for an emotional and thought provoking story I would strongly recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405002746', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1512, 'last_played': 1600606697}
review:
这个游戏给我一个教训，那就是steam上好评如潮的游戏也可能是垃圾，以后对某个游戏心动一定要先看看最有价值（发布至今）的差评。

前面还算正常，等到中国出场时整个剧情彻底失控，疯狂夹带私货。另一个中文差评里总结的很好了，这里我贴一下原文，感受一下：

第一段：
[i]"This Chinese company stole my designs—I have no idea how! But now they're undercutting my prices with their cheap labor and cheap raw materials." 
"Can you testify before Congress that the designs are stolen?" Josh queries anxiously. "If you do, they might embargo the robots, and that will keep U.S. Robots afloat. They said I need an expert witness who isn't in my company, and I've hired everybody else who's good." [/i]
....（这里选择作证）
[i]Based on your testimony, Congress passes a law banning the import of all Chinese robots. 
In retaliation, China cuts off all exports of rare earths and the batteries derived from them. [/i]

在2020年的当下，有没有感觉这个剧情很眼熟？

第二段：
[i]"This must be the parade for the Prime Minister of China. Can we go see, Master?" [/i]
在这里我开始疑惑，为什么在美国会有为中国主席进行的游行？
[i]"Sure," you say. "Why not?" Now that L mentions it, you think you saw something about this on Reddit: the Chinese Prime Minister is visiting San Francisco to discuss trade issues with President Irons. [/i]
这里正常人都会理解为，首相在会见美国总统对吧？
[i]You emerge from your apartment into the crowd of red-shirted, flag-waving supporters, mostly Chinese. You have the sense this kind of groundswell of support for a politician outside of his home country isn't normal, like maybe these supporters were paid. But that could just be an American point of view; you're not sure.  [/i]
作者自己带偏见写的剧情，还要辩解一下。

[b]重头戏来了[/b]

[i]Further down the street, you see the vanguard of the parade: dancers dressed as gods of the ancient Chinese pantheon. They wear Chinese opera masks, bear banners with river dragons on their backs, and twirl bared swords. 
Behind the sword dancer vanguard, you see a troupe of men wearing the Chinese tunic suits sometimes called "Mao suits" and carrying little, red books. They are the ones singing the song, now growing more insistent as the parade draws closer. Behind them, you see a legion of men in modern Chinese military dress uniforms. With the ancient past, more recent past, and the present covered, you surmise whoever comes next will be meant to symbolize China's future. 
At the end of the parade, a Chinese man in a suit stands in an all-red, winged convertible, waving at the crowd. It is one of the sleek, new, Chinese-made flying cars, the Tian Eight, a symbol of China's rise.  [/i]
.....(中国主席被抗议者枪杀)
[i]The Chinese contingent is massacred, and the Chinese government vows vengeance. The first shots of the Robot War have been fired. 
A year into the war, China attacks Taiwan. Chinese drones harry the nearby American carriers, keeping American bombers and fighters at bay while their transports bring wave upon wave of robot warriors to the shores. There is a bloodbath in the streets which the United States is powerless to prevent; the Chinese robots kill soldiers and civilians alike. 
Taiwan is taken, and the headlines that appear across the world the next day are changed by Chinese hackers to read "China Finally Unified."  [/i]

我已经无力吐槽了，这个诡异的游行，“gods of the ancient Chinese pantheon”，“Chinese opera”， "Mao suits" 。一开始我还以为被枪杀的只是个主席的cosplay，看到后面才发现居然是本人？？？他妈的一国首相去另一个国家大街上领导游行？？？作者有中二病吗？然后就是非常草率的明目张胆的他杀，再然后就开始战争了？？？然后中国进军台湾，在你们美国保护不到的地方，屠杀台湾人？？？？Are you fucking serious?

在这里我就弃游了。还有，别以为只是涉及政治的剧情有问题，这游戏主打的有AI，30万字，横跨30年，剧情丰富。可事实上里面科研过程极其幼稚，剧情以一种十分荒谬的速度发展，明明前后感觉时间没过多久，你点开统计信息才发现过了2年，词汇量要求也不高。真想玩文字游戏的推荐去玩sunless sea，150万单词，世界观合理自洽，比这个垃圾好多了。

最后，为什么steam首页上全是好评？英文好评就算了，为什么还有中文好评？我去查找评价才找到一个中文差评，真是，fucking interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006757212', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1668180664}
review:
Dieses Spiel ist eines der besten auf Steam überhaupt.

Anders als der Titel nahelegen mag, verkörpert man allerdings keinen Roboter, vielmehr baut man einen, und auch das greift zu kurz: In "Choice of Robots" schlüpft man in die Rolle eines KI-Entwicklers und hat weitreichende Freiheiten, wenn es darum geht, das Äußere, aber vor allem auch das Innere des Roboters zu gestalten, sein Bewusstsein. 

Baue ich für das Militär eine unbesiegbare Kampfmaschine? Wird sie zweckentfremdet? Durch das Militär? Durch mich? Geht die Welt daran zugrunde?

Oder baue ich einen Helfer für die Menschheit? Welchen Teil davon? Welche Schichten? Welche Nationen? Für mich und den Ruhm? Oder nur für den Reichtum? Gar einen weisen Herrscher? Und darf man ihm vertrauen?

Oder lasse ich meinen empfindungsfähigen Roboter autark werden, also zu einem echten Individuum? Brenne ich mit ihm durch? Stelle ich mich denjenigen, die ihn haben wollen? Verliebe ich mich in ihn? Was geschieht, wenn unsere Liebe durch meinen Tod enden muss? Muss sie das?

Ja, ganz richtig gelesen, so weit verzweigt sind die Möglichkeiten in diesem Spiel, und das ist nur in Textform möglich. Lasst Euch davon also nicht abschrecken, zumal es noch viele weitere Fragen gibt, mit denen Ihr konfrontiert werdet, und davon ausgehend dann mit zahlreichen einzigartigen Handlungsverläufen!

Ich liebe dieses Spiel, und der Entwickler hat sich hier ein Denkmal gesetzt.

review:
Seriously one of my favorite games and favorite things period. It's well written, well executed, and full of thought and heart. I go back to it whenever I have a bad day and feel lost, and every now and then I find a completely new ending that blows my mind.

This convinced me that CYOA novels have the potential to be a legitimate art form, because I can't call this anything other than art. I've recommended it to everyone I know ever since I first played it last year. BUY. IT.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201044503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1584720152}
review:
What can I say about Choice of Robots? 

Should I talk about how well crafted the story is? How much attention to detail? Or how about the fact that this rejuvenated Text based games for me.

This game is best described as a Choose Your Own Adventure novel, that never gets old. There's hundreds of ways to play the game. Want to create a Robot Empire? Check. You want to settle down with a Robot lover? Check. Want to become a super scientist on the run from the United States government? Yeah, Check. Inspector Gadget arms? Check-a-mundo.

5/5 - The best choose your own adventure game I have ever played.

Pro Tip - Listen to the FTL soundtrack in the background. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199053870791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1592954663}
review:
First of all, I love text-based games, books, writing, and reading. I also love scifi and robots and stuff. So I might be a bit biased when it comes to anything robot/android/etc related, because I love this game.

It has an interesting setting (maybe a bit cliché?), and I like that everyone can shape the 'playable character' as they want. It's something that's often lacking in games. In text-based, and otherwise. So that's a great thing to have. You don't have to be the 'straight white guy' anymore, and that is something that I desperately needed when I was younger. And, well, still do I suppose.

The game makes you think, and that's awesome! Making choices, and seeing how they play out is the reason I loved CYOA books as a kid. I would read them over and over again, and they were such an inspiration to me. Hence I wanted to buy this game.

I found the science behind robot-making pretty vague, but it didn't bother me as such. Too much detail would've made this game a bit too heavy for some people. It's just an observation, and it really didn't affect my opinion of the story, or the execution.

But, although the premise is amazing, and the characters are likable, I feel that the game lacks... something. It needs something more. This game barely scratched the surface of what could've been, and I can't help but feel that this game is incomplete regarding that area. The relationships with other characters (especially romantic ones) feel hollow, and rushed. Everything seems a  bit glossed-over, and I just hope that they would've given you more insight as to what kind of people/robots the other characters are. Because all you see are glimpses. And for me, it's not enough. I would've loved to be able to read more about how different relationships play out, and have more control over them. 

In three hours I played this game twice. So... It's not that long. "A 300,000-word epic interactive sci-fi novel" feels like it's a bit of an oversell. Sure, the total word count is probably 300K, I'm not saying it ain't. It's a short game, with a lot of possibilities and different scenarios. I laughed, and I cried while playing this. Especially when something bad happened. It it 'epic'? Well, Merriam-Webster would disagree, but I think it's just that. It is epic. In the urban dictionary way.

I'll buy more of these games, though. And I highly recommend this game. Every single game, book etc. has its weaknesses. It's not a bad thing, but I just wanted to point out the things that bothered me. Maybe I was bothered by the lack of substance, and descriptions, because my taste in literature, and my own style of writing is completely different. But, all in all, a great game and an amazing experience. I'm going to return to this game again, and again. Why?

Because it gives me choices, and it gives me power to change the things that will be. It's fun seeing how time is not linear, and how you can affect the future with your own actions.

10/10 would recommend to someone with ADHD. It's easier to concentrate on reading when you gotta make decisions. Just sayin'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014923034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1573791257}
review:
Choice of Robots is the gold standard by which I judge COG games.  It's very well written, things happen to the PC, and (for better or worse) you choose (usually from several choices) how to respond to what is happening.

Your choices matter in Choice of Robots, because every choice you make has the potential to either impact yourself, others, or the world.  It's usually made clear (roughly) how your choices will impact the story, but the game is very good at delivering surprises, and throwing a curve ball at you from time to time.

While the story is largely very colourful and vibrant at times, there a few roads that you can stumble down that lead the story down a very bleak and sometimes narrow pathway.  Although it is quite possible to jump off the slippery slope, it's normally a very slow tumble, and the game can be "somewhat" forgiving, especially if you catch yourself slipping early on.

When it comes to building your robot, I found the experience very nostalgic, though through a somewhat poignant lens, as it reminded me of younger happier days that have since passed away like leaves in the wind.  Days spent playing with K-nex, Legos, and Machano, days that have come and gone.

Choice of Robots is really good at capturing the very essence of childhood, and retelling it through a neat compact experience, it's character creation is like it's own little side story within the wider main story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201668110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1683409979}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023942961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1582478132}
review:
Steam tricked me into buying fanfictions.
Well done, well done indeed.

This is a nerdgasm of a story, not your typical sci-fi webnovel in that it is too short and stereotypical.

Many endings, go read Andur's fictions on royalroad or other chuuni SF on the net for free if you like this.
I would not recommend that you buy web novel at such a stupid price, ever. That kind of stuff is usually
made for a few bucks if not for free by some webnovelists after all, go give your money to them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995992757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1581115411}
review:
In English:

I'm not really used to writing reviews of things that have no graphics or music whatsoever, so consider this just a random bundle of my comments and observations after finishing a single playthrough. Thus far, I could say "Choice of Robots" is:

*An extremely solid and impressive piece of 'hard' science - fiction

* a glorified, three times the "Hobbit" or  nearly "The Fellowship of the Ring" and a half long personality quiz 

* Astonishingly well written by someone with a vast knowledge regarding the subject he is writing about and also having a great taste in science-fiction classics

* giving you an insane amount of replayability and freedom of choice (my complete playthrough has earned me 5 out of 72 achievements which gives me a rather clear idea of just how many different paths wait to be discovered)

* best read around midnight, with some  whisky and Solar Fields playing in the background (although Carbon Based Lifeforms would also do )

* giving your character a rating of '44% liked' from someone you have just killed

* fully deserving its Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on Steam




Po polsku:

Nigdy dotąd nie pisałem recenzji czegoś co nie posiada żadnej warstwy audiowizualnej, więc potraktujcie proszę tą wypowiedź raczej jako luźny zwitek wrażeń po pierwszym ‘przejściu’ tej ‘gry’. Niniejszym, „Choice of Robots” jest:

* niezwykle solidnym kawałkiem twardej, spekulatywnej fikcji naukowej

* długim jak trzy Hobbity albo prawie Drużyna Pierścienia i pół quizem pt. „Jakim Robotem Jestem?”

* zadziwiająco dobrze napisany, przez osobę która posiada rozległą wiedzę na temat który wybrała a do tego posiada bardzo dobry gust dotyczący klasyki science-fiction

* czymś co można przechodzić znowu i znowu. Po pierwszym ukończeniu odblokowałem 5 z 72 osiągnięć co daje dość jasny obraz tego jak wiele różnych ścieżek czeka na odkrycie

* najlepiej czytany w okolicach północy, ze szklaneczką whisky i Solar Fields’ami grającymi po cichu w słuchawkach ( chociaż Carbon Based Lifeforms też daje radę... )

* grą która ocenia postać głównego bohatera jako „ w 44% lubianą” przez osobę którą właśnie zabiłem

* niedostępny po polsku

* absolutnie zasługującym na Przytłaczająco Pozytywne recenzje na Steamie

author: {'steamid': '76561198165236215', 'num_games_owned': 8496, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1581670484}
review:
#游戏手札#176 
这两天玩了一下以Choice of Robots为代表的互动小说（不是视觉小说，是纯文本choose your own adventure），突然意识到这个类型其实是不可替代的，因为它有着独立于小说与游戏以外的复合表达属性：舍弃了一切视听要素，互动小说试图用语言来描述一切，会在每个选项分歧中写出“你”的动机与该选项的性质（有时甚至会暗示部分后果，虽然有时候也会被用来欺诈），比如以下案例：

（“你”创造出了一个人工智能小生命）
你把她放在了房间中央，让她随意探索。但起初，她看起来好像被过多的可能性淹没了。

你决定教她形容这一情绪：

· “困惑。”然后我给她下达了一个更可靠的、直白的指令。
· “好奇。”我允许她自行决定如何行动。
· “孤独。”我站远了一点，以强化这一例证。

我选择了第二个选项，但第一个选项让我能想象到重生以前（在游戏开局时，我选择的出生点是在机械阿努比斯面前忏悔，因为在创造机械生命时过度重视其思考能力、忽略了共情，最终导致了机器人革命。阿努比斯让我看见高度智能化的机器人已经学会优先攻打医院、杀死人类婴儿的画面，让我重来一次，好好想想这回该干什么）人类会被毁灭的原因，第三项则让我产生了强烈的共鸣，但我不希望、尤其是在知道原本的未来以后尤其不希望我的“孩子”是在这样的意识下长大。第二选项未必就是健康的，但我希望不论是未来的自己、还是初生的这个孩子，都能拥有好奇的自由。
尽管我要做的只是三选一，但这三个选项分别用不同的方式对我的理解和情感产生了影响，也都加深了我在扮演文中角色时的代入感。

互动小说强调的，并不仅仅是“你选择了什么”，还有“你本可以选择什么其他的”，或者说在每一次选择中“你失去了什么”。
这在小说或游戏（顺带一提，我倾向于认为互动小说就是互动小说，带有游戏性质但不是狭义游戏）里偶有发生，但绝对不会是常态，因为完整列出每一种可能性、其动因、性质、结果……在小说中是累赘的，次数过多必然会破坏行文结构的流畅性；而在游戏中，视听要素的参与分散了文字的表达功能，使得文字描述从一开始就无法跟其他表现形式绝对对等，往往退居二线不说，玩家的注意力也不会长期集中在大片的文字上。

现在的互动小说之所以会衰落，仅存的相对流行的大多都改头换面以所谓视觉小说的形式掺杂部分视听要素来拓展受众，主因正是创作者们抛开了互动小说的特性，没有去放大这种复合的多线并行的传达属性，只跟小说比文字剧情、跟游戏比交互模式视听质量，可谓扬短避长了，实在可惜。
不过当然了，也有外因，这类游戏的多语言化成本高得离谱，市场原本就日益小众，还很分散，赚钱实在困难，也就更难吸引优秀的创作者，进入恶性循环了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198019050303', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1789, 'last_played': 1579976033}
review:
This is one of the best CYOA games I have read/played.  So many choices and so, so many branches to explore and find.  Several romantic choices as well with just enough variety in them that I even enjoyed finding the subtle differences between switching genders for the main protagonist.  I like that there are only four robotic skills to improve and therefore keeping it simple but fun.  However, you have attributes for your character too in wealth and fame.  I played several times just trying to increase those skills alone to see the differences in those numbers ("Internationally Famous and Mentioned in History Text Books for example").  

The game allows you to explore your feelings about war, unemployment, wealth, and other things all through your robots.  For instance, will your company and robots participate in a war?  Perhaps as non-combatants?  Will you replace human workers?  Do robots deserve wages?  Rights?  Feelings?  If they do demand wages, do you interject code to lower their autonomy?  So many great choices in this book/game.

I highly encourage this one.  Fantastic replayability especially for all the achievements.  I do wish there was a "back" button instead of having to replay the entire story sequence all over but overall, a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084258405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1669485974}

author: {'steamid': '76561198080741393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1575200555}
review:
Really enjoyed this. The choices offered where cleverer and more open than  I thought. Still I guess a revert Button or the possibility to save might have helped, since one will want to explore mutliple storylines and many descisions don't neccesarrily result in the expected outcome. 
The deemphasis of the technical barriers make the plot accessible, but also pull a lot of the SciFi potential out to make a simpler and more emotional narrative. 
Still would like to see more like this in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042020662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1498117270}
review: "IQ doesn't exist" yeah right, this game was made under the religion of equality, and outright refuses to go down the path that lays ahead. As a result it fails the task set before science fiction, thought experiment based on sound assumptions. Rest assured that none of what happens in this game will resemble what will happen in the near future. But if you like to fantasize about humans and roombas having equal rights then this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198366670581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1601852680}
review: Choices do matter, pretty interestiing overall

author: {'steamid': '76561198157990015', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2898, 'last_played': 1645935593}
review: Sure there are some bugs and some missed opportunities if you know where to look for them, but the positives outweigh them by far. The story and dialogue are quite well-written (with some especially interesting themes about the humanity of the robot-maker, and the ethics of AI-creation that you can interact with, for those interested). And yes, as many have reported long before me, the opportunities for all the things you can do and experiment with are so wide open, there's amazing replayability here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993781094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1572148212}
review:
Unfortunately I cannot recommend this. The writing/prose itself was OK -- definitely not advanced, but there weren't any errors and the story got across clearly. The plot however didn't make much sense. I had a great relationship with my robot and then it suddenly decided to rebel and try to kill me. None of my choices seemed to matter in the end. There was also a war that seemed to start for no reason. Also the ending seemed very disjoined from the rest of the story.

Overall I am very disappointed and I believe the "Overwhelmingly Positive" feedback of this story is misleading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195403662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1542587491}
review: This is the best choose your path I've ever played

author: {'steamid': '76561198029849180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1571105633}
review: For what this game was, it was FANTASTIC. A choose-your-own adventure narrative with decent replayability, a humourous tone that didn't take itself too seriously, well-researched technical detail flourish, fully realized characters, and best of all- a narrative that felt like it genuinely reacted to my choices and didn't railroad me into a particular outcome. Mostly, the results of my choices made sense and were relatively predictable, but with genuine chaotic surprises here and there too- just like real life. Not the longest game out there, and the UI was a bit barebones, but overall FANTASTIC>

author: {'steamid': '76561198052005007', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1570927271}
review: Pomimo braku obrazów czy dźwięku jest to niewątpliwie jedna z najlepszych gier w jakie grałem. Sporo czasu przybierałem się do tej produkcji aż w końcu zdecydowałem się kupić, ograć i nie żałuję. Polecam dla każdego kto lubi dobre historie ale też chce mieć na nie wpływ. Po ukończeniu czułem się trochę jakbym przeżył moje własne alternatywne życie. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971372939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1569336079}
review: I was looking forward to read/play Choice of Robots for quite some time, and finally had some hours to give it a go. Unfortunately, I found the writing to be underwhelming, which is a big deal for me. I was positively surprised with the variety in events, but the world and the environment seemed slightly naïve in its presentation. As with a good book, the writing itself should be captivating enough to not let you stop reading, but I found it way too easy in this case.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008110731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1439327654}
review:
[h1] You Don't Get to Go to the Moon [/h1]

Choice of Robots is a choice-based novel focusing on you creating artificially intelligent robots, where your choices influence the entire world in many different ways. Because there's literally no gameplay, music, or graphics, this allowed for the developers to create a game where every single choice matters to the main story. Even down to dialogue options, your choices can shape the world, ranging from you doing absolutely nothing and being a loser to taking over Alaska. The main story is technically a conflict between China and the US, which you can entirely circumvent, as well as how much sentience a robot should have. As your progress to the game, your "stats" will change based on choices which unlock new options and different branches, resulting in many different endings. The writing itself is mostly well-done, although at times you'll wish you could say or do certain things, but are obviously limited in the choices you can actually make.

It should be reiterated that this is a choose-your-own adventure novel and could barely be classified as a game. The only "gamey" parts are the progression and RPG mechanics as your stats go up and down. The sheer amount of possibilities and scenarios you optionally deal with makes this something you will want to play over and over again. However, since there's so much replay value, it'd be nice if there was a mechanic where if you already did a choice it will tell you what stats that choice effects, so you don't have to reread everything. Overall, this is the best of these types of "games" I played on here.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Excellent story
[*]Many, many choices to experiment with
[*]Unexpected outcomes, as well as choices you hoped for that actually appear
[*]Romantic options are fun
[*]You can take over Alaska
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]This is not a game
[*]Yet still a lot of it can be "cheesed" once you play through more than once
[*]It's annoying to go through the more minor sections over and over again sometimes
[*]Your choices can be limited by extremely strict requirements
[*]No mention of if water is a weakness of the robots
[/list]

[b] Verdict: 8/10 [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198042261375', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3685, 'last_played': 1466023419}
review:
Review has spoilers!




There's a few places where the seams of the branching paths show, and frankly it's disappointing that on the Empathy path you can't tell the robot (after the threesome with you, him/her/rhe/rer/it, and your human romantic partner) that you'll build a robot duplicate of yourself (which is one of the possible endings already, for a different reason), so that nobody has to be alone.

It works out well in the endings where you are married, do build a robot duplicate, and choose to stick around and help the robot!player transition, after all.

Otherwise, it's an excellent story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960271994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 284, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1558786007}
review: yes

author: {'steamid': '76561198872077849', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1590802496}
review:
For my first journey, I spent 2.5 hours and was amazed to find out who I always am, and it really made me think about my life and future. At that time I felt grateful for experiencing such a wonderful and meaningful time.
However, for my second journey, I took the military path, and found some annoying details about Shanghai and China. As me and my family were all born in Shanghai, I feel that the author has never been to Shanghai himself, otherwise some descriptions would not seem so damn stupid.
I am currently receiving my postgraduate education in London. I really enjoy my life here in London, especially all the museums and galleries that we lack, but I don't think London, or any other metropolises are far better than Shanghai in terms of modernization. So please stop portraying Shanghai as a clumsy duplicate of an 'advanced western city'. We do not have any fake castles as the author imagined, but we do have a real one in our Disney Resort.
There are also a lot of outdated details about China. Unfortunately the author's knowledge of China is only limited to the old times, and most probably to what presented by the western media (as they wish).
Finally, I really regret that such an excellent work is now ruined to me due to some narrow views of the author. I intended to try the other works of the studio, but now I never will. Farewell, 'choice of games'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053220659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1573670374}
review: One of the best games CoG has to offer. It gives you a great variety of choices, starting with customizing your own robot and its (her, his, rhim) behavior. Will you start your own company, or end up under someone else's wing? Will you support your nation in a war or stay out of it? Are you capable of commiting treason? How about an opportunity to develop surgical technology to save lives? Maybe you want to make intelligent cars? Or marry a robot? Or even became a robot yourself?.. You can do all of that — and so much more. This game has an amazing replay value, and I encourage everyone to try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334204270', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1565136629}
review: Without a doubt this is the single best game I have ever purchased. Just did first playthrough, there's so many ways to take the story and I'm very curious to see where the other paths in this story go. The story itself is incredibly well made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050154373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1562616039}
review:
I enjoyed this one. My choices seemed to have real weight after playing it a couple times. Although I've mainly gone for variations of a "benevolent" playthrough, I believe there are several more unique stories to tell. The ending does a good job resolving the story while keeping me engaged with additional choices.

[list]
  [*][b]Overall:[/b] 8/10
  [*][b]Story:[/b] 8/10
  [*][b]Choices:[/b] 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198849202629', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1648353369}
review:
很不错的游戏，本想着探求世界的秘密，
后来身不由己，开办公司、涉入战争，
一不小心逃到了加拿大，
只是为了救一个无关紧要的朋友，
之后当两面派，中美两方周旋，做了亿万富翁
又造了一个机器人，恋爱、结婚、收养小孩、人生赢家
后得病，选择了手术，更像机器人，HAPPY ENDING
很幸福，但不是我想要的，
或者坚持寻求世界真相，一生在解谜的路上
或者君临天下。端坐神灵殿堂
这才是我渴望的路，渴望书写传奇
这游戏很好，让你在经历一生后明白自己想要什么，更加坚定向前走去
凯撒与摩西是诅咒我一生的两个名字，知道自己的结局，不后悔

第三周目，建立帝国，统治世界，最后弥留之际
以自己为原本，制造出美丽、强大的机器人
坦然地迎接死亡
这是我想要的传奇

author: {'steamid': '76561198053092806', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1559674056}
