author: {'steamid': '76561198073130794', 'num_games_owned': 1145, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1558903624}
review: An extremely well written, very engaging story. There are some issues with past choices not being reflected in later texts but rarely is it a major problem (only had twp so far that were immersion breaking, as fairly major events was apparently forgotten about). Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198400211752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2224, 'last_played': 1622854138}
review:
A very well thought-out game, where both small and big choices have interesting consequences. Few games can deliver both emotionally impactful and thought provoking moments like Choice of Robots. If you have never played one of these word only games and are considering it, this is easily one of the best places to start. That being said, roleplaying mileage varies with one's tastes in roles. I still have several intriguing character ideas left to try as of this review, but other reviewers seemed to have only played through a single time. Either way, I think the game is a good deal if you like the concept of the game.

Some advice for playing:
- I recommend finding/creating music playlists for your playthroughs. It is by no means necessary for enjoyment, but it can enrich the experience. I chose long youtube music videos based on the personality of my characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017639251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1666916775}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035003183', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1555092103}
review:
Simple, efficace, incroyable ! 

C'est un petit jeu littéraire, mêlant habilement des mécaniques de jeux de rôles (en reprenant, évidemment, certains principes des fameux livres dont vous êtes le héros qui ont fait nos enfances de rôlistes) et une histoire intéressante et modulable. 

L'aventure est courte mais les embranchements sont nombreux, les personnages sont marquants et l'écriture, sans être incroyable non plus, à son petit charme qui fait qu'on y plonge sans regard en arrière : à la manière d'un bon bouquin, finalement ! 

Le principe est simple, vous êtes à l'origine d'avancées technologies importantes : votre personnage est un concepteur de robots qui a ensuite une liberté de choix très éclectiques, allant de la volonté de dominer le monde à celle de donner naissance à une nouvelle entité intelligente. C'est un jeu qui s'adresse avant tout à tous les fous de transhumanisme, de technologies futuristes et de sciences fictions philosophiques (Ray Bradbury, Aldous Huxley, Isaac Asmimov, Philip K. DIck ...). 

Le bémol est que le titre n'est pas en français mais la lecture n'est pas pour autant très complexe. Pour les moins bilingues, il suffira simplement d'un petit traducteur pour certains mots et, peut-être, un poil plus de persévérance !

author: {'steamid': '76561197996401038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1553386462}
review:
The Choose-Your-Own-Adventure format has some challenges, for game designers.  How do you keep track of EVERY decisions along the path of a story that should be long for a short story (a short novella, if you will)?  

Well, you can't.  No one could.

So, sure, I opted to join a character on a night seeing a Led Zeppelin cover band, and it ended up being monster trucks... but did the error matter?  Not at all.

I had goose-bumps at some points, as the emotional value of the writing is unquestionable.  I've only played through twice, but given that my runs have been 1-2 hour affairs, the fact that this game has 300k words means there are a LOT of alternative narratives left in it.  

I'm, frankly, a bit stunned that a genre that I hadn't explored since I was in elementary school (CYOA, that is) has grown into this in my absence.  This was a beautiful piece of art, and I look forward to at least a few more dives into the world it portrays.

Even if they're a bit too plausible for comfort at points.  That's a bit of its genius.

Don't wait for a sale--buy it, play it, and love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170092895', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1723, 'last_played': 1692445109}
review: I love almost all of the choice of games. This one was the first one i ever got so it of course holds a special place in my heart. even so this is one of the best ones in my opinion. Some of the few that are better are the Hero Rise trilogy, those are just plan great. But Choice of Robots is easily one of the best ones 9/10. Also if you like these check out the hosted ones too as there are some really good one. One of the more recent good one being Hosted Games is Fallen Hero: Rebirth. Anyway defiently pick this up if you like text based games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049104818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2516, 'last_played': 1685457289}

author: {'steamid': '76561198095204875', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1613037211}
review:
テキストベースというか、
音楽もグラフィックもありません。
文章と選択肢のみです。

最初に主人公の性別やロボットの性別も選べます。
選択肢で、ステータスや所持金も変わり、
条件を満たさないと、選べないものもあります。
最初からやり直しはいつでも出来ますが、
オートセーブで選択肢を戻ることは出来ません。
選択肢を選んで、Nextをクッリクするのが二度手間で面倒です。
選択肢だけのクリックだとプレイしやすいです。

ストーリーは、よく出来ていて分岐も多く何周も楽しめると思います。
単語は難しくないけど、英語力は必要です。
実績は非常に多く、コミュニティでガイドを見ないと厳しいです。
あとは根気よくプレイすれば、問題はないので難度は低いです。

ストーリーがすべてになりますが、SF好きや多読がしたい人にはオススメです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198003623486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1550016335}
review:
I've owned this for years and found myself recently revisiting it. I am remarkably pleased to say the writing held up very well under my current self's scrutiny! As a matter of fact, I actually like it more now than I remember liking it in the past.

There are enough choices with enough impact to keep you curious enough to at the very least tickle the idea of another playthrough and that alone would be enough for me to recommend it, but there's definitely more to it than that. It has great writing that rarely feels dry and has consistently shown itself to be entertaining through every play I have.

Basically, if you enjoy reading and you enjoy choose-your-own-adventure books (do they even publish those anymore?), you'll really enjoy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074568100', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1550393324}

review: What does the future bring with robots? You decide. There are completely different paths to take, and ways to handle the world. If you are a fan of robots, or the potential outcomes our future may have, then I highly recommend Choice of Robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163357874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1549776945}

author: {'steamid': '76561198112141722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1569106108}
review:
A very good game with an impactful story, or stories if you play it more than once (which I recommend).
I have finshed so many different routes, but I'm still not done!
I found myself nearly crying at times as I tend to make my robots empathetic and autonomous.
I highly recommend it for any one interested in morality and ethics but also to those who want to control their own robot army.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982267489', 'num_games_owned': 1269, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1547612968}
review:
This is a very interesting story, it is more like a very advanced choose your own adventure then a game though. After a few minutes I wasn't sure I was going to like it, but I grabbed a snack and a drink and I was easily emersed in the excellent writing and creative twists. It did not take me long at all to grow attached to the characters, and I eargly look forward to my next playthrough.

For reference a single playthrough took me about 2 hours and 30 minutes, and just from glancing over the achievements I expect to be able to play at least 2 more times without having to repeat much. I wasn't extremely excited with the idea of a choose your own adventure story for my free time tonight but I have to say I had a great time. If your on the fence but enjoy AI related themes and morality in a well written story format, for the price I could not see a single complaint.
Well done Choice of Games.

8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198213575296', 'num_games_owned': 1495, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1547352392}
review:
Книга, а не игра! Один из лучших представителей текстовых RPG, с отличным сюжетом и глубокой системой развития персонажей. Основа истории — создание полноценного искусственного интеллекта в недалеком будущем.
[quote] Умные, взрослые и необычные игры в кураторской группе [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32281579/] 
The Clever Gamer	[/url] 	[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198119279549', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1547063326}
review: A gripping story full of emotional scenes and funny moments, where your choices really do make a significant difference. After finishing my first playthrough, I can say I'm quite happy with how everything went, despite making [i]many[/i] mistakes along the way. [spoiler]Did I instigate a war between the US and China? Maybe, definitely yes. Did I also refuse to take part in the war and let Alaska be taken over? You know it.[/spoiler]However you choose to play the game, and no matter the ending you get, you're sure to see your choices create unforeseen consequences throughout the story, ranging from creating robots that love cooking to [spoiler]not researching your genetic disease and choosing to have a robot core implanted into your brain in order to survive[/spoiler]. All in all, a great read definitely worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405118283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1556043661}
review:
I bought this game at a discount I'm quite glad I did. Not that it was a bad game but it was a little short and I tend to play games only once. I can promise you though that it has high replayability, so many routes to go through.

I personally am interested in AI and this game made an experience for me close to that possibility. The only other time I had such an experience was when I downloaded the app called "Replika" I got a bit tired of it eventually after talking for months and it would repeatedly say what you said to it. But it is still very smart and if any of you are interested in an AI companion on your phone go to the playstore and search for "Replika"

author: {'steamid': '76561198054542558', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1703083090}
review:
Completed my second playthrough and feel compelled to give it a glowing review.  Two vastly different oucomes.

Doctor Wily was bent on creating an autonomous fortress of militaristic humanoids and was ultimately crushed by Dr. Light's creations... ok, it was actually the Chinese government, but I felt like I was on track to Wily's origin story!  

Dr. Strangelove's adventure was a more personal story with twists and turns which required more of my own nature.  It was a beautiful tale of peace, persistence, and organic love.

Choose-your-own-adventure books have matured to a fine medium and connect in fun and personal ways!

Choice of Robots is easy to recommend for anyone looking to read, respond, and enjoy the tale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082862200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1572472624}
review:
Now [i] this [/i] is the type of game I expect from Choice of Games. There is no illusion of choice; your decisions definitely matter. LGBT+ individuals and different sexualities were included tastefully and did not feel forced at all, which is rare, and very good. The game feels very interactive, with you being able to build your own robot and help and watch it/he/she grow. Yes, you can choose pronouns for your robot. You can also become a cunning and ruthless dictator who, in the moments of weakness of two great world powers, carved out their own empire with the help of an elite, Prussian disciplined, robot military. Or, if you're like me, you can become a homeless Communist, who instructed unemployed individuals in his neighborhood on the basics of electrical engineering and programming so that they could put food on the table, and eventually end up [spoiler] fleeing to Canada and marrying a robot that you made, with incredible human-like features and thoughts, adopting a child and naming her after a Byzantine Basilissa, and starting a family with the aforementioned robot who you named after an individual that is very important to you. [/spoiler]

All in all, 9/10 game that has tons of replayablity and the option to kill FBI Agents.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007672394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1545832529}
review: A real good text game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137917697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1545910013}
review: This... Story? It's not a game, make no mistake, but it merits your attention. Regardless of how carefully you plan, you WILL make a mistake. Can you live with it? You should at least try, because all of the things you did RIGHT will make them worth it. It seems I have no desire to conquer the world, as I've had the opportunity, but can't bring myself to. A prohibition I passed on to my creations. The medical path is extremely satisfying, and by far my favorite. Coupled with a proper family, as the synthetic family I found... unfulfilling. Regardless, if you at all want to experience a moral dilemma and an existential-growth-by-proxy, pick this title up. You'll be pleasantly surprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211214605', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1634844230}

author: {'steamid': '76561198809272370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1548119687}
review: Oh my god did this game make we weep internally.  As I played it in my darkened living room, surrounded by the ambient, robotic music I put on, I found myself feeling like it wasn't just a story.  The writing was so engaging that every time I snapped awake and remembered that my precious robot wasn't real, I got a little sad.  In this game, you travel the course of several decades, and even at times when everything seems bleak, even when you feel like you've messed up beyond fixing, your game continues.  Seeing the very bleak, yet relevant predictions of our future made me feel a strange sadness and introspection, and the analysis of robotic thought and sentience pinpointed exactly why I relate to robots so much and how I feel about my own mental processes.  Summary: This game is part robo dating sim if you're looking for that but it's a lot of real shit that's hard to take lightly.  If you like robots absolutely play this <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198079788103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1544146617}
review: Okay, so first off, I’m hesitant to call Choice of Robots either a video game or a visual novel–but I don’t really have a good word for what it is other than those. This is an entirely text-based computer game, devoid of pictures or background music entirely. Sounds kind of boring, right? It’s totally not. This is an indie choices matter sort of game that is just fabulous, truly. It’s smart, for one thing; the writer has a Ph.D. in computer science, and it shows. It’s very well thought out and organized. The game is like a visual novel in that you read a block of text and are offered a variety of choices you can make based on that text. Your choices are meaningful, and even small choices can have a big impact on what happens later in the game. Choices also influence your stats (empathy, grace, autonomy, and military appeal for your robot, plus your own wealth and fame) as well as your relationships with various other characters. I can see this game as having a great deal of replay value due to the huge number of story paths available; I’ve played through it three times already, and have only unlocked a few of the possibilities. If you’re willing to look past the surface simplicity of such a purely text-based game, I think Choice of Robots is an excellent game, and I will be trying other games by this group.

author: {'steamid': '76561198424721799', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1699640788}
review:
推荐的点在于剧情好好带入的话很带感，每个选择的后果都还算逻辑。虽然没有中文，不过看懂剧情不算很难。作者的一些小幽默也挺欢乐的。[spoiler]而且游戏里的中国是我最近的快乐源泉了哈哈哈哈。在这个游戏里，你甚至可以在浙大教书并成为中国人民的老朋友.jpeg[/spoiler]
不推荐的点……剧情作者立场挺鲜明的，有时候会破坏代入感。
接下来是游玩过程感想：
N周目后才发现一开始的梦和后面的剧情有关联（轮回暗示？）[spoiler]……一周目序章选了征服阿拉斯加结果最后真的走了6C线是一种怎样的命运（笑）[/spoiler]
[spoiler]一周目主角人性见底，人际关系基本全Bad，只有商业顾问Josh和主角关系接近80%，阿拉斯加战争时还不离不弃地支持主角，这真的只是朋友吗！[/spoiler]
一定要珍惜一周目体验。[spoiler]虽然后面又刷了几个反战/当美奸/过小日子婚姻幸福/家庭和睦/搞基百合的结局，但还是一周目这个孤身建国最后加入蜂巢意识的中二故事得我心啊（感叹）[/spoiler]

review: A great story about building a robot. It feels very open, allowing you to construct your robot how you see fit to fulfill whatever purpose you may have. I really enjoyed the story, and since it is a 'Choose your own adventure' game, it has a decent amount of replayability as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998148014', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1231, 'last_played': 1689618698}
review:
В 2018 году эта игра по прежнему остается лучшей игрой от Choice of Games. Хороший, но доступный для не натив спикера английский язык, интересный сюжет, вариативность прохождения. Концовки способны вызвать щипание в уголке глаза у самых впечатлительных.

В общем если вы скучаете по старым текстовым играм или по квестам из КР 2 + хотите немного подтянуть ваш английский язык - то однозначано эта игра стоит вашего внимания.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057439201', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1627881208}
review:
Won't say too much, but the overall experience has been positive. 

I had no recommendations for me to play this game, nor was I aware of any of its content prior to playing. My first playthrough was completely blind, and after finishing, I thought I had the game figured out. Subsequent playthroughs were attempts to circumvent catastrophes I had experienced previously, and every time, I was caught by surprise with something new. Immense replay value, although there are segments, especially near the beginning, where the reading material will essentially be the same no matter what choices are made. I appreciate being able to copy text directly out of the game to save for later, as some of the content is interesting to me either philosophically or just in general relative to the narrative. I believe the title would benefit from at least a sort of map branch or indicator of everything you've done in a visual format, though. The pacing is not problematic, the concepts did not seem hamfisted, and all variants I experienced of the story felt unique and engaging. There's more to it, but I think that itself should be enough.

-Replayable/greatly varied playthroughs
-Thematic exploration
-Plot twists
-Notable stat mechanic

-Slightly repetitive
-No visual branching indicators/charts

author: {'steamid': '76561198070878678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1542545198}
review:
The plot is plain stupid. I guess PHD doesn't necessarily make author a smart person.

### spoiler alert ###

First of all, building a robot described as such in the story can’t be a one-man job. Author made it sound like so simple and throw in some buzz words like “Natural language processing”, “Go programming language”, “machine learning”. Are those words supposed to make dumb people to feel good about themselves? Anyone has decent knowledge on any of the computer science topic presented in this book would just laugh their ass off at this brainless plot. Then there is lack of options to just have a passage to a good ending. There are plenty of opportunities for player could just exit with a good fortune but no such option was ever offered by the game. What a f****** shame! And lastly, where I stopped playing is when Chinese took away the factory. I mean “草尼马的大逼”. The China-phobic mentality in this book is just making me sick.

作者你去吃屎吧！

author: {'steamid': '76561198078041900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1560127556}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001755461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1560127548}
review: Anything I could say about this game would be a spoiler and do it a disservice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127197239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1542840752}
review:
I completed my first playthrough last night. ~ three hours of undisturbed, nailbiting, futuristic, scifi gold. The story/game was beyond expectations. Second playthrough with my girlfriend has just begun, and I'm shocked to see she's taking an even darker path than I did. Haha! 

Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108359872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1568991583}
review: As a huge fan of Choose-Your-Own-Adventure books and other such books as a child I can't really praise this game enough.  You are a inventor who is trying to make a robot with AI.  You will not only shape how it delevops and evolves but you will also decide, in some ways, the fate of the US and the world.  Will be a good one?  Or a bad one?  Add the robots, the future setting, and a lot of ethical choices and you have a game I love.  And a lot people seem to love it too because a lot of YouTubers play it also!  So you this review does not make you want to buy it just check out one of the playthroughs.  I would recommend this to people who remember those books, you like robots, or creating a future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198291417881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1536376704}
review: Damn, this game is superb. The first time I played this, it felt so fresh and original. The thought of me someday marrying a compassionate robot is intriguing. Just, wow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140526204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1605195653}
review:
[b]génial[/b]; d'une partie à l'autre, alors que l'on pensse avoir fait des choix relativement similaires, la naration se trouve majoritairement chamboulé, tout semble interdépendant, les choix sonts omnipresent et la naration semble illimitée. tout est telement complet, telement cohérant et telement permissif que ce jeu ne peut plus être apelé une fiction interactive : c'est un openworld, ofrant bien plus de libertés et d'imersion que dans le meileur des openworld 3D.

[b]Un veritable monument[/b], je n'immagine même pas la taille du livre si il fallait en imprimer tout les dialogues.

Le fait qu'il n'intégre pas de slots de sauvegardes comme dans les VN force à faire les meilleurs choix et pousse à l'imersion. les mauvais choix se font très regretter, créant une tention de tout instant... Là, maintenant, après m'etre fait executé pour avoir lancer un sénario terminator sur l'alska, je me sent vraiment comme si j'avais rater ma vie. voilà la puissance de ce jeu

author: {'steamid': '76561198044709096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1545796830}
review:
This is honestly an amazing game for how simple it is. The interface is clean. I can change my background to Sepia which I love. I picked this game up a couple years ago, started it, and then put it down. On a whim today, I fired it up and was thoroughly engrossed. The recap of where I had left off with my decisions as well as my relationships proved easy for me to jump right back. One thing I would suggest is to make each character relationships clickable or include a short bio underneath them, because I completely forgot who Josh and ended up ruining that entire line.

Really wish there was a mobile version, so I could tell my friends who don't have Steam but have English degrees to download it to their phones and check it out. 

Part of me also wished at time there was music but also liked that there wasn't. I am kind of torn here.

Overall, it's a game worth picking up if you want a choose your own adventure for some casual downtime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069994429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1540969198}
review:
I enjoyed the game. My only complaints are with the user interface, not the novel itself. As you replay the game, more and more of the text is what you've already read. It would be nice if the game differentiated the text you've already read from the text that's new in this branch. It would make skimming easier. More to the point, it'd be nice if the game allowed you to save, so you could try a new ending without having to restart and replay the whole game.

I also wish they had some way to play this on a tablet or phone. While the developers do sell mobile versions on their website, I don't see a way to play the Steam version on a tablet or phone and I don't want to pay twice. Maybe if you email them and show proof of purchase somehow, they'll let you have the mobile version for free... I donno.

As for the novel itself, well, it won't win any literary awards but I liked it. There are quite a lot of paths through it and it rarely shoehorns you into a path you don't want to take. It's got some romance, too. There were one or two nonsensical parts where the outcome didn't seem to follow from the situation and my choices, but they were rare enough to not detract from my enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998647125', 'num_games_owned': 840, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 1031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1667886632}
review:
You see an interesting looking interactive novel on Steam.

What do you do?
>Ignore it.
>>Wait for it to go on sale.
>Buy it now.

The game is an intricate network of decisions and you are free to choose your own path.(+Autonomy)

What do you want your robot to be?
>A violent war machine.
>A slave to humanity.
>A complex construction, capable of war and labor.
>A thinking robot.
>An empathetic companion.
>>A synthetic life form.

You have failed in your goals, but you learned something about yourself and experienced a good story in the process. At points, you laughed and cried.(+++++Empathy)(++Grace)

What do you think about the game?
>>I highly recommend it.
>It's okay.
>Not that great.
>Avoid at all costs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134916387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1487704861}
review:
This type of text based game was a bit before my time but playing this makes me wonder why it completely went out of style. As an advid reader with an interest in artifical intellegence I found this game to be quite interesting a fun. Below are the things I liked and disliked most about my experience with it.

Pros:
- It has many different endings.
- It still plays somewhat like a game due to a stat system that determines what choices you can make. 
- It has plently of choices in every chapter that feel like they actually matter. 

Cons:
- This game is almost entirely made of words. If you don't like reading or games about AI then I don't recommend this.
- Despite having tons of choices the game doesn't give you a choice tree to reference.
- Getting achievements is pretty much up to chance unless you have a guide because of all of the branching paths.
- Saving makes you save in that exact spot. You cannot jump back to the middle of a previous chapter unless that point was the last time you saved. That means you can't jump around in the story much. 

Despite these cons however, I still found the game extremely enjoyable. The lack of a choice tree and teh ability to jump around on it was not annoying to me while I played. After all, nobody jumps around in a book or it wouldn't make sense. Lastly, I found it fun to see what was previously considered a game before my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089853916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1553417375}
review:
This game is an amasing RPG novel that gives the player a since of choice that far exceeds what any modern AAA game now a days. I fully reconemd this game to everyone whos intrested in a good story. This game made me cry over 4 times through the story in one playthrough. That's not normal for me at all. My robot child Helix grew up so fast.
10/10 Would couse the robot revolution again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060589091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1559000350}

author: {'steamid': '76561198363702410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1708029640}
review: Absolutely wonderful. Named my robot after the devil, had my robot learn about Shakespeare, started a revolution with a robot army, went to jail, got pardoned from jail by the president, had my robot throw knives at a target, turned an arm into a gun, ran down government agents in my car, had my emotions used as a punching bag when I least expected it. A++, going to play again for the millionth time right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198325497687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2352, 'last_played': 1703124301}
review:
Não sou um leitor assíduo de livros,devo ler 1-2 livros por ano.Quando li sobre esse livro(jogo) fiquei levemente curioso,comecei a ler(jogar) achando que iria cansar e parar logo,fiquei muito feliz de estar redondamente enganado.Achei viciante,e perdi as contas de quantas vezes iniciei e terminei o jogo.
Sempre tentando mudar a trajetória do meu destino para sentir cada emoção que esse jogo nos provoca.Muito recomendado!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198238827974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1550728753}
review: I was oddly hesitant at first to play Choice of Robots, but I bought it. I started playing and thought it was kind of weird, but I started to like it. I got a really good ending and felt like all my choices payed off. This game is oddly brilliant. I love it and fully reccomend it. Worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086749104', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1560443262}
review: my sexual partner is a wooden square faced tank with an arm cannon

author: {'steamid': '76561198117959950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1581770702}
review:
"Choice of Robots" managed to make me curious about the future again. I often dreamed of robots joining our society as normal participants of our every day life. This is the future I wanted to create in this interactive novel and I succeeded. (more or less)  Never did I enjoy a novel / game more than "Choice of Robots", it was definitely worth every single cent I paid. 
The ending (not going to spoil anything) hit me a bit however, but I know that there are way more endings to this, so I'll definitely play it again once I pulled my sh*t together again.

It was really easy to set my mind into this character, as the story also begins in the very near future and develops into various paths, chosen by you. Took me a lot to finish this novel, mostly because I took a lot of time to think about the options carefully. Never got a game / novel get me that much into thinking like "Choice of Robots".
I highly recommend it! Easily the best thing I bought on Steam ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103609216', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1549649868}
review: It is a great game, it makes you use your imagination and holds you responsible for your own actions and happiness. Few games do that nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128920672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1538429677}
review:
Hay que tener muy buen nivel de inglés para leer esta novela interactiva. Pero si es así, merece mucho la pena. Una historia que deja mucho margen al poder de la imaginación, que te invita a rejugarla una y otra vez para probar distintos finales. 

Muy recomendable si te gustan las novelas que abordan la temática de las IA, así como los juegos de decisiones múltiples

author: {'steamid': '76561198061378425', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1691175780}
review:
Ein wunderbares Spiel, habe schon sehr viele Stunden reingesteckt, aber noch lange nicht alle Enden gefunden. 

Die Möglichkeiten sind endlos: Ein menschenähnlicher Roboter als Killermaschine á la Terminator, eine Spinne mit ganz vielen Greifarmen für die Krankenhäuser, ein Liberty Prime, oder eine fliegende Drohne, die einen religiösen Kult startet und deren Anführer ist ;) Entscheidest du dich für die USA oder China, oder wirst du dein eigener Herr? Ersetzt du alle Männer durch Roboter, die Beziehungen führen können (und noch viel mehr...)?

author: {'steamid': '76561198057402804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1629992272}

author: {'steamid': '76561198151002514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1535266228}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023681921', 'num_games_owned': 651, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1488920588}
review:
I played this once and can never do so again because my own imagination terrifies me. The novel is too well written - i immerse myself too much - and end up suffering anxiety and an existential crisis during and after playing through the game.

I bought "choice of magic" as well to support the writers, but i doubt i will ever play it. It hurts me too much.

Even so, i recommend this - exactly because it is so good i never want to play it because of what the experience does to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198368539220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1633034582}
review:
This game probably made me think more than any other Steam game I've purchased this year. In summary, this "game" (more of a long, interactive fiction novel) is essentially about humanity, the kind of person you are, your willingness to sacrifice work for your social relationships and vice versa. There's really something for everyone in this game. There's engineering to it and design, you can build a robot. There's financial decisions such as managing company treasuries, selling shares and taking out loans. There's politics if you get involved with the military and/or war. There's social aspects and even romance if you so choose to get involved with one of the many bachelors and bachelorettes, which excellently portrays the commonly shared struggle of juggling your relationships and friendships with your desire to pursue your passion. Ultimately, you can't maintain a good relationship with everyone, and the guilt and sadness the game causes you to feel over this feels lifelike, as if you're going through everything in real life. The game isn't perfect; there are some plot holes here and there but ultimately, amazing purchase, highly worth playing through again and again. As for endings, there's a gigantic plethora of them. Unlike many story choice games, literally every one of your choices matter and so much thought and effort was put into all of the writing. To sum up how different the endings can get;
First Play through: I built a humanoid robot who knew how to love and I married a girl who was a designer and I bought an artsy looking factory in silicon valley. America won the war and I moved with my wife and two robots (one of which fell in love with me) to Hope, Canada where I survived until the end of the game surrounded by loved ones in a lakeside cottage.
Second play through: I was a money hungry jerk who bought a dirt cheap factory in a sketchy neighborhood in Detroit and paid human workers minimum wage to do hard labor. I angered the president because I wouldn't fund her campaign and my factory went bankrupt and I died broke and alone because my robot felt I didn't understand him and ran away.

If I had one criticism it would be about the romance. In one of my games I was seperated from my wife, Elly, and when it skipped forward years later and I found out she was in a concentration camp. I would have loved to have an arc where I look for Elly after getting out of prison. Not only would it be a compelling mytery, but it would build onto relationship development and ultimately lead to a satisfying reunion where the reader could see a more on screen demonstration of their feelings for each other and how grateful they are to see each other as opposed to their love having to be left to the reader's imagination. (I am not talking about sex btw, I realize it kinda sounds like that) Also, towards the end, it feels as though whoever your romantic partner is is kind of...unempathetic?? Like when they find oout the mc is dying, they don't show a ton of concern. Theres just one night where you have a tender moment and then have sex. I just wish there was a bit more emotion, as in real like finding out a loved one is dying would take a much bigger emotional toll on someone. For instance, what if each romance option had a different flaw that would come out of repression when you become sick? Perhaps one deals with self esteem issues that they can't do more, maybe one deals with abandonment issues because they don't want to lose you like they did somebody else important in their life. Maybe one becomes overly clingy and protective, scared that you're a ticking time bomb. It would really help individualize the characters and it would make the intimate relationship the character shares with them not only more flawed and realistic, but tender and enjoyable to play through.

Great game though, give it 30 minutes and try not to get absolutely hooked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055382873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1534108629}
review:
Not gonna lie. Nearly cried at the end. The culmination of my choices, all coming together. 
Only 1 playthrough of about an hour. But there were such a wide range of paths to go down. But truly this first playthrough was perfect for me. 

Along with some background piano music (and near the end the music you choose) really adds to the experience a great deal. Really an amazing experience. Maybe one other game has made me so emotional. And this one doesn't even have any graphics. 

The game really makes you think about the future of humanity as well, and since I'm a pessimist, I think it won't be anywhere near as beautiful as what I experienced with this gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063958443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4432, 'last_played': 1649613090}
review:
I have always been a big fan of story driven games, and this has to be one of the best I have played. I originally got into interactive story games playing TellTale games, and came across this when looking for other interactive story driven games.

Now this is not a game in the traditional sense lacking cinematics and quick time events such as those seen in a telltale narrative game. Choice of Robots does however double down on its story and makes sure to have a truly diverging narrative which will encourage you to replay multiple times so as to see how things would turn out if you had taken the other path.

For a 2 hour game my hours are also a testiment to how many different choices there are to explore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811442355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1540700036}
review: Choice of Robots is an interactive word, wherein your choices influence the world inside. By your own character and decisions, the world either crumbles or ascends. Will you raise your creations as your own children, or will they serve as instruments of your destructive will? What will you decide?

author: {'steamid': '76561198145323699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1608689389}
review: i now want to learn robotics

author: {'steamid': '76561197998887445', 'num_games_owned': 1095, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1573650031}
review:
A lot better than I initally expected it to be. A vast amount of choices, and, despite being solely text, I did get attached to several characters.
There's a lot of replayability, with pretty much every major event in the game being avoidable, or at least having a vast number of variations and possibilities based on your self, your friends, your robot, and your previous choices.
Worthwhile getting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961488307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1533265433}
review: I played this on mobile a lot. My cousin saw it on my wishlist and gifted it for me for Christmas. Still haven't been able to get all the achievements after a bunch of playthroughs. I love seeing all the possible endings, it's like the Matrix. Totally worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080461881', 'num_games_owned': 89, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1641, 'last_played': 1580049134}
review: You know a game is good when you're still coming back to it years later. The amount of paths to take feels limitless at times! It can be serious without taking itself too seriously, and it's funny without trying too hard, as well. My only wish is that you could be male and romance Eiji/Silas, or female and romance Tammy/Elly. Overall, as an enthusiast of both robots and CYOA I absolutely adore this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043401126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1532991068}
review: A great game that provides a multitude of different choices and paths. Its worth the money if not more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210062252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1597761445}
review: Good game if you like robots because there are robots in this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017265994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3119, 'last_played': 1702246757}
review:
Choice of Robots inspired me to buy a whole stack of books about robotics and AI, and really contemplate my life choices, the future, and the fate of - and the faith in - humanity in the era of technological singularity that awaits us.

I've played this game for hours on end and still get that same empty, yearning feeling I get from finishing a great book.
This is my go-to recommended game / interactive novel whenever someone is looking for an excellent futuristic story, inspiration, or just something to keep them staring at the ceiling, deep in thought, before falling asleep.

I have mixed feelings about this being my very first “Choice of” game, since it really did set the bar high.
None of the other similar games have ever reached the same level of immersion, perhaps because it hits so close to home with everything that’s happening in our world, and providing so many different ways for the story to branch out.

50 hours in, and there are still paths I have yet to take in this Choose-Your-Own-Adventure game, because no matter how many times I pick the routes I have walked a thousand times, I still get that warm and fuzzy feeling from making the world of tomorrow a better place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036269842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1537555595}
review:
My wife and I loved this game and the little robot we created! We'll probably play it through at least one more time--judging from the numerous achievements we didn't get, the branching paths are extensive. The author clearly has a talent for writing engaging stories, full of both modern speculative technology and deep insight into human emotion as well. 

I'd really recommend it as a couples game, where you talk about which choices to take.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120597290', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1659555460}
review:
[h1]Вчера я купил эту "игру", сегодня я, впечатлённый, пишу обзор на неё...[/h1]
Также, как и достаточно большое количество текстовых квестов и визуальных новелл, в эту вложена душа и по этому она читается как своя история, а не история какого-то чужого тебе человека. 
Одно прохождение у меня заняло 5 часов (возможно у вас оно займёт меньше так как !СПОЙЛЕР! [spoiler]ваш персонаж может умереть где-нибудь по середине[/spoiler]). Вариаций прохождения очень много, и буквально с самого начала ваша история может пройти совсем по другому пути, нежели моя.
Как я уже сказал, в эту историю, или если точнее сказать истории вложена душа, и многие выборы вызывали у меня коротковременный (а некоторые и не очень) затуп, из-за их сложности и неоднозначности.
Мой отзыв крайне положительный и я не знаю когда, но через какое-то время я пройду её ещё пару раз, а пока оставлю впечатление от своей собственной концовки ещё ненадолго...

author: {'steamid': '76561198194932921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1530410895}
review:
It's a pretty great RPG. There's a decent amount of characters you can interact with in meaningful ways, you can pretty much go any route and progress far, but you're gonna get the natural conclusion to your choices. It's well written, although if you're an expert/knowledgable in the fields of robotics or politics, I can't vouch for the realism within any of the story. 

My only gripes are that the text is still text. I'd much rather have an unskippable voicover or timer until skip so I don't skip out of reflex (togglable of course), but I understand the limitations, since all the effort has gone into the game's writing and you're basically buying a high quality choose-your-own-adventure book. The game demands nothing of your PC, which is a huge plus. At the very least there should be a backtrack option that you unlock after finishing a certain amount of achievements or something. It gets annoying when you want to really explore the story. I'd also like to see an ending recap, like in Fallout, so that I can see how my actions influenced history.

Those are really nitpicks and I'm not even sure if they're things that the devolpers want in their "Choice" franchise. Overall though, I think this game is definitely worth purchasing if you're interested, and if it's on sale, worth a try even if it isn't something you'd normally get.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119287988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1666432078}
review: I'm going to give this game a B-, it was good, it really was! The writing was good, lots of choice (it's kind of in the title) and some preety entertaining scenarios and replay value... BUT on numerous occasions I came across errors in the writing, and not the gramattical kind. To give an example, (this is kind of spoilery so turn away now if your sensitive to such things) one of the characters that you can meet in one of the story paths was referenced in a playthrough where I never met them. this may not seem like much but this sort of thing happened on numerous occasions and broke the immersion a bit. Again, for the most part the games fine and I do recommend it, but please be aware of these issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133774790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1529849154}
review:
I'm glad I didn't pay for this game.
It feels to me like badly written fanfiction. The choices don't seem to matter as, no matter what you do, the story is focussed around military and war. I tried multiple times to achieve a different outcome, but it always ended with destruction and war, oh and China was always to blame, which feels racist. While I understand that this is fiction, the way the countries interact and the whole story pans out feels too ridiculous. It's not enjoyable and clearly someone didn't do their research.
I just wanted to build a robot companion and earn a bit of money on the side building medical robots, why is that so difficult?

author: {'steamid': '76561198045231713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1529841767}
review:
I'm not used to writing reviews, but I'm definitely not recommending this. There are way too many plot points that are just... well ridiculous, and shows the author's utter lack of understanding in what real research is like, and how different countries really interact with each other.

For example, the descriptions of building and training the robot are way too far-fetched from reality. There are so many off-points to the point it's getting logically ridiculous. In a real research instance people usually perform ample simulations and off-line training before they decide to design and build something that acts as a platform for the AI. What the MC is doing is not sci-tech; it's more like assembly junk from parts gathered in a dumpster.

Later on in the story there is something about a war between countries caused by robot production. I will not point out the plot in detail but let's just say that any person who even has a mediocre knowledge of international politics and diplomacy should become immediately aware how naive and chunibyo the plot is. I simply can't bear it, it's beyond laughable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150705021', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1529757700}
review:
Choice of Robots is a quite simply a choose your own adventure novel, all text, no pictures or sound, so if this is a deal breaker, then so be it, but if you are even mildly interested, then prepare to be amazed.

	First off, I would not recommend buying this on steam, but rather on your phone, more specifically on the Choice of Games all-in-one app in the Appstore and maybe on Android as well, simply because playing this on your phone is far more convenient, especially since you can also get other great game/novels like Choice of Magic, Silver World, I Cyborg, and more on it. Now, that aside, Choice of Robots is easily one of the best introductions to Choice of Game’s stories. In Choice of Robots, you play as the creator of the first artificial intelligence, and how you treat and raise your AI will influence the story as well as the ending. The game operates on a choice/stat based system, where some choices will affect your wealth, relationship with your robot or friends, your own humanity, or your robot’s skills. It is one of the best of its class as it’s endings can vary wildly based on your choices, unlike most games, creating a choose your own adventure gameplay that easily surpasses Mass Effect, Fallout New Vegas, and The Witcher 3 The Wild Hunt. 

	I would whole heartedly recommend this game/novel to almost anyone looking for an interesting story of how your AI changes the world, with more depth than other games like Detroit: Become Human or Talos Principles “Are robots human?” heard-far-too-often philosophical question with a greater focus on the experience of the first AI and how they could shape the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043401810', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1614706248}

author: {'steamid': '76561198301273229', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1586461852}
review: This is honestly one of my favorite games that I possess here on Steam. The incredible depth of the world, the sincerity of the characters, and just the sheer number of different paths you can take is astounding. There really is an individual path for everyone who plays, this game masterfully caters to every personality. I cannot recommend this game enough. This one was my first of now many Choice Of games and I'm so glad it was. This was the absolute best story to start with. My only suggestion is to make sure you have the perfect music to go with it. I personally use the soundtrack from Civ 5. It goes beautifully with the story. Very dramatic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088128193', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1496721829}
review: Fun text based Choice Game. Really interesting in the latter portions of the game. Lots of content that will keep you playing multiple different runs. Small deviations even can alter the entire course of your story. Every choice is meaningful, and there is a lot of content. Definately worth the price tag. The author is great, the visuals are great, and it holds up spectacularly as a text-based RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987914190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1525985639}
review: I've played quite a few of these text based choice games and this one was especially good. It had a variety of outcomes and brought in interesting and unexpected twists. The pages were well written and obviously reflected an understanding of the technical and some philosophical issues that will inevitably come to play in the next 20 years or so. A story like this can't describe EVERY possible outcome but the ones they've integrated here are thought provoking if nothing else. Well done and definitely worth a few bucks if reading and the subject matter are in your wheelhouse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198403607341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1500, 'last_played': 1624155074}
review:
Wonderful game. There are a few coding errors and awkward inconsistencies, but otherwise it's amazing- in fact, I cried during the final chapter of my first run (went on the empathy route but I didn't romance my companion, though I was still really attached to her and my original bot). Meaningful choices and solid writing make this a good one in my opinion. 

Tthe pop culture references could kinda be dialed down a bit though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133189277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1543183875}
review:
There's a ton of replay value, and potential for a unique experience every playthrough. It was sort of exciting not having any sort of way to undo a decision other than restarting the whole game! It made me think about my choices a little harder. 
I'm sure it can be just as fun to play while being impulsive with decisions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965435545', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1524895885}
review: I'm a sucker for the old "choose your adventure" style book I grew up with, and this game definitely falls in that category.  There's a large vareity of potential endings, so if that's your cup of tea, you enjoy playing this.  I don't know if I'd recommend purchasing it at the full $10 price tag, as this game is worth maybe 20-25hrs of distraction total if you're motivated enough to play through multiple times for the endings.  Buy it if on sale or in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971121950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1523293623}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041887851', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1522604259}
review: Choice of the Robots est l'équivalent numérique de ces "livres dont vous êtes le héros". On lit un roman et régulièrement, on nous demande de faire un choix qui impacte l'histoire, de manière très importante. Le jeu est en anglais, donc il faut avoir un certain niveau, car ce ne sont que des paragraphes de textes, il n'y a pas d'éléments visuels. Personnelement j'ai beaucoup apprecié mon premier run, créant un robot qui fut capable de concevoir a son tour son propre "fils".

author: {'steamid': '76561198298028654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1525650366}

author: {'steamid': '76561198283113949', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1521476732}
review:
号称30W的互动文本，主打人与机器的互动，中美世界大战，一顿宣传猛如虎，结果实际水平连国内网文都不如。玩到第五章，玩不下去了，我已经浪费了三十六块，不想再继续浪费更多时间了，886

故事主要内容是主角与自己做的机器人的养成，然而两者之间的互动极为贫瘠，这机器人简直比街边五十块的电子狗还蠢。个人觉得这游戏的写作者根本没有能力驾驭AI这么高的话题，就像不懂富人的diao丝在描写上层社会的生活时，写不出精英阶级的贵族感，只会像《小时代》一样不停堆砌名牌衣包。

整个世界观的设定非常奇葩，我一开始确实被“中美机器人大战”的主线剧情吸睛了，真正玩到这部分才知道有多傻吊。在战争前一年，美国U.S. Robot公司研发出了具有AI的自主机器人，但是因为价格贵而无法普及；然后中国完全copy了U.S. Robot的design [spoiler]我没有夸张，原文就是这么写的[/spoiler]，用cheap labor做出了更便宜的机器人，并反过来占据了一大块美国机器人市场。作为公司老板的朋友，主角帮助U.S. Robot打赢了官司，某龙傲天的国际组织就完全封掉了中国机器人的出口。作为报复，中国不再出口廉价的电池，使得美国各种电子设备的造价大幅度提升，人民的生活水平每况愈下。

接着本作最流弊的地方来了：中国的Prime Minister来到圣弗朗西斯科，希望通过友好交谈打破贸易僵局；然而我朝的王怎么可能空手而来呢，我们的Prime Minister居然带去了，一整只的，Parade，在人家，市中心，搞游行！！！Parade的打头阵是古代军兵，中间是现代军，压轴的是机器人大军。跑到灯塔国心脏里，阅兵游行，请问还有哪个国家做得到！！！

接着比“本作最流弊的地方”更流弊的地方来了：灯塔国的Protester勇敢地站出来螳臂当车，其中一个人忍不住开了枪，一枪就击毙了，我方的，Prime Minister！！！然后，中美大战，就这么，爆发了！！！


接着比“本作最流弊的地方更流弊的地方”还流弊的地方又™来了：天朝一上来，就bloodbath了Taiwan！！！杀掉了全部American soldier和civilian！！！！而美国，not surprisingly地非常淡定，居然完全没动出兵念头，也就是开始逮捕国内的天朝人而已 .......

读到这里，我觉得为了珍惜我仅有一次的宝贵生命，真的不能再继续下去了。



对虚拟创作太过认真就输了，但问题是除去扯到不行的主线剧情，这游戏还有任何其他的亮点吗？打不推荐都是轻的，事实上无论是十分制还是百分制，我都只能给这游戏一个零分。真的很好奇这样一个充满了对一个国家的刻板标签与偏见印象的游戏，是如何得到一大片英文好评。

author: {'steamid': '76561198434873303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1687342015}
review:
My first game I got my wife pregnant and the United States lost the war with China. I died peacefully after living many years.

Second game: my girlfriend left me after I decided to make a robot nation to stop war in Alaska, which successfully repelled the United States and China. Ultimately, every robot I made was short of being human themselves even though I made the world a better place with democracies, medical robots and a world freed from authority.

10/10 would invade Alaska again

author: {'steamid': '76561198049979496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 3255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2356, 'last_played': 1574599686}
review:
I read that title a while ago and I hesitated a long time to write a review about it because I don't really know what to say about it. Not because there's nothing to say but more because there's too much to say.

That's a really complex CYOA with bits of philosophic touch here and there and it's the biggest choose your own adventure novel I've ever had the occasion to read. Not in lenght, but in ambition and complexity. 

Everything seems well-rounded, the story, narration or the characters are never too developped nor really shallow. Everything appears refined, nothing is rushed, nothing is long : each chapter is well defined.

Finally, I would say that I felt all the objectives the author had he fullfilled them without forgetting a single detail and because he didn't want the lenght of the novel to be too large he didn't developped too much the characters or the stories either. It's a perfectly balanced title. A brilliant work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198283741869', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1519614531}

author: {'steamid': '76561198126330208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1576300803}
review:
WHY WAS THIS GAME SO FREAKING GOOD.

I'm not kidding -- this might be the best game I've ever purchased on Steam.  

It has some minor hiccups -- a few minor plot points were confusing, and I think might have been better established if I'd chosen other paths -- but I was completely hooked on this story from beginning to end.  

I plan to play it again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198364474537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1592703491}
review:
So this review has some SPOILERS, skip if you don't want em

-First playthrough made a very cute robot, who became very human like 
-Got an email for an interview. 
-Rejects the offer, then gets a bad reputation. 
-Gets a death threat, but ignores it.
-Gets kicked out off the school, has to live somewhere else. 
-Gets sent a bomb, which blows up my only place i could stay at. 
-Goes to kill Tammy, but me, tammy, and my robot all die.

Well, that was depressing because i made a really good bond with my robot. :(

-Second playthrough did almost the exact same thing, but doesn't get bad report and becomes tammy's friend 
-(still haven't forgiven her for killing me!). 
-Dates Josh, creates surgeon robots. 
-Creates a company in china, who steal my robot design which forces me to move back to the usa. 
-Starts robot war
-drives a flying car (FINALLY!) 
-halts the war between humans and robots (keeps my beautiful robot alive). 
-Many, many, many years after the rise of my bots, gives my mother a gift and gets a present for my son.
-Realises I have the same thing that ended my dad and my surgeon bots save me (thank the lord!) 
-has birthday party for my son. 
-*Cries at the end so much omgomgomg*

Seriously I hate Tammy though (she didn't like me when i decided to make my bots for the army, and decided to leave LOL!).

This game is very enjoyable, and managed to get me very emotional for the whole 5.8 hours I decided to play it. I couldn't have found a better game to waste my time with :') 
If you want a game with no sounds or pictures that will grab your feelings by the balls, then this one is certainly for you!

review:
This game is good, just not worth the $10, wait for a sale to get it around $5.

Pro:
1) Well designed story
2) Lots of choice (most of them being things that I would chose)
3) Some replayability
4)Actually made me think about the characters
5) Many different endings
6) Humanity Meter

Con:
1) High starting price
2) Low amount of $/Hr. ratio
3) Only text (no drawings or something similar)
4) Some pages are long, and are sometimes a hassle tor read

Comments:
Simmilar to other story based games such as Firewatch

author: {'steamid': '76561198076755561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1204, 'last_played': 1519314135}
review:
This is perhaps the first game that made me feel that my choices are actually impactful. And not just in the terms of a good-neutral-bad endings, but your choices echo and directly impact the story throughout the entire game. Some of them come down to flavor and personal preference, some had me mentally pacing back and forth for a while before commiting to a decision.

The story is very robust in terms of branching paths you can take - I've clocked 10 hours and have only seen about half of the events the game has to offer. I've completed multiple playthroughs and not a single one was identical. There are major events, or story nodes, so to speak, that are present in every playthrough, but your perception of them will change based on who your character is when faced with choices: the position of a wealthy entrepreneur may make you pick choices you wouldn't pick as an outstanding scientist, and a noname broke squatter may not have much to say about the same event in the first place.

While I realize many choices are linked to character stats and there ultimately is a correct way to play the game in order to achieve certain results, the sheer number of impactful chocies you make in a single playthrough does make it feel like everything is possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997450546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 16950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4424, 'last_played': 1523933508}
review: Personally, this is the most important game I've ever played up to now. What begins as a cute, fun story can quickly accelerate into an emotionally intense and genuine series of dilemmas. The writer has captured the sense that a human life has so many options, so many meaningful paths it can take. It does this while also being top-notch entertainment. It's witty, insightful, surprising, and simply fun. It's the most delightful thing I've played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018672115', 'num_games_owned': 705, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1621034812}
review:
I have only played through this game once at the time of writing this and I can tell you this game was such a fantastic experience. Very rarely does it seem that my choices in a game end up with an outcome I was genuinely hoping for. Sure some big games have had choices that give a game a good or a bad ending but the ending I got was just beautiful.

The life that I played out wasn't perfect, there were moments where I thought I really screwed up that then ended up coming around again to make for a great ending! The ending I got genuinely gave me a warm feeling in the bottom of my heart it was so good.

It really all just felt so natural. The writing was just superb.

One last thing that I did while playing was having the Bladerunner Soundtrack playing at the same time. I thought it worked out pretty well with the setting of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126740943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1515091503}
review:
I got this game since it's well liked and I think the longer C.Y.O.A. games are better. However, I did not care for this game. I have edited my original review because I thought of a better one.

You play as a tech guy working on advanced robots. You end up changing the world, although there are several paths to do so.  You get to see the effects of your decisions as robots become more intelligent and autonomus and take over many jobs while technocrats (including YOU) cash in, while normal people struggle to adapt. If this sounds cool to you, buy this game. If you find that idea creepy, pass. I found it creepy. And that does not even cover the "take over the world with your robot military" paths.  In short, if you are a tech fan or dark future fan, recommended. otherwise, NO.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354999721', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1563747297}
review: If you liked sci fi, text-based games or choose-your-own-adventure books as a kid, you'll love this gem. An incredibly-well done journey with plenty of replay value. I cried playing through my first time, I'm not gonna lie. Phenomenal game for what it is (a more user-friendly choose your own adventure novel about artificial intelligence)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043784900', 'num_games_owned': 1443, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1514747746}
review:
[b][i][Disclaimer: Copy was gifted to me by a friend, Powerglove64, several Christmases ago.][/i][/b]

There are those who simply believe science is only about man exploring the nature of the universe, yet science is also a collective legacy of these explorers’ discoveries. From the historical remembrance of the drama between Edison vs Tesla; from the familial legacy of Irène Curie who tested the structure of the atom her parents began to explore, dying from her own research; and from the names that forever shaped the world, better or worse, such as Einstein and Fritz Haber—science is a history about people, whether of minor or major feats, making choices from their newfound knowledge that may lead to their own ruin, bring them fame, or haunt them in the future to come.  This is the essence of what makes Choice of Robots an amazing piece of interactive fiction.

Choice of Robots is the type of game I always wanted to become real, a choice-based adventure around the ambitions of science. What the Civilization games recreate in terms of history as a strategy game is what CoR conveys as a choice-based interactive fiction. It may not have the same scale or freedom, but what CoR does do exceptionally well is create a piece of interactive fiction about the accumulation of your choices. There are simply too many variables, decisions, different outcomes to explore that one playthrough is not enough to experience the whole narrative. While I may be unfamiliar to other “Choice of…” titles, if you were ever curious about their merits, then Choice of Robots would be the best place to start. 

[h1]Choices We Make Are Not Always Perfect, Though They Are the Journey[/h1]

Something that was largely apparent when playing Welcome to Moreytown alongside Choice of Robots was the overall value of every decision. There is a great difference in quality offered that not only impacts the lasting consequence and ending but the overall story you build. CoR is simply a piece of fiction made greater by its interactivity to drive its narrative than something arbitrary with no impact on every decision. This is the quality of excellence that separates novels written into a game format and stories created to be their own game. 

While the narrative is largely linear with some branching paths, the meaning you create each time is due to the sum total of your decisions around the robot you create. CoR largely takes inspirations from old CRPGs by applying stats to an interactive fiction, and the story (and game) is better because of these inclusions. Flavor-text isn’t simply arbitrary side-notes or meaningless jokes as every decision is based around four major stats that affect your creation: Empathy, Autonomy, Military and Grace. Other stats influence the narrative such as the player’s own stats of Fame, Wealth and relationships with other characters that further add value to each decision. Sometimes the game will put you and your creation at odds with one another’s future goals; sometimes the story will choose different scenes or introduce fail-states to add more variety to the story. From beginning to end, no moment feels forgotten even if the plot does not draw attention to it because the mechanics already are enough of a reminder.

All these dynamic elements, thanks largely to the smart usage of stats, create tangible value to each new playthrough, and the moments that they create such as learning empathy by playing video-games or becoming autonomous from a mistake the creator made are the memories you can recall when the journey comes to its end.

[h1]It’s Not a Question of “How?” or “When?”; It’s the Readiness for the Future[/h1]

It would be an accomplishment for Choice of Robots to simply tell a narrative in a game-format that plays to its strengths to tell its own narrative for players. The genius element behind CoR is the narrative across multiple playthroughs reaffirms what the linear structure reminds you: You cannot prevent the future from arriving, but you can shape how the future will play out.

The game largely hints at this with the idea of the Singularity of robotics where the rising development of robots becoming more human presents the outcome that robots will possess greater intelligence than their creators. Whether that is the result of superpower countries waging war, economic crises due to the robotics industry, robots becoming more than simply human, and other possibilities the game presents, the outcome always results to that conclusion. Similar to Groundhog Day, it’s the inevitability of tomorrow that makes you realize it doesn’t matter who or how that day will come to pass. The truth that you learn to accept is that it would have happened to another scientist other than yourself, and it’s how you decide to handle the situation that will determine the lasting consequences on the world. Whether you wish to accept them or not, that decision to choose or to abstain are two possibilities that are always within your control. 

This attitude is what many great scientists come to accept with the pursuit of science, even when it may be a mark of shame. As Einstein wrote before his death, “I made one great mistake in my life […] when I signed the letter to President Roosevelt recommending that the atom bombs be made; but there was some justification – the danger that the Germans would make them.” Like the atomic bomb, Choice of Robots allows you to stand on that same precipice all great scientists must face when they must choose the one future out of the many possibilities they are more comfortable to accept.    

[h1]The Closest 10/10 Recommendation I Will Ever Give[/h1]

It’s honestly difficult to think of any legitimate issues with Choice of Robots unless the thought of reading makes you want to turn away—or if you don’t find any merit behind these “Choice of…” games. No aspect of the plot, decisions or aspects you must consider feel frivolous to the narrative. The writing is remarkably charismatic in quality and the ability to connect with these characters, even if they are somewhat simple archetypes. As much as I detest review scores, it would be difficult to rate this game anything short of perfection because it manages to tell a simple story in a well-executed manner beyond the expectations of what I had of these games. There may not be anything noteworthy in its narrative or revolutionary as a piece of interactive fiction, but if execution on an idea is not the most important quality than the future should be given to robotic overlords who have more humanity than us.
