author: {'steamid': '76561198070044674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1597537055}
review:
I've only done a single playthrough. This is almost like a more interesting, more realistic, robot-based version of the Sims. People seem to do these sorts of reviews on the Sims games, so here are the ridiculous, entertaining, and often truly touching events that happened in my story

-started out trying to create a robot that was aware it was a robot but was capable of emotion and companionship, in the hopes of travelling the world with it as a best friend.

-accidentally started a major, violent war between China and the United States in which one of the characters was bombed to death on an aircraft carrier.

-was arrested for treason and put in prison for about three months.

-created a male robot capable of love, denied having a relationship with it for a few months, finally gave in, and remained dating but not marrying said robot until the end of the story.

-had a robotic grandchild.

This is game absolutely incredible. It admittedly started out a bit slow, but it quickly got more interesting. The writer manages to write the game in a way that, after a while, it truly does feel like you're reading a novel. The dialogue is interesting, there are events that leave you with feelings of regret and sadness, and there are events that leave you touched and joyful. I don't do reviews often, and so I'm not quite sure what else to say. But, overall, would absolutely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126726141', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1515032284}
review: This is the first "Choose your own adventure" game/text-based-adventure I've ever played. Your choices matter, and it is genuinely emotional. I highly recommend it to any who like robots. The only "gripe" (I hesitate to call it that) I can find is that a little music would have been nice for atmosphere. I ended up listening to the Minecraft OST for it, and it helped add ambiance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007823029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1514822422}
review:
Review with some spoilers:

1) Choice matters. Every CYOA game try to claim that choice matter but in most of them, the text is nearly identical no matter what choices you pick. There are broad difference in story flow base on dialog choice and success or fail of events base on stats but that is it. CoR is different, at least for the first part up to the end of the war. I see attention to details everywhere, text and event flow subtlety different based not only on different dialog choices but also on the stats of your robot.

For example, a broad story decision of getting funded or not and by which department depend on whether you are willing to compromise on meeting the military's requirement (dialog choice) and 20 pts in a single stats (stats). It is not the result of just selecting a dialog option, but the accumulation of all the decisions you made previously. It not only make the result feel natural, but also make the choices affecting the stats feel relevant. Choice mattered indeed.

2) Subtle changes in text that show the attention in details the author put in. For example, the night after your robot is activated, if the autonomy is high, the robot will explore on its own, otherwise (if empathy is high?) it will stay and watch you sleep. There are many more examples like this and whenever I notice them, I really appreciate the effort the author put in. It is what make the robot come alive for me. I do not see the same level of details for other CYOA games and unfortunately, only the first few chapters of CoR have this level of detail.

3) Small decisions at the start have large impact much later down the road. For example using the cellphone battery will screw you up when war with China start and it is the straw on camel back that bankrupt me on my first play through. This is a really brilliant cascading mechanics that make CoR much better than other CYOA games.

4) Feedback. The one thing I hate about CYOA games is when the game present me with bland choice A, B and C. I look at them and wonder why I should choose one over another and suspect that none of the choice have any impact. One factor that make the first part of CoR so amazing is that nearly every decision I make at the first part of the game, I can see how it affect the stats of my robot. I get feedback that let me know I am indeed making a difference.

5) List possible endings/Set a goal at the start. If your game have multiple different endings, you better let me know so I have incentives to replay the game. I also need some hints on which decisions I should make differently to get those endings because I am sure as heck not going to have the time to try every permutation of dialog choice in the hope that you have hidden an ending there. A few hidden endings are fine, but don't leave me in the dark completely. The starting dream of CoR is an excellent mechanics although the singularity hint is perhaps a bit too explicit.

CoR is of course not perfect. The story start to fall flat after the war. The attention to details is gone and I hardly feel any attachment to the companion bot I built. The most memorable part is when I taught my robot about death and even that part could have been stronger if it have connection to the first lesson on death when the father dies.

Lastly I want to add a general criticism I have for CYOA games in general. Language is imprecise. It is impossible for an author to communicate his/her intention via description and dialog options to the reader perfectly. And indeed, sometimes it is better for the communication to be intentionally vague as it allow the reader space for his/her own imagination.

However, I personally hate it when dialog options are vague on its consequences or which skill check it is trying to make. I dislike having to deduce or guess the intention of the author behind each of the dialog choice to make a decision. It is inevitable that misunderstanding occurs, or that the author's interpretation of event/choice does not match with the mine and when it happens it ruins the play through. This is especially frustrating towards the end of the game because there is no save option.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272856386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1513894439}
review:
I liked the concept of the game, but after I bought it and played it for a while it just wasn't grabbing my attention anymore. I felt myself skipping over to the choices. Unfortunately I didn't even get the ending I wanted and I didn't feel like playing the game through again. 
The pages where you read the text was boring looking. It just felt like I was staring at a void. Maybe to liven the game up you could doodle something there or add like a notebook feel to it.

So to sum it up. The game is pretty boring, but might interest some people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111673498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1514806179}
review:
Okay, before I start this, I just have to get this out of the way. *Breathes in* THISISONEOFTHEBESTCHOOSEYOUROWNSTORYGAMESEVER, *breathes out*. 

Choice of Robots is beautiful in every way imaginable. I was fully immersed throughout the whole truly wonderful story this "game" provides. The characters were believable, (and i grew attached to a few of em *cough* mainly Josh). The ending that I had got made me tear up, and just whoop in victory. That Happy Birthday gets me everytime. 

I ended up building and a raising a beautiful and 'elf like' robot that I grew attached to, (who ended up with a gun for an arm, but meh, she's still so innocent and pure.) 

I would absolutely reccomend this for players looking for an immersive storytelling experience, where the choices that you make DO actually matter.. I can't wait to play this again, thankyou for the awesomeness devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059334926', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1563132302}

Teared up on the romance path with a robotic love interest, and laughed maniaclly when i took over Alaska, killed a bunch of haters, took over the world basically, and hilarious times with God robot boi i created a cult with. Amazing game, and now i have more to fantazise about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026547931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1635339573}
review: 언어의 장벽을 경험하면서도 한 가지는 말할 수 있다. 좋은 게임이다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984468715', 'num_games_owned': 2025, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1578898663}
review: Interesting and entertaining. Lightly touches on some interesting questions about AI, but disappointedly doesn't go very deep with any of them. Some paths have minor continuity problems, like Elly reveals to you some secret about her past, and then later, you she explains the secret to you again, almost word for word, and your character acts like it's the first time they hear it. There are actually several full stories in here and it'll take multiple playthroughs to experience them all. Your choices really do matter here, and you go through completely different sequences of events depending on what choices you make, unlike the typical Telltale game, for example, where no matter what choices you make, the broad strokes of the plot remain the same. Well written. I did not notice any spelling or grammar mistakes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005634435', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1704830676}
review:
Enjoyable interactive story with lots varied endings! I've played twice now and had two completely different stories; one where the robot tried taking over the world, and the other where the robot was in love with the protagonist. 


My only niggle, sometimes the continuation is a little bit off which has had me scratching my head a couple of times. In one instance  I had my character say no to marrying the robot, but then the next page mentioned our wedding photos?? Regardless, still a worthwhile buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080155274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1589452018}
review:
I'm not finished this game yet, but I feel compelled to write a review. I played the demo and immediately bought the full version to continue. I'm just wrapping up Chapter 3 at the time of writing. (Update: I have finished the game now, so continue reading for extra thoughts.)

As a security researcher with a massive passion for technology, this is so far one of the most interesting, endearing, and believable stories I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Nothing feels very forced or vague. I don't have to suspend my disbelief very much, and the more specific references to technology and security are jarringly realistic.

This is less of an "I, Robot" type of universe, and more of a heavy, introspective look into what the real world could be looking like in the not-so-distant future. The choices are very fulfilling, and none of them feel like they are designed to trick me or force me down any specific path.

(Update: This game can tell many stories in the same setting, and I was able to guide the narrative away from any tropes that I wasn't too fond of -- but I saw the options there, ready to be picked by anybody who might enjoy them.)

Edit: I just finished the whole thing in one session. The updated points above have some new thoughts from this perspective. I got a really touching ending. It's clear that my ending could have been more touching, or less touching, depending on what choices I made earlier. I also got an achivement for surviving until the end of the story. Everything in my review is still just as true as it was before, if not more true. Buy it!

I would recommend this game for anybody even remotely interested in this style of interactive fiction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091232389', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1263, 'last_played': 1513697337}

author: {'steamid': '76561198127817295', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1500174145}
review:
This game made me realise that text-base adventure can still have a chance in the market. I fell in love with this game with the idea of what could happen in the future with robots on our side, what choices would it make an effect in our life. This really makes an interesting Asimov setting almost scary close of how advance robotics are now. I read and watched how advance we are in robotics and it made me want to read more robot stories mainly written by Asimov of how a world would look like with AI robots.

 This game have many varieties of choices to make, though depends of how strict your path goes, sometimes some 
dialouge may not make 100% sense in how the characters respond, but whichever you go with, it will effect your choice. I could never forget my first playthrough and even my robot oh my god I love it from beginning to end, now I just experimenting my choices to see where I have been missing which is fun to toy around the scenarios.

 This game makes me inspire to create stories probably base on text-adventure games and the developers enourage people to do just that. It is not just a bunch of words to read and that's all, is about the journey and imagination your mind takes you of how simplistic video games can be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075902844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1439332358}
review: The first Choice of Games game I played. Though you can't really call it a game, it's more of an interactive novel. The story is incredibly compelling, and it's made better by the fact that the outcome is at least somewhat unique to you. After Robots I looked into more of Choice of Games' work. Because it comes from multiple independent authors there is no real way to tell if a game or series is going to be interesting, but so far I've only found a few that I absolutely cannot get into after at least pushing through the first chapter or two. As for Robots in particular, well, [spoiler] after building an iRobot style companion, homeschooling him to about the intelligence of an adolescent, creating a company to make a bunch of smaller, less intelligent versions of him to sell out for mining labor and such, fleeing to Canada to prevent the U.S. gov. from kidnapping an reverse engineering him, creating a more intelligent female version to be his companion, having her fall in love with me and spurn her advances, fighting for robot civil rights, then allowing him to build his own son, I spent the final moments of the book surrounded by my robotic children and closest friends. [/spoiler] Whats in the spoiler text is just the bigger plot points that I can remember off the top of my head. There are tons of details and scenes and decisions in between those bigger moments, and chances are you'll go off on a totally different path early on. I highly recommend not only playing this game but looking into all of Choice of Games' selection, especially if you're a reader.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037652441', 'num_games_owned': 910, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1513725454}
review: A great book !!! There are so many possibilities, since the first episodes, that it is impossible not to play it again to change at least the initial events for a totally different development of the story. You will love to see the same universe completely reimagined !!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037924429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2209, 'last_played': 1696163887}
review: The first game of this type I played, it's the standard by which I still judge the others. Few match the reach and diversity of this game, and even with my 37 hours played I still haven't seen everything. I've been a psychotic despot, a benevolent cult founder and a vaguely talented loser. The gameplay ends up repetitive, but it is in chasing the variation that the most fun is had. Some choices matter little, and others seem impossible, but for the most part the branches exist - talk to your robot about power and self-preservation... you can guess what happens.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992941174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1472954059}
review:
Wildy flexible and incredibly well-written and edited, this CYOA allows you to play almost whatever character archetype you prefer while still maintaining a level of challenge and awareness in player choices as you progress.  Be the war-mongering mastermind you always knew you were, or possibly the savior of Earth and harbinger of peace between Mankind and Machine.  Or, y'know, just have sex with some(/every)one(/thing.)

Absurd amounts of replayability, and some genuine emotional attachments were created.  Very fun 'interactive novel'.  Will absolutely never 100%  :T

author: {'steamid': '76561198005013964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1438979624}
review:
Played it once. Tried to make a world a better place, gained friends, lost friends, fell in love with a robot, then died a happy man (or have I?). Cried like a baby a few times during the process.

Not something I would do more consecutive playthroughs, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253747078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1511678543}
review:
Love: all the different branching stories and possibilities. 
So-so: great re-readability: you’re going to be rereading a lot of text if you want to get all the achievements this game has. The writing is good enough that it doesn’t get stale, and is pretty damn entertaining on it’s own
Dislike: No true save system, sometimes I accidentally click in something and wish I could go back to change my decision.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970328598', 'num_games_owned': 574, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1461231168}
review:
Rule Anchorage with an iron fist from your supervillain murderbot factory? 

Retire to a quiet life of painting with your lesbian fembot?

Experience many terrible days for rain?

author: {'steamid': '76561198106390046', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1468490363}
review: Like similar Choice of games, it's like an interactive novel. Make a character, make choices, have your arm blown off, make a robo-arm. The usual. There are many different endings, dependent on what you choose from a set of options. You can make a robot lover or take over the world with an army of robots. The choice is yours. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198040835910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1565861422}
review:
While it's a text-based game (hope you like a lot of reading!) the decisions you make actually make a difference.  (Looking at you, Telltale.)  For instance, you can decide a war for one side or the other, with all the consequences that implies.  Just make sure you're ready for whatever your robot decides to do; it may surprise you.

And anyway, how can you go wrong with a game that uses the phrase "engaging in electrified pickle shenanigans"?

author: {'steamid': '76561198196407422', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1511391949}
review: its pretty good

author: {'steamid': '76561198119507402', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1576951325}
review:
At first, I saw this game and was a bit repulsed by it after I started playing. However, as I continued playing, I found myself more and more interested in the story. You're presented with a series of events out of your control, and your choices determine how those events develop. Simple enough, right? But as time goes by you realize just how deep and important each of these questions asked is, and soon you begin to be really invested in the story and where it all goes. It presents you with your life, you decide where you go, how you act, and these actions are not without consequence.

All in all, it's a text based game with an emphasis on your own choices, your own beliefs, and while quite broad at first, slowly narrow down towards the end of the story to become more and more personal. The game is definitely worth the buy in my opinion, but I would say that you should play this game alone and with as few breaks as possible in order to maintain the attachment to the story and characters.

I really, really liked this game, and I think you will too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126507943', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 901, 'last_played': 1470087048}
review:
Play this game. There are no pictures, there's no gameplay but there's a story where the choices you make have a real impact. Anyone who complains that Choice of Game is not a real game should consider the fact that they have been warned: it's an interactive story, not an action game with beautiful graphics. 

This one is clearly the best of all, with probably the most endings. I don't even think I've done them all, and I don't mind even playing them again because the adventure is different.

Anyway, give it a chance, it's cheap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043415728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1499230104}
review: I found it interesting and the writing enjoyable. If you can do without the fancy graphics, I would definitely suggest checking this one out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019154898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1498429542}

This is my first game like this and what an experience. It might be just text, but it got alot of emotion to it, as well as excellent story.

Best text-based games in steam (going with reviews, including this one) !!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198104351553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1509237077}
review: This was an awsome novel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024097133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1508131345}
review:
This is a choose-your-own-adventure novel with RPG-esque stats that change based on decisions that you make about the robot(s) you create and the world that they now share with you.

I completed my first play through in just under two hours, in which time I raised a gender-neutral robot child named Curry, helped set legal precedents supporting robot autonomy, became a Canadian citizen in order to marry my gay robot best friend, and had a AI neural net implanted in my brain. 

I don’t know about you but that is literally all I’ve ever wanted to accomplish in my life so I guess I’m done now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062270246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1112, 'last_played': 1508029048}
review: Love this game. Choices actually matter. Tons of possibilities. Get it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067911350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1508062717}
review:
Неплохая история из серии книг "Choice of..."
Выборы читателя влияют на облик и возможности роботов.
Большая вариативность, но я в таких проектах все же ценю первое прохождение.

Поднимается огромное кол-во сложных вопросов, но из-за формата изложения они не приносят должного эффекта, в том числе по причине того, что в книге охвачен значительный промежуток времени, поэтому большая часть глав зачастую является перечнем альтернативно-исторических фактов. Тем, кто интересуется роботами, а так же физическими и этическими вопросами переноса сознания, стоит обратить пристальное внимание на игру SOMA.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019337124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1510802743}
review:
An engaging choose your own adventure book that tackles a lot of emerging issues in our society, many of them involving transhumanism.

Cons
- Graphics
- Some of the descriptions and segments later in the game seem rushed or inadequately covered.  

Pros
- Thoughtful
- Science Fiction
- Choices
- Consequences

(Note: Its difficult to penalize a cyoa novel for graphics, but its sold on a game platform so should be judged as such.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067579630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1509133015}
review:
SPOILER WARNING!
YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!!

You can make a robot with a arm cannon like Megaman! :D

Where was I? Oh, the review.

It's a great game, and if you enter your actual name as the protagonist's, it feels more real. There are funny moments ("Why am I dreaming in political cartoons?") and serious ones (Such as choosing whether or not to get surgery to remove a genetic desease, at the cost of the Charcter's emotions) but it all flows together very well. There's a stats screen as well, and some stats influence later decisions. There's the fame stat (which is how well known you are), Wealth (which influences several decisions) and a way to see who your character is married to (or seeing) with the Romance stat. The robot you build has stats too, such as Autonomy (how well it can move), Military (how weaponized it is), Empathy (emotions) and Grace. There's achivements as well, but you can't get them all in one playthough, which is fitting; a person can't do everything in their lifetime. It also has a few moments that makes you ask yourself questions, but I'll let you figure those out.

Overall, it's an amazing game. If nothing else, use your actual name as the protagonist's and give it a blind run. You'll be pleasantly surprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042136412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1585078083}

author: {'steamid': '76561198076634385', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 767, 'last_played': 1588844936}
review:
Going into this game I had no idea what this was really. Upon starting, it seemed to be just a big wall of uniteresting text. However, once I went beyond it, I realized I had discovered a gem of a game. In my first game I created a robot similar to that of a synth, started an international corporation, sold robots to the American military to fight in a war, became a war hero, then started a rebellion in Alaska, only to die fighting rather than fleeing. The next game I created a robot nearly identical to that of a child, worked with my friend in a robot toy business, converted my child robots into military robots, developed extremely realistic human looking soldiers, and made companion bots that were nearly indistinguishable from humans, marrying one in the process and starting a family with her raising a human child and my original robot child. The game is written like a sort of fanfiction which really isn't a problem in my opinion. 

It tells like a story and I love it. I have played through this game about 4-5 times trying to min-max my decisions to achieve the most success and get different endings. After staying up an extra several hours to play this rather than sleep I stayed up longer just to plan out how I can get new endings and better scenarios. I highly recommend this game and I hope that the other games like this are just as good, but I doubt they are as quality as this lovely game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060483913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1506110959}
review:
Fantastic game. An emotional rollercoaster of moving moral choices. And with plenty of replay value... after getting over the initial shock of what you've done to the world, next time make it better... or worse!
Self-referencing, witty, at times sarcastic, and some great science, video game and literature references thrown in there too. Give yourself a couple of hours to really get stuck in, let it wash over you and enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198421322490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1505431742}
review:
花了三个小时完美通关。自己开了个公司赚钱就没亏过，一开始养的机器人很爱我但还是当孩子养了，不知道可不可以发展感情线啊。总之一直是以一个好人角度在玩这个游戏，反对战争。打起来以后我就哪国也没帮，其他的人我也都没救。和后来造的机器人去加拿大结婚了，最后的手术也没有问题，还收养了人类小孩。总之最后有钱有家庭有事业的哈哈哈
但是我还是想吐槽和中国打起来这件事，什么时候中国开始在各个外国游戏里担任假想敌角色了？？？这个游戏的政治因素体现出的作者背后观点真的好像我的国际关系以及经济发展的教授们，每节课不提中国十次就上不了课哈哈哈哈哈
总之游戏本身还挺好玩的，有时间会再接着玩

author: {'steamid': '76561197978660606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1503385538}
review: I have played through this game many times. It is fun and entertaining in each time I played through. This is a choose your own adventure novel that truly explores the human spirit. If you are an avid reader like me, playing again and again to see the new paths, the new success or failures, then you will love this game. I bought this because I have always been a huge Issac Asimov fan and was hoping for something along the lines of Robot Dreams. While this is not quite like that, it is still very fun to read and see where your choices take you for better or worse. I would suggest this to anyone that loves to read as much as I do. If you are not into reading, then play something else, this game is not for you. I would recommend this game to anyone who truly seeks an adventure that spans a lifetime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036168769', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1564548600}
review:
This isn't the sort of game I'm used to playing, but I think it really won me over to interactive fiction! The science fiction is very tame and believable, and it focuses much more on the human and emotional element than any philosophy problem we're tired of hearing by now. And even beyond the premise, there's something really fascinating and beautiful about simulating a person's entire life from young adulthood to old age (at least if you survive to the end). This element works really well because the author seems to be very knowledgeable about not only the technological and political processes he describes, but also how human beings tend to act. I was most immersed in the game when I felt helpless, when the game's sense of society and personality sort of crescendoed into waves of forces outside my control. 

It's great stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059566191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1500160281}
review:
So, you're here after reading description, interested in creating AI?
Do you really think you can handle all the responsibility it brings?
Do you really think mankind is ready to neighbor yet another, equally (or more) intelligent species on this planet?
Perhaps you think you've got what it takes to teach AI the value of emotions and human life?
Or perhaps you think such self-aware creations can be shackled to be a mindless tools of someone's war?
Do you really think self-conscious being will mindlessly serve you as a slave?
Or maybe, just like me, you think you've got what it takes to pull it all off, eh?

Well, strap yourself in, sunshine, cause you ain't seen sh**, princess.

10/10 - fantastic, interactive novel with plot twists that kept me on my toes more than some of recent FPS games or TV shows. If there's one thing better than a good book, it's a good, interactive book. WELCOME TO THE FUTURE (wink wink)

author: {'steamid': '76561198280385023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1504750393}
review:
*Finishes first playthrough*

Holy

Shit


I started out the game attempting to create a hyper intelligent robot that could lead humanity to greatness. I ended up creating a robot that started an AI revolution that stopped a massive war, fucked over our corrupt government, and worked with me to make a world were man and machine live together in a libertarian North America. My brainchild went through multiple stages during my time with her. She went from niave, to rebellious, to suicidally depressed, and finally building a child. To say that this game is an emotional rollercoaster is an understatement. You will go through multiple stages of your character's life, balancing relationships and teaching your robot your values. My character led a lonely life, having only a few friends and family to accompany him on his journey. He gave up on romance early on to focus on his creation and career. He sacrificed his chance at a normal life to make the world better, will you do the same? Or will you focus on another aspect of life? What will your creation look and act like? The only answer is to try the game. My experience will stick with me for years to come. My only major criticism is that I couldn't spent more time with my little Materia.

*proceeds to have an existential crisis*



Glass of Water master race



Seriously though, buy this game if you even remotely like CYOA stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992966935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1545808844}
review:
Choice of Robots is the game I always wanted. It's deep, punishing, joyous, and so very genuine. I love that this story is as much about who you are, and who you become, as it is about the world you inevitably change in very real ways. 

We sit back and judge triple A games on it's 3 endings with different colored cutscenes; but CoR is so much deeper and enjoyable for it's design. I'm torn between describing it as a game, as much as it is a novel that unfolds to your hopes and inclinations. Every decision made creates a very real impact in your story, and I respect the design choice not to allow for backtracking; as now everything you do has weight. 

If I might make a recommendation beyond 'buy this game now!'; it's that you don't try to min-max things. I'll confess I'm guilty of always trying to get 'the best' outcome in most games I play; but Choice of Robots drew me away from that direction. It rewards your mistakes as often as it punishes or ignores your wisdom, and like life; makes you wonder if you made the right choice at every turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105087848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1501259609}
review:
No es un juego como tal. Es un libro interactivo en el cuál puedes decidir tu propio destino y el de tu robot. 
Al principio es algo lento, pero una vez que enfrentas las consecuencias de todas tus decisiones simplemente no puedes parar hasta llegar al final.
Lo único que me hubiera gustado que se cambiara sería que, dependiendo de qué amigo eligieras cuando decides quién te marca por teléfono, la conversación cambiara. Por lo menos con los dos que he elegido, Eiji y Elly, la conversación ha sido exactamente la misma.

Por lo demás, este "juego" es excelente y realmente te hace sentir el peso de tus decisiones. Muy recomendado incluso para aquellos que no sepan mucho inglés, pues el lenguaje es muy sencillo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116930297', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1511889785}
review:
An unusual game to say the least. I remember when i was a kid, i used to read tons of "you're the hero" kind of books and this game's pretty much the same. You decide the way the story goes. And it feels great. Who needs top end graphics when you can simply enjoy reading a good ol' book.

As for the game, well it's very well-written, there are dozens of endings/choices and it might also give yourself a little insight of the human beeing you are, as you're completly free of doing w/e you want with the robot you've created.

I strongly recommend it, however you'll have to either be british/american (or english's your mother tongue) or have above average english skills, since there are quite a lot of bizarre/old fashioned words used, as well as famous quotes from famous english writing authors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988566726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1496896145}
review:
I paid $7 for Choice of Robots, and it lasted for around 2 hours. I was entertained, and don't regret the decision.

I've played interactive fiction before, and both seasons of The Walking Dead. Although I enjoyed them, and The Walking Dead was super polished, they did not provide the same experience as Choice of Robots.

You see, in the other games, I felt like there was only so much freedom allowed, and that certain outcomes were absolute. Of course I know that there aren't limitless choices in any game of this kind. Still, I felt like each of the decisions made in Choice of Robots contributed to an end that I influenced.

This could mean that there is a lot of plot branching in Choice of Robots, or it could simply be that the game doesn't allow multiple saves, so you don't get to easily see the illusion. It's essentially a rogue-like. You can start over, but other than that, your decisions stand.

I'm torn about whether or not I should play this again. Another play through is just me trying to get a glimpse into the game's inner workings. That could ruin the experience for me. If I do play it again, I will update this review.

The author was smart to provide a demo. It was enough to draw me in for the sale. It's a fast download, and worth a try.

review: Truly a stunning game, where the limitations of being purely textual became it's strength. If you don't have a very active imagination this game isn't for you, but I loved it, played through a whole bunch of times to see some of the options. Great writing all around. I'd say it makes me nostolgic for text based adventure games if I was old enough for that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000799744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1493602646}
review:
Choice of Robots.. Where to begin.

There are so many routes and options that you can choose in this story (with major plot points unraveling and rejoining in a different manner) that I played this through about 4 times so far. With that said, I NEVER replay games or reread stories, but this here, i did 4 times, simply because it feels like a different story each and every time. 

I highly recommend this to anybody who enjoys fiddling with the idea of a future that heavily involves AI and robotics and the repercussions of the events that lead to this future. Not to mention the suprisingly emotional connection you have with what is in essence your own imagination. It is stunning. Even the killer you may imagine up will draw you into a connection with it, again, amazing.

I played this without a soundtrack, but it would be very much welcomed to play one while enjoying the story. I found I did not require a soundtrack simply because my mind was able to create all of the setting and what it would sound like through what was written for my first read through I now figure that an outside disturbance(?) may have ultimately taken away from my experience. I may have even been able to smell some described smells at the time.

Needless to say, I will be checking out more of these from this particular author(?)/developer and I highily recommend this title in specific. The price also makes this a no-brainer! It is much more dynamic than a classic sci-fi book with more re-play(read?)ability as well. Very much worth the $5, knowing the contents at this point, I would gladly have paid double.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007757363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1551838490}

review:
Whatever version of Chrome Embedded Framework they're using is out of date, I just sat there at an empty white screen literally for hours.

I assume it works on older versions of Windows, but on my vanilla Windows 10 Pro, it did not. Even so, I was able to re-host the files and still play the game (merely opening the index.html fle isn't enough, it actually has to be hosted on a real web server in some way). 

Would be nice to have some theming options, but it seems the CYOA portions do work as intended (mostly).

author: {'steamid': '76561198078640856', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1568155355}
review:
I don't think I've ever gotten so attached to a character in a game so quickly before. I feel like I just lived an entire life. This game does such a good job in having your choices matter far down the line.

Also, enter into this with the ability to accept failure, pick yourself up, and keep moving forward. Even if something looks like it'll be the end, don't quit. I'm so glad there's not a "back" button; you live with the consequences of your actions.

Excellent experience to curl up and play on a rainy day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191087073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1492531965}
review: เป็นเกมที่สนุก แม้จะไม่มีกราฟิกอะไรเลย เหมาะสำหรับคนชอบอ่านนิยายและเล่นเกมที่เลือกแต่งเรื่องของตัวเองได้

author: {'steamid': '76561198124158395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1542110030}
review:
I enjoyed my first playthrough, but it soon started to get boring on my second playthrough. I figured out all endings, but all are plain and quite predictable. And it is really weird how that all those people just falls in love with the protagonist because the protagonist thinks that someone might be a good person to date with. The story needs more interactions between characters.

I have played [i]Planetarian[/i] and [i]Lucy[/i]. They cost a little bit more but are more immersive. Maybe I am just a shallow reader who find less enjoyment reading pure text, but anyway I do not see how this story is as great as many of those overwhelmingly positive reviews say. 

Actually I will give 6/10 for this game. I still recommend the game. I just complain about it because I cannot see any of this novel's problems addressed in other comments, and I had too high expectation of this game because of these overwhelmingly positive comments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006875525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1491682965}
review: This is an absoltutely riveting, emotional, and deep masterpiece that everyone must play. It brought me to anger, shock, tears, and the whole gamut of human emotions and interactions. This is a masterpiece. A must play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970784893', 'num_games_owned': 1007, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1492942192}
review:
Choice of Robots is an interactive Science Fiction novel by Gold who have a PhD in Computer Science, but is interested in Political Science and ethics too.  The novel examines the role robots will have in our near future as a civilization, namely from 2019 and 30ish years ahead. Through the player character who is an American Computer Science graduate in the story where we get to pick his different life choices. For example is it morally right to lend our talent to the military if the wish to support us financially? Etc. Etc. 

Verisimilitude is deftly accomplished by focusing on certain aspects that lends itself well towards being, primarily, a reflective medium about an important challenge humanity have to face in the near future.

I've played through one path of the game so far, it took around 2.5 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043982773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1480461610}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198130586607', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1659577810}
review: this is one of the best games i've bought in my life. It is real touching and well written, totally would recommend buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042089710', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 975, 'last_played': 1615165875}
review: A great game that is long enough to draw you in, but also short enough that you can just start over if you mess up fatally by doing something stupid. Coming from me, a paranoid failure-averse gamer, this means a lot. It satisfied both my desire to read new stories and my drive to perfect and master things; you can play it a couple of times for the emotion the story evokes, and then have some fun dominating the narrative with your spoilers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965341488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1461759662}
review: Very interesting story with many choices. The downside is there's no "backtrack" option (kind of standard in most of the genre these days), so seeing how a specific other choice plays out (or just if something didn't mean what you thought it meant), the only way to see it another way is to do another playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007308819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2736, 'last_played': 1525842878}
review:
Without doubt this is the best game from the Choice of Games stable. I highly recommend this to anyone who does not yet own this. If you don’t have this yet – buy it now!

The plot covers a huge amount of ground and has a vast array of different plot paths, all impacted by your decisions and which will bring you back again and again to make different choices. I have played a huge number of run throughs and have 2 achievements left to get, but I still find there are scenarios which I have never seen before. The key reason for this is every choice you make has a major impact on where the story goes, and with a word count of 300,000 the detail included in the story is phenomenal with a huge number of different plot branches you can travel down. 

But the greatest part of this game is the subject matter which is incredibly thought provoking, mapping out a world we are not too far away from seeing which is at times funny, sad and terrifying. It takes you to the logical conclusion of your choices and keeps you involved in the plot in a way that a great book or film manages to do which keeps you coming back to try and get that perfect ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196081281', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1490877396}

author: {'steamid': '76561198171750818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1460251892}
review:
Choice of Robots is a delightful choose-your-own-adventure story about what's really important: humanity, autonomy, empathy, rotoscopic eyes. 

During my first game, my robot murdered me! (Rude.) My next robot, Pickle, was more child than conqueror. In my third playthrough, my robots saved medicine and started running the world.

I know there are more stories in this game than I ever found, but I loved every path I took.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103175092', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1579480787}
review: Great, just great. So many good things. There were even parts that made me think about what path the human race is going down. Just god damn  great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152718326', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1564776978}
review: Very fun game. I played it on my own, then I played it with my friend (with me reading it and them picking the choices). I found it especially fun to play with a friend and see what type of choices they made and how their game differed from mine. It's a good game for people who don't play video games often, as it's a very straight-forward text-based choose your own adventure. I enjoyed the adventure that played out and I wouldn't mind playing it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029830780', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1489871085}
review:
Wow.

Ich möchte nicht spoilern, deshalb fasse ich mich kurz.
Wenn ihr gerne SiFi/Cyberpunk im Stile Asimovs oder auch Blade Runner habt mit viel Herz und liebe zum Detail, dann holt euch bitte dieses Textadventure. Fantasie und gute Englischkenntnisse müsst ihr aber selber mitbringen.

Das Spiel ist wie ein guter SiFi-Roman, nur dass ihr selber entscheiden könnt was auf der nächsten Seite steht.
Fesselnd bis zum Schluss, und immer wenn man denkt das Ende erreicht zu haben, nimmt die Geschichte eine neue Wendung.

Für Wertschätzer guter SiFi Literatur gebe ich hier eine absolute Kaufempfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024890639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1488172107}
review: The Choice of Games franchise nails the Choose Your Own Adventure format, and this is one of the strongest entries in their catalogue. I would recommend it to existing fans of Choice of Games, or newcomers who enjoy interactive fiction. The beauty about Choice of Robots is that it explores deep themes like war, the ethics of wealth and relationships, both romantic or platonic; but it explores these themes in a fun way. It caters for everyone, from those who hold the simple ambition of raising a merciless army of robots to conquer the world, all the way to those who have the natural urge of inseminating a fembot. For those interested, I have a video discussing the Choice of Games franchise - https://youtu.be/22wAYzW_CdM

author: {'steamid': '76561198257075711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1489606135}
review: This may be one of the best games I have played in a long time. Definitely worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075114315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1324, 'last_played': 1630368823}
review:
Listen.
I've probably done 15 to 20 playthroughs of this game, and I know I still haven't seen all the possible endings. This game will tug at your heartstrings, will make you laugh, will make you care more than you think possible about the future of your tiny robot child, and more. I've had friends fall in love with fictional robots with me over this game when they only saw screenshots of my playthrough. I've colonized Alaska, helped create a robot government, got married to the robot of my dreams, built a financial empire, helped America win a war and started a cult.
Please buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014389407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1488680013}
review:
*Starts game*
Alright I'll take it seriously but it's just a game.

*About a minute in*
Wow, this is crazy. Guess I'll just go with making decisions I would make in real life.

*Hours in*
Wow, I'm a fucked up person. I care about these people, my friends and family, but like in real life, I just keep fucking them over without intentionally wanting to do so but I do anyway because of my principles.

*Hits the end*
Go fuck yourself Caliban

*Caliban, a venetian masked wearing robot with beautiful golden wings and body made of advanced alloys, beats the shit out of me in my shitty apartment.*
Still go fuckyourself.

*Dies a lonely death*

......*Plays again*

11/10 from me

author: {'steamid': '76561198128270816', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1499304484}
review:
Amazing CYOA type game! These types of games normally don't keep me interested for long but I was fully invested in my story and plan to play again for a different outcome. 

You WILL cry and you WILL be shocked at some of the things that happen.

You will also feel bad for not treating your robots as well as you could have.

My second robot just up and ran away from me while we were walking in the park. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198098456380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1429, 'last_played': 1555861863}
review: This is a really nice CYOA novel. There was obviously a lot of thought put into this, and there are so many different outcomes and experiences that you can discover. It's very easy to get wrapped up in the story and lose track of time. Each decision you make impacts your story, and you'll have to keep track of your stats, those of your robot, and your relationships with others. Even if you choose the same basic path, there can be endless little differences along the way, giving this a ton of replay value for such a great price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025000201', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1488389882}
review:
Actually amazing.  I build a child, botch an interview, and get my house bombed by some crazy lady.  Then I go on to produce not!millitary robots, the USA loses to China by miles, I hijack a flying car, and then get shot in the head and die.

Time to try again.  I could tell my choices had long-term consequences, so I'm gonna be more focused this time.

Also, the game autosaves and keeps a summary, making it easy to pick up and (slightly easier to) put down.

A simple but effective game at a great price.  Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055559493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1603772627}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035624342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1574520302}
review:
It was getting late when I first booted this game up.  About 11pm I said I'd just open it to see how it played then go to bed.  
Next thing I knew it was 5am the next morning and I was finishing off my third playthrough.

The story has real scope and your choices really do change the world in dramatically different ways.  It's very satisfying playing through with different characters (there are three very different main endings with a large number of details that change based on your choices).

This game is very well written and exectuted.  The world and characters are believable, and the humour adds a lightness that balances some of the heavier moments.  

I haven't played many Interactive fictions (though I highly reccommend Steve Jackson's Sorcery), but this was a great experience, and one I'm sure I'll return to soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212371348', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1278, 'last_played': 1529487317}
review:
[h1]在游戏的画面音乐达到极致的今天，我玩到了一个令人感动的作品[/h1]

怎么说呢，通关了以后我的心情很复杂

一方面我推荐代入感很强的人慎重游玩，因为玩完了以后很难再忘掉里面的情节（至少对我来说），很难摆脱它的影响。
一方面它真的很不错。它真正的体现了互动艺术的魅力。

如果这只是一本书，只能说它的质量中上，情节较俗套，设定上也没什么很出彩的地方。
然而它是一个游戏（互动小说），
不管这些事情多么俗套好像从各处重复了千万遍，
你的决定带来的影响真正发生的是在你的身上。真正影响了故事线（或者说是在你脑中想象出来的人生），加入进来的体验总是比作为局外人印象深刻。
所以这是我非常纠结的地方，对代入感强的人就像是苦乐交织。

个人认为对于这种只有文字纯靠想象的游戏，比剧情炫酷场面火爆的游戏代入感更强，你在想象中根据文字构建出的世界，都是你可以理解接受的东西，这是真正的幻想乌托邦。当然对于想象力不是那么丰富的同学，这种文字avg在情感上的表达就弱了许多。

[strike]个人闲扯不喜勿喷（爱心）[/strike]

[spoiler]个人建议，保留足够高的humanity，第七章会非常感人。[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198123230886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1491100654}

author: {'steamid': '76561198144706785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1400, 'last_played': 1598574829}
review: story is deep and fullfilling. It actually makes me feel as if im in the story and my decisions really matter. truly the best game ive played in a while. even if you can't consider it a 'game'

author: {'steamid': '76561198028646074', 'num_games_owned': 855, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 838, 'last_played': 1487331317}
review:
My wife shot me when I tried to invite her to join my robot rebellion in Alaska. 17/10 Would do again.

Now in all seriousness, this game is amazing. It's not your typical kind of game, but boy do I not regret getting this. Regardless of how you and your robot end up, it's a story of ethics, morals, philosophy, and more importantly, it's a story of what our future may be.

Do you want to make robots for war? For love? For peace? Or robots that transcend humanity to rule over us?
It's your Choice of Robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060553163', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1218, 'last_played': 1486019295}

review: I *love* this. And I'm not just tossing around the word "love" to get out of explanation, I genuinely love this. 12/10. Realistically worth x3 more, but unrealistically my fascination with the story wants to say x10 or something like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056171822', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1514471157}
review:
I just picked this game up and finished my first playthrough in a couple of hours. The story contained is one of countless possibilities. In such a short time, I worried about Sapling, I fretted over whether to make him more likeable or help him to protect himself. I felt excited at how a tiny option I made earlier in the game could help me out of a snare later on. I laughed at the quirky dialogue, questioned rather philosophical conundrums in the game, and cried like an actress at the ending Ireceived. If you love an outstanding story full of twists and turns, loveable characters and limitless possibility, do yourself a favour and purchase this game.

I cannot rate this story highly enough. I'm gonna go play it again now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136647917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1511645698}
review: bem loco

author: {'steamid': '76561197993177549', 'num_games_owned': 1190, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1506924477}
review:
While the writing style is unlikely to win a Pulitzer, this is a very enjoyable CYOA-style novel. With over a quarter million words, you'll certainly spend lots of time exploring the different endings. Not only do you work with robots, but you must track your own humanity, the relationships you have with several other characters, and your robot's stats. Let the AI become highly autonomous but lack empathy, and you'll witness a rise of the machines to exterminate humanity. But make it graceful and empathetic without a shred of military skill, and it'll get butchered in combat. 

Don't let the 300,000 word statistic frighten you into thinking this is TL;DR: The PC Game. You won't actually read that in a single play through. Rather, your choices lead to different plot branches, sometimes wildly different from each other, and each branch will expand the total word count.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993926319', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1486530458}
review:
I don't think you understand how invested you will be in these characters.
I chose the path where I tried pulling a "Chappie" and released a robot child unto the world. My goal was to try and establish rights for sentient robots.

I loved, by the way, that this was even a possible path in the game. The vast majority of philosophical explorations into AI seem to always be like "LOL TURMINAYTUR AIN'T DIS SO SCARYYYY?? LOL FEAR TECHNOLOGY".

But, (and I won't give spoilers) I chose a very...science fiction ending. Aaaaand loyal to the story, this game was like "congrats, you've reached the end!" and I swear I almost threw something. If you put yourself in a situation where you wouldn't know the outcome, the storyteller doesn't suddenly become omniscient and tell you the result. You're limited to what your character could realistically discover.

So now I'm actually emotionally recovering from a major Schroedinger's decision that hangs my character investment in the balance.

Also: I don't think you realize how hard it is to keep robot slavery and a terminator military from becomming a thing. Like, I passionately fought against those, and it is REALLY HARD. Humans are so damn power-hungry!!!

This was an AMAZING experience, though. There are points that seem like the decision, from your standpoint, is obvious, but everyone eventually will get a decision that makes their heart drop with that "oh shit" moment. I was very happy to see the extremely wide variety of story paths available here. The author did his homework.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116304941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1309, 'last_played': 1598681954}

author: {'steamid': '76561198070799869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1419, 'last_played': 1526042599}
review:
You need to get this game right now if you enjoy reading.  I'm a very big Metal Gear Solid fan, right?  In my first playthrough, I developed a military robot named Sahelanthropus, and lead a rebellion, started in Alaska (Shadow Moses Island is in the Alaskan Archapelago) but my rebellion failed.  I successfully lived the rest of my life with Sahelanthropus, my rebellion having failed and withstanding a life threatening surgery.

I'm starting a new adventure immediately.  As long as you enjoy reading, you NEED this game.  It's a choose your own adventure book, but the adventures are really different.  Your choices ACTUALLY MATTER!!!!  EVERY LITTLE OPTION GOES DOWN A DIFFERENT PATH!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198312088041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1495060384}
review: Première chose à savoir tout est en anglais même avec un niveau plutot moyen l'histoire est toute a fait conpréhensible, pas de son ni d'image mais l'imagination fait très bien son travail, en ce qui concerne les choix c'est le jour et la nuit on peut vraiment crée son chemin sans que cela sois la même histoire, pour 5euros c'est du tout bon n'hésiter pas foncer ! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054129024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1486148787}
review: Choice of Robots is shockingly detailed. In the past, I've been frustrated with CYOA games, because the options didn't seem to have logical consequences or there wasn't enough variety of choices to include all types of players. CoR blows that problem out of the water. Highly recommended to everyone who loves a good read (and robots)!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000066565', 'num_games_owned': 1413, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1545074555}
review:
공상과학 소설을 써내려가는 소설가의 옆에서 이야기를 같이 써내려가면 이런 경험을 할 수 있을까? 
인간성이란 무엇인지 다시 생각해보게 해주었다. 
수 많은 줄기의 실타래 속에서 하나의 끝을 보았지만 아직 많은 길이 남아있기에 다시 플레이하고 싶은 게임이다. 
다만 지금의 여운이 사라지지 않게 다시 플레이하는 것은 조금 더 미래의 나에게 양보할 생각이다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034313699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1485042556}
review:
Admittedly, after the first hour or two I couldn't help but start min-maxing to try for every variation of the story, even if I wasn't fully reading it at that point. While generally well written, the author's futurist visions can begin to seem a little trite at times.

SPOILERS BELOW


Strangely enough, the most human-like robots spawned from my military focused play through. I don't know how many permutations of each type of ending there are, but the only robot that tried to make a child was my gun-toting, world-dominating spider bot. Maybe I the other's were lacking autonomy...

Biggest dissapointment? No signularity. Singularity is explained fairly well in the first few pages - when robots reach human intelligence, nothing will stop them from going beyond it. If humans can design something that can surpass them, then so can robots. But my robots never designed anything that did that. There was no explosion of artificial intelligence. They were able to lead the world in some cases, but nothing changed. The dreams were just dreams. I don't know if I was doing it wrong, but at this point I sort of doubt the game allows for true singularity to happen in one lifetime, as it theoretically could. As much as I was afraid of robots designing machines that would preserve humanity as digital constructs, I couldn't get it to happen no matter how hard I tried.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044675496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2927, 'last_played': 1465233119}
review:
If someone had told me that I'd spend literally 2 days of my human lifespan on a game that featured nothing but text and the promise of robots...I'd probably bellieve them because I'm kind of weird. Even so, there is not a single regret I feel for doing so. Choice of Robots is probably one of the best text-based games out there, bar none. Compelling characters, humerous, intellegent writing, references there's almost nothing it doesn't handle with a disarming level of grace.

With an engaging story that stretches across a staggering volume of possibilities, never once did I feel like I was being railroaded into something I didn't want. Every success and failure I could sit there, nod and think that I had a hand in nearly every step on the path that led me there. 

One of my favorite features of the game was, and don't act too surprised by this, was the robot itself. There's a strong feeling of controlling through proxy, like watching a child grow you have to simply influence it and teach it and hope, in the end, that your guidance will help it reach the peak of its existance. 

It's difficult to describe a game that's so varied, so all I can say is to buy it and experience an entire lifetime in an afternoon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972370507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1484598604}
review:
Choice of Robots strikes a good balance between allowing you choices that feel important and dishing out surprises. The writing style conveys all it needs to without stepping on your imagination. I ended up actually caring about the various creations, characters and decisions I encountered whilst playing/reading. 
This adventure is priced right and worth a few hours of your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022989401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1484484565}
review:
Als SiFi Fan habe ich mich sehr auf die Story gefreut. Nach dem ersten durchspielen war ich dann doch sehr entäuscht. Die Auswahlmöglichkeiten und Folgen sind doch überschaubar und laufen meist auf das selbe Ergebnis heraus. Das Handeln einiger Figuren ist ziemlich unnachvollziehbar. 

Um nicht vorschnell zu Urteilen habe ich das Spiel ein zweites Mal mit anderen Antworten durchgespielt. Im Grunde läuft es darauf hinaus mit den Antworten "+" und "-" auf die Eigenschaften Wealth, Grace, Military, Empathy zu bekommen. Am Ende bietet die Anzahl der Punkte unterschiedliche Antwortmöglichkeiten.

Die Story konnte mich weder Emotional noch inhaltlich überzeugen. Sie bietet in meinen Augen keine neuen interessanten Ansätze zum Thema AI und Robotik.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041731734', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1567726054}
review:
I always play these games initially as how I feel I would genuinely respond going through it if I was truly there. Not purposefully being an ass or purposefully being a saint or anything in-between. My first play through I somehow [spoiler] ended up leading a robotic rebellion and then being captured by the United States while only less than a year previous, helped them win a war against China. Before finally being saved from a genetic disease from medical robots I invested in 15 years before. [/spoiler]

I am now about to go through my second play through just because I am excited to see what this game must offer. Truly an experience that makes you think and is enjoyable in all aspects. This game does what TellTale games TRIES to do, and achieves it 100% better with only words on a screen and no other visuals. Being honest, at no point did I ever feel like I needed the visuals either. This game, and game company, is truly doing something right.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198063560294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1499723503}
review: Choice of robots is a text-only game. You're basically reading a book in which you are the main character and control his/her actions and decisions. The story itself is about the creation of artificial intelligence and the effect this has on the world and has many different endings depending on the choices you make. On forehand I wasn't sure if I should pick this up but I'm glad I did. It's a very good story and a nice experience overall. I you like reading you should definitely try this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998629152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1483567432}
review:
Gonna keep this short:

First 'Choice of' game I've played and they've set a good first impression!

Story is entertaining, quite a few narrative pathways, although some are very difficult to access. After 8 hours I have approximately half the achievements. First playthrough took maybe 2 hours, as I got to the very end without dieing. Subsequent playthroughs are much quicker as I can skip reading a lot of the text.

Needs more proofreading, noticed several inconsistencies whilst playing, like events being referred to that didn't happen in the playthrough I was in.

Very enjoyable though (not as emotional for me as others claim, but each to their own)

author: {'steamid': '76561198085130060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1510465807}

author: {'steamid': '76561198202796145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1555920112}
review:
10/10 would have threesome then break my companion bot's heart again.

And then my second playthrough, since I am a fan of Danganropa, I created Kiibo the Ultimate Robot. I tried to get the Grace Route, while also making the choices based on the decisions my discord buddies (And sometimes myself) made. The result is Kiibo becoming a big rancor robot, and screwing over my previous romance with Eiji the manga artist so that my character can become a lesbian robophile to the new female robot I created called Aigis (P3 anyone?) We moved to Canada to get married, and Kiibo became our child. And proceeded to make a robot version of myself to do stuff for me, while I hang out with my robot family. 

Cute/10

review: This game/book is wonderful, fascinating, and downright beautiful at times. The first time you read it all the way to the end will probably be the most impactful, but it has a lot of replayability. I was instantly drawn into the story and found myself just as entertained as if I were playing a game rather than reading. You'll be thinking about the ending way after it's over.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025109486', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1485199442}
review:
Choice of robots n'est pas un jeu video.
C'est un livre interactif, avec des choix moraux, des stats, et des achievements.

Et c'est genial. La liberté dans les choix est bien plus grande que dans n'importequel jeu video, et l'hsitoire avance vraiment selon ce que le joueur choisit. Cette liberté vous permet de vous identifier au protagoniste sans soucis; Vous etes le protagoniste. Il fait les choix que vous faites, et se comporte comme vous le feriez et cela rend l'histoire d'autant plus prenante et emouvante.

Le theme de l'intelligence artificielle est vraiment bien traitée, et l'arbode sous de nombreux point de vue : Militaire, Sentimental, legal etc.

Bref, j'ai passé un tres bon moment, et j'ai hate de le recommencer !

Si vous n'avez pas peur de lire de l'anglais, foncez !
