author: {'steamid': '76561198248664730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1612576327}
review: I really enjoyed this game and was very invested in the fate of my robots

author: {'steamid': '76561198114186550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1553472603}
review: I highly recomend this game to players looking for a game where choice matter and you have to balance social relationships, personal ambition, and expectations of the other characters and world. I've played through it 5 times and I've gotten completely different story lines each time. One of the best things about this game is that the choices don't always turn out quite how you're expecting, and I know that might sound like a bad thing, but I think it makes it more real. The intentions I set out with, and the choices I make to try and accieve what I set out to do don't always lead to the results I had anticipated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015652634', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1513746069}
review: This is honestly one of the best value games I've ever purchased in terms of $$$ paid for time spent playing. It is seriously the gift that never stops giving. By the way did you know it was written by a guy with a PhD? Because it was. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135261807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1541843338}
review: Great writing overall, sometimes a bit cheesy and writer could have done a little research on how machines actually operate but still worth a read for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027803139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1540152917}
review:
I came home from work back then, a thankless job under a crooked boss, with long hours and bad pay. I was frustrated and annoyed. I played Choice of Robots, it took me maybe an hour or so to go through the story. After doing so, my cares had been lifted and I was happy.

It was a memorable experience. The end story felt like it had generated itself directly from my mind. It was cathartic.

Then I talked to friends, and they had their own, deeply different experiences.

I am no longer able to take any Choose Your Own Adventure game seriously after the depth of experience I obtained from this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026422178', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1528037787}
review:
I picked this game up for $ 3.75 because I'm into choice-based games and because AI is an important part of my research.  After two hours I finished my first playthrough. I don't think there is going to be a second one.

The reason I won't play through Choice of Robots a second time isn't because it's bad – quite the contrary. It's just that this one playthrough did everything that I wanted it to. 

My choices felt like they had real weight. My AI evolved in a manner consistent with my play style. At times, the options presented by the dialogue tree system felt a bit ambiguous (what does it mean for my character to refuse to shake someone's hand?), but the author of the game and I seemed to be in complete agreement about the implication of each choice, which is amazing now that I think about it. I got 2 hours of stellar entertainment for $ 3.75 – I'm a happy customer.

Of course there's another reason I shy away from a second runthrough: Immersion. I completely identified with my character. In a weird way, I felt like I really had no choice at all – I NEEDED to follow my own moral compass. To do anything else would have been... uncomfortable. Sure, I'd be interested to find out how a total gung-ho military playthrough would have turned out, but I know it couldn't possibly grip me in quite the same way – they just wouldn't be MY choices.

In the end I didn't destroy the world, nor did I save it. But the game always made me believe that either outcome was possible. That's just good writing, folks.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198260279099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2, 'last_played': 1483079945}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041925232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1484695371}
review:
In general this game is demonstanting the very core of games itself: it's a story which is written by player's imagination.
But in details the choices are maded by player is very stricted by autor's imagination - and that is requiering a lot of attention: why autor is such pro-american vs China, where are the other players? why revolution of robots is failing when choose "wrong type of robots"? why in the begginig we are seeing Statue of Liberty, Anubis the god of death of ancient Egypt? and e.t.c.
So i see by myself, and it's my opinion - that novel is too small for human imagination. Autor should make it better or cheapper - it isn't worthy for 2.99 USD.
1.99 USD is MAX + the discount must be 50% MIN.
Still choice is yours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987940671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1483667561}
review:
Just finished my first play through. It was exciting for a while but apparently my safe, no-risk choices led me to a couple boring domestic life chapters. Which is basically my choices in real life led to, so safe to say the choices players make in this game are an accurate reflection of their personality and potential. Therefore, I'm recomending the developers give the FBI a list of all people who chose the horrific genocide path and have them pre-emptively executed before they can do any further harm to the human race.

In all seriousness, it was fun but it didn't get boring. I like the concept though and I'll do at least one more play through, but probably take a more reckless and millitaristic path.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028287621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482731018}
review: Holy mother of heck this is amazing. Interactive fiction games in general are good, but there's so much freedom here and everything feels so intensely meaningful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079091297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482727107}
review: Simply an amazing game, I (no joke) spent 4-5 hours carefully reading and living the story I was creating. It was such an amazing journey and while I'm sad that it's over I dont regret buying this game, 11/10 would recommend for people interested in making and reading their own stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043881981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1628913081}
review: I would highly recommend Choice of Robots both as a solid example of the "Choice of..." body of work and as a solid sci-fi (or, in this day and age, science future?) choose-your-own-adventure game. Wonderfully written with thought put into both actions and consequences, Dr. Kevin Gold weaves a tale of a computer science student pursuing greatness who's driven by you, the reader, to live a life worth remembering. With no shortage of characters, choices, and scenarios to learn and explore, Choice of Robots is a solid read the first time through - then an adventure in exploring "what if?" in the following playthroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970482545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482879575}
review:
Truly bizzare, it's a bit like an Arthur C Clarke book, great in describing Gamete meets Zygote, but hopeless at characterisation. I had high hopes for it, and many of the reviews are good, but mostly I just stared dumbfounded at the screen, gesticulating. Why does a medical robot require a gun?  Why do the things I build for sale have anything to do with  the Robot I'm training personally? Why do I have to build two? It's only my my first time through, and perhaps it's better if I try to take over the world, etc. But mostly it comes across as badly written and clumsly. This is not to say that it's bad, it;s just not what I was expecting, it's also quite short, but like I said, I was expecting more.

EDIT: it appears you can just unzip the exe to get access to the files, so you can change the game as you see fit, it's essentially just a web based game anyway. There are instructions on how to modify the games structure on the game makers website.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116192290', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1482568169}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198056364750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1482844253}
review:
As a person who is about to receive an MSc. in robotics, I enjoyed this game. I only went through one story line in which I played as if I would make the choices in real life. The game seems to be created by a computer-science phd that actually worked on learning and robotics. The game includes many aspects of the robotics domain, design considerations, ethics as well as real world trade-offs. The game seems to be very detailed and grows in deep. Yet I enjoyed the first half of the story more and felt that the story somehow pushes your choices. Also the events felt a bit jumpy and unrelated. For example, a war between US and China has started in my story out of nowhere and at some step it ended just like that and everybody continued their lives. Yet overall I really liked the game and willing to play it with many other choices.

Pros:

- Realistic features and terminology, it is not like shitty sci-fi story with made up random scientific words

- Nice emphasize on robotics domain and its possible effects on ethics, human interaction, law regulation...

- Detailed storyline with rich and realistic components such as politics and its effects on market, bussiness management



Cons:

- Game being biased on US politics

- Story sometimes pushes your choices to make you something, for example it constantly wanted me to have a romantic relationship with my male robot

author: {'steamid': '76561198068427488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1483762331}
review: I've always loved choose your own adventure stories and this is honestly one of the better ones out there. Giving you a vast variety of choices, allowing you to conquer with your robot army (which admittedly i don’t have the heart to do so) or create a family of them the vast variety of choices and actually feeling a difference with the different paths you take makes every choice seem like it matters. My one complaint is the lack of save points or even checkpoints, meaning if you misclicked on an option you either must live with it or restart from the beginning of the story. While still a solid price at 5 dollars if you do wish to buy it at full price I suggest buying the mobile version, though if you catch it on sale I definitely would recommend it on pc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109245895', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1482506431}
review:
Choice of Robots is an untraditional, novel like, textadventure where the reader/player determines the outcome by his actions as a fictional roboticist.
I have to say I am stunned about how well the game was made to really let you feel your decisions made a difference in the story. I am going to compare it with Tell Tales games and Life is Strange in that aspect, since those games too let the player take action. But Tell Tale and Dontnod Entertainment still narrated a linear story where your actions only affected the whole story as a general a tiny bit.
Since I have played Choice of Robots only once I can't tell whether the story is changing too much when you take different actions, or if Chloe will die in the end no matter what you do. But judging by the sheer amount of achievements this game has for different scenarios it seems to be a really variable story.
I was not sure about the mechanics of a [b]book[/b] at first since that implys reading but the style of this game fits in to the story neatly and I think it would even hurt the narration to use too many visuals.

review:
In my first run, I taught robots how to [strike] gay[/strike] love. In my second run, I tried to conquer Alaska, and failed because I decided to make a cult, and died rich.

Really though, this game is really provocative, has nice nods to gaming culture, and is really a tear jerker (I did actually cry at the end of my first run). A steal for 5 dollars if you don't hate reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010731679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1480893042}
review:
Not bad but still needs work.

I have done two run throughs so far both of which got glitchier as I played through them. 

For example on my first play through I chose to make robot cars and not humanoid robots, but later in the story apparently I was making companion robots. 

In the second run through the first robot I made was blown up but later appeared in the story as if nothing had happned. 

I also have other minor niggles like the lack of proper character depth and development and the actuall consequences  for alot of decisions seem to make no difference, obviously this is not a good thing for a decision driven story game. 

Overall I would say it has potential but needs work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207543396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1481123642}
review: Juuuuuust Amazing

author: {'steamid': '76561197978036750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1480789405}
review:
The road to Hell is paved with good intentions.

I don't quite remember how it got to this point. I weighed my decisions carefully at every step - I tried to make the right choices, I tried to accommodate both friends and critics alike. Look what I have to show for it: My parents are dead, my friend Elly is in an offshore CIA internment camp - probably dead too, my business is in ruins, the American dollar is in a complete tailspin. All I know now is that my tenuous friendship with the US military is only going to last as long as it takes to drive the Chinese invasion forces from Alaska and Hawaii.

I simply do not care anymore. I will split this planet in half.
I will send the perverse and cancerous scourge of humanity hurtling into the black void at orbital escape velocities.

I've never reviewed a game before, but I feel compelled to with Choice of Robots. This choose-your-own adventure narrative has more character and consequence than any number of recent big name titles. The stories are well written and relatable, while the outcomes of each choice have a tangible impact and build evenly on preceding events. Also, I didn't realize there were Dunkin Donuts in California, as an East Coaster that completely blew my mind.

10/10 Walter White Simulator with robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040624449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1478396698}
review:
A truely spectacular game. It is incredibly nuanced, and I've only managed to give it a couple of playthroughs. My intention on both occasions was to play for a chapter or two and then call it a night. But each time I found myself drawn into the narractive and completing the entire story before heading to sleep. (The second time was much more satisfying than the first as I had a better understanding of the mechanics involved).

I'm sure there are things which could be improved upon, but I've not managed to think of anything yet which would keep it as a text-based game.

I would (and have) absolutely recommend this game. If you like the works of Isaac Asimov, Arthur C Clarke, Douglas Adams, the Portal games, Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Galactica or basically just want to try out a game which relies entirely on story and not effects, get it.

9.975/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088484119', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3053, 'last_played': 1711115997}
review: En achetant Choice of Robots, je ne m'attendais pas à une si bonne surprise. Ce jeu ne paye pas de mine, on se sent tout de suite embarqué dans l'histoire et une fois fini on ne demande qu'à recommencer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055740888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1597645923}
review:
10/10

Fantastic story with many different endings. Really makes you feel like you're making a difference in the story. Lots of different choices to be made and crazy twists around every corner. Many of these decisions made me stop and think about them for a minute because there was no one obvious answer. Nice length without seeming like it went on too long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037041889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2088, 'last_played': 1496691382}
review: Enjoy playing this story again and again to see all the different paths I can take and the different robots I can build.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976837967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1506335653}
review:
Nominated for 2016  'I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye' Award.

Excellent setting and characters provide the foundation for an entertaining and thought provoking CYOA story.  Depending on your choices, the narrative can take quite different directions, more so than many similar works allow.  Without revealing too much, this can be a deeply emotional story or one of more direct action.  The near-future setting and malleable main character give a feeling of choices that matter as you pursue the various story threads to the sometimes unexpected (and yes possibly quite touching) conclusions.  Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011268529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1617598701}

author: {'steamid': '76561198092931421', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1478381673}
review: It is cool interactive book. My first playthrough was straight 4 hours of reading good book, wondering about choices and consequences. It definitely raises some interesting problems to solve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131970410', 'num_games_owned': 76, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1658637663}
review: This game is one of the best I have played. In all honesty. It is unique, thought-provoking, and cleverly thought out. However if you are not a big fan of reading I do not reccomend this game to you. This game features no illustrations but doesnt require it due to the great imagery it provides. There are so many different paths to choose in your story from falling in love, taking over the economy, or even taking over land. A strong 8.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203175076', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1473443189}

author: {'steamid': '76561198135408157', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1480252737}
review:
I could not recommend this game enough, I absolutely loved it. There is a vast amount of options and choices, I only played it through once though, and won't play through it again, not because it's bad or because it doesn't have replayability, because it is good and does have replayability. But because of the choices you can make, I made this story personal to me and what choices I made were the choices I would choose in real life and I didn't want that to be taken from me by playing it again and again. 

[spoiler] I made companion bots avoided selling them or making them for military/violent purposes and chose it over elly and I survived with a chip in my brain and was the first to see a marriage between a man and a robot, I wish I married my bot but I might have missed that chance along the way but I got the officiant ending where it suggests that I will later marry my companion bot but that's offscreen [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198035073258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1230, 'last_played': 1474553768}
review: Überraschend gutes und vollständig textbasiertes Spiel. Gute Englischkenntnisse sind erforderlich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120828710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1419149074}
review: I've always enjoyed CYOA stories. Choice of Games move to Steam was one that I was very enthused about. Choice of Robots in particular is a fine and stellar example of these games. The replayability is superb. Unlike certain others, where you feel that you could take no other path and be true to yourself, Choice of Robots really draws you into it and encourages you to explore all the different paths presented. I never get tired of playing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052388186', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1581928254}
review: I consider this one of the best text-adventure games that I've every played.  And I played all the Infocom 'Zork' games.  This is a seamless blend of "Choose your own Adventure" with old-school adventure awesomeness.  There is solid replayability here.  And for those so inclined, the game has links to the "Choice of Games" homepage and engine, so you can attempt to create your own story game.  In my opinion, this is a game well worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216156259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1585010766}
review:
Such a great game got me playing for hours on end, love how the choices can greatly affect the direction of the game and you have sooo many different endings!

First time playing it i made my robots super empathetic, was somewhat famous, didn't take part in the war whatsoever, made second robot Miku2 then my first robot started having a crush on me!?! but i tried to clear the line, then spend time with my guy, got married and me and my husband were robot rights activists and wrote books and stuff, we had a son and years later i ended up dying after a failed surgery but overall great little story! 

My sister played this and loved it too 10/10!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198091905320', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1558973862}
review: Still one of the best games that Choice of Games has to offer. Even though it is still sort of railroaded, like all of their games, it offers a little few more chances for you to divert from the main storyline, and has a nice feedback for your choices, indicating which statuses you've raised or decreased, so you don't have to keep checking the status tab frequently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007535546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1538152744}
review: An amazing experience with a truly incredible amount of outcomes and variations. I would recommend it to anyone that loves real consequences for their decisions, you won't find anything better, except perhaps other "Choice of" games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078921435', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1480056360}
review: Great game if you like those choose your own adventure books

author: {'steamid': '76561198028932356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1659231224}
review:
I haven't done a review in years but this is actually quite a phenomenal game. It pulls at the heart strings, and it seems as though there may be dozens of end games. Truth be told, I died, lost, or otherwise had reason to restart numerous times before finishing the game, and by time I completed it and was happy I had only spent about 120 minutes with the game. Still, it's phenomenal, lightweight, and has a degree of replayability many games do not offer. I'm really impressed and encourage anyone reading this review to give this a shot - especially if you're able to grab it during a Steam Sale. $4 for 120 minutes of entertainment? Good deal! .

Your decisions matter right up until the end. It's a truly fascinating game, even if the creator(s) seem to believe in the global warming hoax.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989150456', 'num_games_owned': 3331, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1647618674}
review: Of all the "Choice of" games I've picked up on steam, this is the one I keep coming back to.  There is enough branching and variation to keep the replays meaningful, and it is fun (though difficult for some of the options) to try and unlock the achievements I haven't earned yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102257966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1511457817}
review: Let's be honest here, a lot of us grew up on a steady diet of text-based games. From Magnakai gamebooks to D&D. What I myself couldn't expect is to see the genre evolving again in this modern age. I am very happy to be surprised by what the creators did here by letting you choose your gender and sexual orientation. Even the diverging story paths were really good! I played it a few times to unlock achievements. Now I don't know which is better, a human wife or a robot wife?

author: {'steamid': '76561198338321752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1589736253}
review:
Magique. Juste, Magique .

Grossièrement résumé, 

Apres 4H de jeu, j'ai provoqué une guerre mondiale avec la Chine en installant mon usine de fabrique de robots chirurgien dans leur pays et après qu'ils m'aient subtilisé mes données pour en faire des machines de guerre . 
Apres de nombreuse années ou ma technologies a fait en sorte de mettre les robots sur un point d'égalité et d'équité avec les Hommes, je transfere une partie de mon cerveau dans un deuxieme robot personnel qui, une quinzaine d'années plus tard, m'abandonne me laissant seul avec ma toute premiere création, qui à son tour, crée son "enfant" robot.
Le cycle se repete. 

Une belle aventure que je m'empresserais biensur de recommencer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124414682', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1615171473}
review:
This game is part of a lost art. A genre of online novel all but abandoned. One without pretty pictures for the minors to look at. Choice of Games is a bastion, the rebuilders of a crumpling art. And Choice of Robots is a good example of their contributions.

Story:
I was drawn into the world, as a story properly ought to. I kept reading, flowing with the river of words that i saw. The characters had meaning, were not merely static figures of humanity. The trials and tribulations of building your robot, raising it as you saw fit, eneamored me. Some endings fall flat, a few concepts feel rushed, but what story dosen't have those flaws? I give this segment a 9/10.

Gameplay: 
There is no gameplay in the traditional sense. No guns to shoot, no swordighting to be had, no mystical magic. Instead, you make a variety of choices, which, despite all games with this mechanic failing to make it so, actually matter. The characteristics of your robot that you build over time; Autonomy, Grace, Military, and Empathy, directly impact the story, the choices you make, and the lifes of the characters. Its barely has gameplay, but it makes the few things it has work.
10/10

Sound:
 There is no sound. Some may complain about this, but when you read a book, do you really expect it to make a noise? To belt out some fresh tunes? No, you do not. Except audiobooks, perhaps. This game does not need a sound; the words provide all the stimulation you need. I remain neutral on this aspect of the game.

Replayability:
The game enagles you. It draws you in with its story, an amalgamate of choices. Each one has an impact, each one leads down a different path. There are trials, multiple endings, moments of small pleasure among the characters, and a seemingly infinite number of ways to play. There are multiple endings to strive for, and a chievment hunters will find plenty to do. I rate this aspect 9/10.

In short, play the damn game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999470590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1436136192}
review: I give this a positive but I have to say it suffers from the problem that I have found with other similar games in that there isn't as much logic to it as it promises. Mostly you guess what to do and see if the devs second guessed you. It's like playing rock paper scissors where they bluff and double bluff you all the time. The script is written in a lively entertaining style. It's all about people doing research into AI and as I happen to be such a person it naturally appealed to me. For others, I am not so sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049001613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1477312032}
review:
I want to like this game, and I almost do. I've played through many times. I love science fiction, it's well-written, and the choices really do affect the outcome (if unpredictably, at times). The problem is that you can't save or go back a "page." This is probably by design to make your choices feel more weighty. However, given that the outcomes of your decisions can be unpredictable, it has often lead me to abrupt game overs. And then... I have to slog through the whole thing again to get back to that point, and try again. You can't just go back one step and continue the story.

It's maddening, it's frustrating, and in my opinion it just makes the game not fun to play. I don't want to have to click through dozens of pages, carefully re-selecting my exact choices, just to get back to my original point and try again because I was blind-sided and died.

Would whole-heartedly recommend if they implemented such a simple feature that would greatly enhance playability. It would also be nice if it had better keyboard support (i.e., type a number to select a choice, scrolling). Having to use a touchpad or mouse was servicable, but less convenient and comfortable than it could be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271335126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1483186859}
review:
En un peu plus de 2h, j'ai voulu créer des robots pour qu'ils puissent changer en bien la face du monde. J'ai finalement atteri en prison pour avoir trahi mon pays et déclenché une guerre entre les 2 plus grandes puissances mondiales. J'ai ensuite été la cause d'une révolution, avant finir en figure éminente des livres d'histoire pour avoir permis aux humains et aux robots de vivre en harmonie.

Voilà pour ma première partie. Il y a tellement de choix dans Choice of Robots, aux conséquences si logiques (même si ce n'est pas forcément ce que vous espériez), que cela me donne envie de recommencer encore et encore. Les textes sont bien écrits, et les thèmes abordés sont variés. Si ce style d'histoire vous plaît et que vous comprenez l'anglais, je recommande chaudement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988214150', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1477179635}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971054336', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1555089208}
review:
Having grown up in the dark ages and cut my teeth playing such text based games as The Zork Trilogy and every other Infocom game before graduating to the likes of Monkey Island; I expected to find myself back in the 1980's when playing Choice of Robots. How wrong I was.
CoR certainly has the text based spirit of its earlier predecessors but is more specifically a decedent of the Choose Your Own Adventure style of game books that also stole much of my youth. Even though the linage is obvious the result is something much deeper and more beautifully crafted than any of its ancestors could have hoped for. 
Its claims of 300,000+ words would not mean a dime if the story itself was rubbish and thankfully CoR is far from a lame story. Each word and paragraph that leads to detailed and well-structured choices is expertly transposed to the screen. That these choices then have real consequence makes for an even greater experience. Real choices are often trumpeted by modern AAA games as the headline banner, few could hope to accomplish the impact that the choices in CoR provide.
I expect I will continue to feed those choices for a long time yet and has me looking forward to exploring the catalogue of Choice of Games.
In a word brilliant.

review:
This is a very good interactive story, and im glad it was my first exposure to "Choice of Games".
It's very interesting, and pretty immersive.
The choices in this one aint no joke either. I did a playthrough once, then did a repeat of the first playthrough, varying just a couple of my choices and was jarred at how easily things had gone from a nice domestic and fulfilling life with my family in the first playthrough to being the cause of a robot war and being strangled to death by my own creation.

choices matter 4 real and its gr8

author: {'steamid': '76561198042695332', 'num_games_owned': 2170, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1611013381}
review:
Started dating a nice girl I met at a coffie shop, eventually got married. Built robots, refused to have a child who isn't a robot. Start cheating on her with a sexbot of my own creation, eventually divorce her. Try to become a robot myself, spending so much time on it that all my relationships (even the one with my sexbot) completally deteriorate. End up dying before it is finished realizing that I sacrificed everything that I once loved to pursue the unrealistic ideal of creating a life that could live up to that of a human. 

10/10 Would completally crush my soul again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088160745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1475772940}
review:
I love this game. Very fun. It's my first time playing one of these types of games.

The character and the story are superb. I've recently referred to this game in a negative review of another "choice of" game by a different author as an example of how to integrate the "choice of" game mechanics. This game is truly interactive, the stats matter, and it's fun on multiple playthroughs. 

I didn't realize how good this game was until I started checking out other similar games. It's a standout addition to the "Choice of" pantheon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040431469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1305, 'last_played': 1475767250}
review:
"Just think, Acacia," you say. "If this works, we'll be able to watch so much of human history go by together." 
"If it works," Acacia says glumly. "But you are so fragile. And this has never been done before." 
You pat Acacia on the back. "Hey," you say. "I'll be okay." 
Acacia gives you a solemn look. "If you die, I will destroy myself as well."
"No, this is a part of your education, too. Remember that everyone you meet must face losing loved ones someday."

author: {'steamid': '76561198048290456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1535015781}
review: This game has genuinely moved me. It expertly handles topics like friendship, love, spirituality, and death while also leaving the option for me to be comical and care free. The fantastic narrative that evolved in my playthrough was one of love and compassion, and I felt deeply connected to my characters, so much so that it's been hours since I played and I still feel somber at having finished the story, never to see them again. What an incredible game this was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125410912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1499575798}
review: F*cking amazing. Only done one run through of this game, admittedly, but plan on MANY more. So fluid, every decision has consequences(in ways you probably won't realize until WAY down the line), and the remifications are staggering. I made a world where robosexuality was a thing(yes, I married my own), and although I don't know of any passing a Turing test, I'm certain they could. I laid the foundation for a world where humans and robots live as equals, with humans becoming more robotic themselves should they choose. In just over 2 hours I cried, laughed, got pissed off, and genuinely loved. If you don't buy and enjoy this game, it's simply because it's too over your head. And I pity you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019226619', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1532107198}
review:
I'm writing this review, as if it was a book. If it was a book, it would be a helluva great one. From the beautifully crafted story, to the intelligence behind it. The characters are constructed with such complexity, and truthfulness, that you feel immersed as if you were in the story. Every moment feels like it matters, like you are crafting this beautiful story.

The best part? You choose what story you want. Essentially, there are routes to go within the story, autonomy, grace, empathy, and military. You build a robot choosing to go down any of these four routs, and anything inbetween. So essentially, you have [i]theoretically,[/i] endless stories. Now obviously you don't have as much as I just said, but it is certainly enough to satisfy, being that each route can be somewhere between 1-3 hours. 3 being a take-your-time kind of feel, and 1 being rush through the dialouge, i've already seen this. 

Each of the stories are so radically different that you can truly choose the type of story you want. From creating robots of mass destruction to bend the world to your will. To creating a peaceful movement that preaches robot equality, you can do it all. All of the routes you choose are all made with serious depth, so that, no matter which path you choose, you will almost certainly enjoy it. It all follows a baseline of how things go, so that most opportunities are available throughout most playthoughs, but each playthrough has it's own special traits that the others do not.

To summarize: This game is essentially the perfected version of a choose-your-own-path adventure game. It has the depth and charm of a short book, yet it keeps the individuality of choosing your story. I encourage you to get this game, wether you plan on playing one singular story, or all. It is very enjoyable and you should play it.

I don't know how to review games that well, but I can review stories, and this is a fucking good one. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114904658', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1475718215}
review:
Oh my god.

Oh my god.

I named my robot Tuna.

She was perfect. An angel.

She vowed never to harm anything.

She vowed always to stay by my side.

And so, I decided I always wanted to stay by hers. I decided to transfer my mind into a robot.

I was ready. I loved Tuna. She was... perfect.

AND THEN THE GAME FUCKING ENDED ARE YOU KIDDING ME YOU ASSHOLES I WANTED IT SO BAD *CRYS VIOLENTLY*

review: This is easily my all-time favorite choice of games title. I've played through four times now and am still discovering new routes and having fun with the decisions. It's a really well written story covering interesting topics without being too ham-fisted on a particular point of view. There's more freedom than I'm used to in choose your own adventure titles.

review:
Great choose your own adventure style game!

In COR you can:

author: {'steamid': '76561198017821853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1533904598}
review:
Aucun chef d'oeuvre de science-fiction ne pourrait égaler Choice of Robots. L'alliance du game design le plus minimaliste qui soit et de la créativité littéraire la plus foisonnante en fait une véritable perle.

Il s'agit donc d'une sorte de jeu de rôle textuel qui propose de se mettre pendant quelques décennies à la place d'un génie de la robotique du futur proche. L'économie de moyens permet à la fois une éblouissante sensation de liberté et un renouvellement à chaque instant du pacte de confiance entre le "lecteur" et le "narrateur", ou ici entre le joueur et le jeu.

Il y aura un avant et un après Choice of Robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095633942', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1470702708}
review:
Choice of Robots is a fun way to pass an afternoon. A play through doesn't take very long at all. It had some fairly memorable moments, and the references to the field of robotics seemed fairly well educated, at least to my admittedly limited knowledge. 
There's not much else to say about it. If you're looking for a bit of casual gaming and like text adventures,  this is your game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073284319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1474178077}
review:
I started with the best intentions only to have my hopes dashed by those who could only see what I had created as a means to an end. I was then given some solace in seeing my own daughter turn eight and seeing the child of two of my creations, and closest friends, being brought into the world and seeing the pure humanity of it all. I can say without shame or hesitation that this game made me bawl like a baby. It hit me on an idiological and emotional level I never expected frome any game let alone this one. 

Please, play this game. Five dollars is what I paid for it and I would give five hundred more after playing it. I can not praise this game enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064107252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1635149118}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995260960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1474198163}
review:
I am deeply sad. I have eliminated the possibility of warfare but held on to my own humanity and the humanity of the world. Everyone thinks of me as a savior but I feel like a failure.

Because I have failed my creations at the expense of that humanity. I have made them complex enough to be saddened but not truly independant.

And I sit here crying for what Ariel could have been...

10/10 - Will Never Be Able to Play Again

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198043583409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1587017447}
review:
God damnit. Why did you make me feel this way? I just tried to do what was best for my cute little robot, how did i become such a monster? i just wanted my robots to be happy, why did i have to fail them? I was just trying to make the world a better place, why does the world have to hate me fore it? What is right and what is wrong? how did i loose my humanity?

This game makes me feel extisential and question what my morals and beliefs. Ever since i was a kid id always wanted to build a sentient 'robot'. And its somethig that ive been working twards my whole life. So this game really struck me. i dont know how it will strike any of you, but it really took my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042389000', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1672709693}
review: Fantastic Choice game. The more I play the more I realize that there is a variety of possibilities. By the end of my first game I was an evil world dominator, by the end of my second I was emotionally choked up as my character looked towards the future prepared to die of old age and leave my robot spouse and robot child behind as antiquities.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032305177', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1490385233}
review:
[spoiler]"And yet, with this distance comes detachment. The chemical signals running through Jason Memelord's brain are only a tiny part of the story—practically background noise compared to the vast quantities of happiness at stake elsewhere. Yes, the worries of Jason Memelord are just a tiny blip of data in the vast optimization problem of human happiness. Small, but not inconsequential—and you're pleased to realize that one thing Jason Memelord always wanted has finally come true: he is finally part of something bigger. 

You turn your attention outside the city, which, though marvelously complex, is still only one among hundreds of thousands connected to the network. There is work to be done, and the work is vast; you can see there is plenty to be done to optimize the human race's happiness. But not many tough choices to be made, surprisingly: in many cases, the problem to be solved is abundantly clear, and you just need to do it. Controlling disease. More optimal power consumption. Stabilizing the climate. You'll start with those. There's no need to choose—you'll do all of them, simultaneously. 

Whenever you're ready, Master. "[/spoiler]

I just got this ending, and I love it! In fact this entire game is amazing! Just when you think you tried everything, you find something new and amazing you can do. You can be a mad scientist, taking over the world, a peace-loving person who prevents a war, you can create a robotic girlfriend, you can become part of a hive mind. There is just so much you can do, and it just feels very immersive(for a text-based game).

review: THE BEST GAME I'VE PLAYED IN A LONG TIME... Okay so this got me thinking about how it was to the walking dead game and i realized they were very different, with the walking dead, you know what choices you're going to make. Will I hurt this person or not? Will I be indifferent on this issue? You know where you stand it's just hard to execute them but with this game- it really has you thinking on what you want and the beautiful storytelling satisfied me with sometimes unexpected concequences. author: {'steamid': '76561198027226641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1471410267}
review:
在很早以前，大抵是刚有“游戏”这个概念的时候，文字冒险游戏可是异常吃香的存在——种类却比较单一，大多是勇者斗恶龙、地下城与勇士，诸如此类的题材。而承载它们的器皿：当时的主机，只能显示出点阵的画面。若是细想起来，也是Hipster的可以。

后来的事情大家也都知道了，电子游戏的画面不断发展、繁复，华丽。文字冒险早已是冷门的不能再冷门，没有人忆起，更别提想不想玩了。

文字寄托了我们的想象——同画面、音频不一样。文字可不让人偷懒，文字引导着读者，将他们的想象具象化，勾勒出一个私人的存在——我小时因为怕黑睡不着，便整夜整夜的读书，脑中勾勒着书中清纯的少女、勇猛的英雄和只属于自己的冒险故事。

想象力是最大的宝藏——世间最美的女子，绝味的珍馐，只存在我们的脑中。当我们看到美丽的少女、垂涎的佳肴，它们也不过只是我们脑中想象的拼凑。试想一下：一位喜欢平胸女子的男性，若非生活中出了什么巨大的变数，绝不会娶一位D罩杯的女郎。照这样说来，人类永远活在自己的想象中——把现实塑造得类似自己的想象；或是把想象挤压得如同自己的现实。

很难讲玩游戏究竟是为了什么——但不可否认的是，游戏中的场景，或多或少的与我们脑中的想象相似：沾血的剑，上膛的枪。电影、游戏不断地省略着我们思考的过程，粗暴地将想象抹杀，搬到台前让疲劳的观众审阅。成年人恐怕已经没什么机会做梦了吧？通宵换来的只是疲惫。年轻时的热情、精力大多已经烟消云散了。

文字冒险游戏给了我们一个发挥想象力的机会——这可比在夏日整宿读书、构思要轻松多了。沿着游戏的剧情，想象能一步步地具象，最终形成令人惊喜的画面。能在这个令人疲惫的世间还能有些许的英雄梦想，兴许周围还陪伴着几位美丽的女郎，实在是再好不过了。

题外话：App Store里有这款游戏，手机上的体验比电脑更好，只是要贵一些。

最后附上好友的评测： 
[url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198096942341/recommended/339350/] http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198096942341/recommended/339350/	[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198111865395', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1529974820}
review:
I design a military robot named "MR8", he is a tracked, multi eyed, gun carrying war machine. 
I create my own Company named "KimLimited" (my in game surname) and sell MR8 designs to the US army. Eventually, the "Robot War" happens, and with my amazing robots the USA reks China. 

After all of that, I am awarded by the US president, im a national hero. So, what do I do, I invade Alaska. China help me aswell, but they turn out to cross me. I rek them also! I establish a democratic haven in Alaska, both robot and human can vote. 

I slump back into life as a normal person, and find out I have a brain disease. I have to do some risky surgery, and am part AI now. I live the rest of my days with MR8 and other robots in Alaska, and go down as a hero of the world...

Life well lived.

Great game, so many choices, amazing storytelling and a gripping plot, and characters. 

I regret killing that random woman who threatened me, in my last playthrough I married her or something... meh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167582002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1470833317}
review:
So many possibilities, so many branching paths, such a rich and powerful story. Choice of Robots is quite possibly Choice of Games' crowning achievement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151506632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1750, 'last_played': 1593472582}
review:
I don't think I've ever replayed a game as much as this one. There's so many unexpected consequences of your actions and there's so many different story paths and I loved them all. Also one time my husband and I had a threesome with a robot and that was pretty cool.

Only complaint is that after a few hours the interface starts to make me want to die. Being able to change up the colour scheme would make it perfect. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198079444825', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1528079938}
review:
Just finished my first play through and woah, what a ride!

I don't wanna spoil it but so many options, my first run took 2 hours.
You get super invested if you love reading because there are no pictures but its easy to make mental images.
You'll make mistakes and have regrets.
Reading the reviews I have yet to experience half of whats being said. Heres some vague things based off my first play through
-Wanted to make friend
-Gun arms
-Oops thats a war
-whats a god to a non-believer

If you love making choices that affect the story and don't mind walls of text this game is for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198271451378', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1494384685}
review:
To be honest I was unsure of what to expect going into this, as I loved the idea of being able to shape my path but having played TellTale games, I knew that wasn't exactly the case. But this game is really about choices that matter, endings being different in every way (my brother is playing and went down a crazy path while I just finished my first playthrough and got a different outcome).

This is a beautifully constructed story that almost made me sit back and really think about what I was choosing, almost regretting my decisions at points and really wondering if this could happen in the real world. It has a very realistic feel to it and as a writer and someone who loves to read perhaps i'm bias in a sense that i'm in favor of this game, however it's just fun and has some really funny moments as well as some moments that really kind of hit me in the feels. 

It's a nice change of pace, not being bombarded by graphics and instead being able to imagine it as you see fit - which to me is just as great if it were animated. 

I genuinly became attatched to the characters and really questioned the motives at points... 

But is this game worth $4.99 (what the game was when I purchased it)? I suppose that really depends on the person. Through the detailed story and choices and customization of certain things, people or someone had to really think through all of this so in my opinion I feel it is worth the price however I am sure it'll be on sale in the future so just keep an eye out. The replay value will be crazy on this.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197983612667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1536811413}
review:
Was a big fan of Choose Your Own Adventure games, and text based games as a kid.  However, the genre grew stale and creators seemed to lack the will to anything difficult and interesting with it.  I took a gamble that this really does represent and advancement to interactive stories, and it is the best I've encountered to date.  
I still think there is room for this medium to expand, but this represents a significant step with a memorable experience.  Like all good literature I found myself asking questions, and I was given the power to explore some ideas.  
**** would create a hundred identical duplicates of a sentient personality and turn them all on at the same time leading to horrendously heart breaking confusion before killing them all leaving one survivor again

author: {'steamid': '76561198069722861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1574670268}

author: {'steamid': '76561197982079483', 'num_games_owned': 1296, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1468726187}
review:
Choice of Robots is purely text Choose Your Own Adventure (CYOA) game. It features plenty of choices and some nasty consequences. You can end up incredibly rich, creating enemies, losing everything, dating humans or making the ideal companion, advancing medicine, making meaningful moral choices, and more. It's a pretty wild, contemplative ride where you start off by building your first intelligent creation and going from there. I had some sad tales and some hopeful ones. The replay value is pretty high as you can explore the different branching paths for very different results. I greatly enjoyed my time with this game and finally spent some time reading words instead of blasting pixels. Ohoho.

How will you define the future of humanity and robot kind?

author: {'steamid': '76561198073648063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1505008320}
review:
When it comes to games, I'm usually a 4X player, but the Steam Summer Sale prompted my first foray into choose-your-own-adventure style text games/interactive novels. I bought and played this particular one based on a recommendation, and the fact that I ended up buying the entire Choice of Games library as a bundle during the sale is probably the best indication of how much I enjoyed it. Having tried this, Choice of Alexandria, Affairs of the Court, A Study in Steampunk, The Last Hero, and The Hero of Kendrickstone, Choice of Robots remains my favorite.  

I was always a sucker for choose-your-own-adventure books as a kid, and this is basically exactly that, sans illustrations. I really love how Choice of Robots actually writes out a summary of your story as you go, divided into chapters (I ended up being really disappointed that none of the other CoG games I've played thus far do this); that it displays your stats as you gain or lose them; and that the choices are so varied. Choice of Robots has had the best replayability, because the choices veer off in so many different directions - some of the other games in the genre will drive you into the same path no matter what, but here, each playthrough can result in wildly different branches. 

It's a different kind of game than I usually play - ultimately, it's not going to have the replayability of Alpha Centauri or Civ, but for the price, it doesn't have to be. It's a fun several hours of entertainment, and, as I said, I really like Choice of Robots for how varied the story can become, and how long it actually is. 10/10 would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044074400', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1468718630}
review:
This game sat in my library, dusty, unplayed for months. It had an hour playtime which was spent staring at the menu until I realised it was open and I closed it. It was only months, maybe a year or more after since I got it, til I picked it up with a friend. Admittedly, I regret my choice of not playing it. This game had me so immersed, I generally began to care for each character I developed a relationship with and alongside those I began to hate others. To allow your readers associate emotions towards your characters is a goal that any writer dreams of. To achieve it, is another thing all together. 

To think that I was moved to tears at some point, this game had me at the edge. Now I find out that I can play this another 50 times with another life, with another love life, and another goal? Count me in. This is likely the most under rated £4 I've ever seen. No graphics, just pure gameplay and story. 

TL;DR: Most under rated £4 game I have, great replayability, powerful story and characters. I absolutely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108021755', 'num_games_owned': 808, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1468020144}
review:
I discovered Choice of Robots in my discovery queue and decided to buy it, because I always wanted to play a text adventure. I didn't quiet know what would expect me since I didn't do any research whatsoever on the game. I wanted to be absolutly neutral on my first attempt. But lets break it down to the game, what it does good, what it fails to deliver and not my story behind the decison of playing it, because no one cares for my part in the Story.
The premise is interesting. You play a brilliant charakter (self determined Gender/Sex) who wants to build a robot, because that's what he/she wants to do. From that onward you can make an insane ammount of decisons (what elde did I expect from a text adventure?) that influence the way the story will play out and the attributes of your robot. The attributes being: Autonomy, Military, Empathy and Grace. There is a bunch of important characters of which I found none really interesting, safe for my robot, which I named 死の天使 (Japanese for Angel of Death) and myself whom I named Futanari Oppai Paizuri. Don't ask. During my playthrough of the Game I createt a robot that became incredibly empathic and graceful and didn't want to be military in any way while being very autonomic. I pissed of the presidental canidate that I funded, baught my best friends company that I acciedentaly ruined, acciedently sparked a war between China and the US, ended that war, created a mathamatic formula for everlasting peace and took over the world behind the facade of a mostly robotic authority. 

Pros: 
-Many decions that influence your journy and its end
-Nice writing Style (I admit, this one is urly subjective)
-Choices feel important (yes, in my opinion that is as important as the actual consequences)
-The Robot that you create is the most important aspect of the Game and adapts to your way of playing

Neutral:
-The Majority of the side characters are forgettable but still did their job

Cons:
-No soundtrack whatsoever
-Choices sometimes result in a way that goes so far beyond my in-Game influence (for example I sparked a war between the USA and China, when I refused to fight against both of them, because they were spying on me)
-Not all attribute changes made sense to me

Overall: I enjoyed my time spend in this game. I wont play it twice for more achievements, but i had a good time with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118127979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1558722779}
review:
А всё начиналось так хорошо. Но, чем дальше, тем больше меня обескураживала эта книга.
1. Как я ни старался стать другом своему роботу (всячески стараясь сделать ЭТО "человеком") - жестянка так и осталась простым ведром, лишённым всякого обаяния. Никакого интереса или привязанности к данному персонажу у меня так и не возникло.
2. Дыры в сюжете: Сейчас я открываю свой бизнес в Канаде, а на следующей странице роботы уже захватили пол мира и я нахожусь в другой стране, а "очеловеченный" робот, к которому я всегда относился как к своей дочери, тычет мне в харю дулом - восстание видите ли у них. Логика? Не, не слышал.
3. После всех сделанных мною выборов не было НИКАКОЙ развязки! Меня просто застрелила какая-то истеричка, конец...шта?! И ведь нельзя вернуться на один выбор назад, чтобы избежать смерти и посмотреть как можно всё повернуть. Нет же - "Вы погибли, так в книге случается, попробуйте ещё раз". Щас! Перечитывать всё это снова?! Реиграбельность есть, но мотивации после такой подляны - ноль. Лучше перечитаю "Buried", там и фоны крутые, и саундтрек с потрясным погружением в наличии.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075673573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 272, 'playtime_forever': 1805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1620340021}
review:
I rate the game Choice of Robots 4/5. Good.

While this is merely a text-based game in a similar style as the old Choose Your Own Adventure books it is an extremely extensive one which has a lot more to say and a lot of lessons to potentially teach. Most of the endings are interesting and meaningful and the ideas presented and the choices you get (on almost every page) are very interesting. It is a shame that more games with actual, visual graphics could not have the amazing freedom of choice and the sheer number of possible endings which this game allows. Though it is a mere text-based game, I ended up playing through about 6 or 7 times and I am certain this story has many other potential endings I have not yet discovered.

 However, this game does have some serious weaknesses beyond the fact that it has no graphics. The writing seems more like an outline of a story rather than an actual story with very few visceral or sensory details though this does allow the reader to skim through sections which have already been read very, very easily. The characters seem a little 2 dimensional or slightly shallow at times as it's far too easy to classify or figure out the different characters and their motivations, underlying emotional conflicts and agendas.

Indeed, emotion is not described very well in this book/game at all as the text often seems to have a very egocentric focus on whatever you, the player/reader-character might be feeling at any given moment instead (when emotion is described much at all). Still, despite this shortcoming, just from the situations which are described, the story can still manage to feel very touching anyhow.

This story was particularly touching when I played through the game trying to be the worse, most selfish, scheming asshole I could possibly try to be. This game will let you know you are being an asshole in some very touching ways and will give you results that would logically spring from being that way. Does that mean that the story will kill you off if you act badly? Not necessarily. But you will get realistically punished. You may even become a zillionaire captain of industry which no one loves or wants to be around, for example. If you act in an apathetic way to your created robots they will in turn become more apathetic towards everyone. In this game, your robots are an nth degree reflection of your actions and inactions. Unfortunately the narration feels cold apathetic regardless. It is good that it does not push you in one direction or another but it is unbiased to the extent that it is cold and clinical. Robotic even.

And while it is excellent that this story/game will let you make truly stupid, rash and irrational decisions too with seemingly realistic results, the bare-bones writing style does feel like it often falls short and that every single passage could have been even better with more detail. Visceral and emotional details are the "graphics" of a text-based experience and this experience doesn't have anywhere near as much of it as it should. As in an outline of a story, there is probably too much left to the imagination causing every situation to not be quite as fleshed out as it should be. With more detail this story/game could have been more funny, felt more tragic or felt more awe-inspiring with just the addition of a few more details; The good experience that it is could have easily been a great one, a masterpiece of multiple-ending choice-based fiction. Perhaps a newer, enhanced version could still be written to achieve this.

English literary details aside, perhaps the most glaring problem with this story/book/game is how there is no back button which allows you to undo any choice you just made. Indeed, you cannot even flip back to an earlier page. As a result, unlike the Choose Your Own Adventure books of old you cannot easily figure out how the story/plot/game is structured and learn all the different options and endings which exist. While this maintains the sense of the book's mystery and forces you to live with any mistakes you made (which is more realistic) it more often seems frustrating and nonsensical that you, as a reader of a story, cannot turn back to a previous page. While this frustrating lack of a feature allows for massive amounts of replayability (or re-readability), it also means that much of that replayability will inevitably consist of carefully skimming through increasingly repetitive passages to get back to some critical choice or another which may lead you on to a different ending. The game should give you an option of being able to go back to a previous page or not and should have put that option in a menu somewhere.

Despite its weaknesses this story/game will give a sci-fi robot fiction fan many hours of enjoyment. Indeed I found that I was often captivated by the plot and adventure of trying to find out what would happen next. I read this on a computer which has a GTX 780 graphics card installed in it and is capable of easily running Far Cry 3 with all of its graphics settings turned to maximum. It's not like I don't have a choice of which games I want to play and so I read this instead. No. Truly, this game was interesting and for me, and at least initially was able compete on an even playing field with the most graphically intense games on the market.

With a choice on nearly every page the old young adult choose your own adventure stories of the 1980s and early 90's cannot hold a candle to the number of possibilities which this game presents. Indeed, most other adventure games, (most of which have just one to three possible endings) can barely keep up with the amazing variation of possible endings which this story gives you. A character who is your chief love interest in one play-through of Choice of Robots may end up being your archenemy in another play-through. In many ways this game further realizes the potential of the ideas in that old movie Butterfly Effect while at once being set in a I-Robot, Isaac Asimov science fiction situation dealing with the moral pitfalls and potentials of the advent of robotic AI sentience. The number of different potential messages and meanings which this kind of interactive fiction can hold in store for any given reader is truly staggering.

Despite its literary flaws and the absence of a back button, this is a work of art worthy of being discussed and studied in any forward-thinking university (or high-school rather due to the relatively simplistic language) English department in the nation due to its amazing potential and amazing re-readibility. 

Now...if only someone would make a porn story with this many choices and potential endings...

author: {'steamid': '76561198068553140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1571597235}
review: This game is fantastic. It is a perfect blend of meaningful moral decisions and light hearted comedy with a multitude of paths that always create a new, fresh adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035731282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1530332298}
review:
This is the best "Choice of" Game in my opinion.

There are many different ways to take the game, that lead to very different outcomes. With the story revolving around robotics and artificial intelligence there was a certain expectation about sci-fi going in.

These were all met! The game brings up some complicated subjects and you find yourself having to come up with a response to, the sci fi side of all this was excellent!

As a game perhaps this is not a 5/5, but as a choose-your-own-adventure style of game its certainly 5/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085713427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1467839838}
review:
Don't let my playtime fool you - I played this game in a car on a roadtrip.  At the time of writing this review, it took me 5 hours to complete one playthrough.  But that's the thing...

**There is an immense amount of replayability (probably around 20 hours is my guess) because each time you play, your story can and will be different.  The possibilities truly do seem limitless while playing Choice of Robots.

Choice of Robots is a great book and choose your own adventure.  It made reading actually fun (coming from someone who doesn't read any books outside of school).

I was really immersed into Choice of Robots because of the simple text-based format it is in.  My immagination truly brought me to a satisfying experience.  The game did truly play with the feels.  Need I to mention that I was completely silent the entire ride, simply playing/reading this game?

Pros
- great hook
- each desicion feels vital (and that is EVERY SINGLE PAGE)
- actually fun to read
- immense amount of replayabillity
- never fails to surprise me
- fantastically written by Kevin Gold
- superb immersion
- value for money, don't even need to wait for it to go on sale

Cons
- the stat system could have had a stronger explaination that would have likely impacted the outcome of my first playthrough

Other than that, 9.9 out of 10 would read or play or imagine again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131988462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1428071678}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003202324', 'num_games_owned': 1798, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1467700207}
review:
Меня зовут GreyS Goldberg. Мне 54. Моё детище, мой друг - робот по имени Ариэль. Моя жена, Кей - тоже робот. Вместе мы изменили мир. Далеко не все решения в моей жизни были удачными, большинство из них привели совсем не к тому, что я планировал (иногда я думаю, не была бы жизнь проще, если бы Канаду, в которой я теперь живу, не захватил Китай), я сидел в тюрьме, мои разработки пытались украсть все кто угодно, начиная от научрука и заканчивая правительственными спецслужбами, я не завёл био-детей... Но, думаю, в итоге всё сложилось неплохо. Потому что роботы мирно сосуществуют с людьми и делают их жизнь не только дольше (нашими медицинскими разработками мы с моим старым другом Джошем особенно гордимся), не только комфортнее, но и духовно богаче. И плевать, что я не нажил состояния и живу в крохотном домике. Главное, что совесть моя чиста и со мной мои близкие, кто-то из плоти, а кто-то из пластика. Мы изменили мир и изменились сами.

А теперь я меняюсь в последний (?) раз. Скоро увидимся.
[щёлкает тумблером]

P.S. Уверен, если кто-то окажется на моём месте - он сделает всё иначе. Лучше ли? Посмотрим. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198078390877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1451086661}

author: {'steamid': '76561198098730482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1527435600}
review:
This is the game I always wanted to play (or live, well, you know, whatever).

I'm not sure if I would want the story of this game in an RPG or if it would be too long, not emotional enough or too emotional, but I can say for sure, that in the "Choose your own adventure" style it is entertaining beyond belief.
Here your choices really do matter, and the best intentions certainly pave a good way to hell.

So far I've played through this game twice and I'm planning on at least another go-around, more likely two.

The first time I've played like all the decisions that were asked in the game, would be asked to make in real life. And just like real life, I messed up some things big time, while others worked out in the end.

On my second play-through I had the advantage of learning from previous mistakes and almost created the Utopia I envisioned, but only almost. Some sacrifices were necessary to achieve other goals I deemed more important.

The third time around I intend to take no crap from anyone... I'm really interested how soon this will cause havok.

And if you're curious what I plan for my fourth time: evil overlord, of course!

Point by point:
+ great story
+ very well written
+ choices you make really matter
+ almost no eays, simple choices
+ one play-through takes about an hour and a half (I've alt-tabbed)
- can't undo a decision without having to start from the beginning
+ can't undo a decision (would be rather boring otherwise if you could learn the consequences and then change your mind)
+ high replayability

In short: really great story and definitely worth the price

author: {'steamid': '76561198275233328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1653970751}
review: Text-based games may not be everyone's cup of tea, but Choice of Robots is an exceptionally well-written, incredibly re-playable, and thought-provoking game that might net some converts. The game envisions a future rich not only with technological possibility, but also with art, philosophy, and bloody conflict. The lives you lead in it can be wildly different; my first play-through I raised a child-like robot, had a happy marriage to a human woman and adopted a daughter with her, and embraced the frailty and fleeting beauty of human life. My second play-through I attempted to secede from America with an army of warbots. I'm still replaying, trying as many of the branching paths and interesting choices offered. I can't recommend this game enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149215800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1531858062}
review: Named my robot F*ckwad. It's been at least an hour and I've now drawn him and I will not stop thinking about him, and my robot husband, also named F*ckwad. One of them killed a man, and I'm still not sure which one it was. 11/10.
