author: {'steamid': '76561198041543513', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1626674841}
review:
[b]tl;dr -> I realized that I am extremely superficial because in ~6h of playtime (numerous playthroughs) I have divorced my wife in order to marry my sexbot EVERY TIME. 11/10 stares right into my soul.[/b]

[b]Cons:[/b]

-super addicting, binged played it for 6 hours

-really makes you wish there were other great choose-your-own-adventure (CYOA) titles available (for other solid ones, check out the Heroes Rise trilogy (Choice Games) and Tin Star ("Hosted" on Choice Games)

[b]Pros:[/b]

-quite easily the best available CYOA text-based game on Steam

-300,000 word count - extensive amount of content and scenes, multiple endings to explore

-employs the "discovery" system - main characters are not revealed in the stats menu until you meet them

-your stats (ex: humanity, wealth) and your robot's (ex: military, empathy) directly impact the story and available choices

-every decision you make will affect the game and your unique story - the different paths are very different 

-amazing story that remains engaging with every path you decide to walk

-dynamic characters that will react to everything you do

-longer than most other CYOA titles in the Choice Games franchise

Of every CYOA I've played on Steam, none have come close to the quality of Choice of Robots. I explored the game for ~6 hours and still have not discovered every possible ending. There are many achievements and scenes to encounter, and the different story paths are all extremely interesting and well-written. I hope to see more Choice titles of this calibre. A must-buy if you enjoy CYOA games and robot themes.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,
DJSF [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/djsfsroguereviews]@DJSF's Rogue Reviews[/url]

[url=http://theroguereviews.com/]My Website[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998912041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1452588486}
review:
[h1]A story for robo fanatics[/h1]

Any robot fanatic should try this out, you get to put yourself in that dream situation that seems almost so impossible to reach. As an aspiring sci-fi writer, I found this to be a very inspriational and satisfying experience. 

[h1]Possible spoilers below[/h1]

There are many paths, but I've only taken one, and it was an emotional rollercoaster. I feel like I would spoil the experience by going with choices that would go against my true morals. Everyone's path will be different, and I mean [b]everyone's[/b].

The paths last around 2 - 3 hours each, so make sure you have some free time ready as there are no save options.

It's very well written and very much engaging. At no point did I really feel like I was being restricted by the author. Hell, I went into this hoping I could live a gay robot fantasy, and you bet I was able to live a gay robot fantasy. There aren't many experiences out there that let you do that. The really fun thing about this is that the author doesn't ask personal questions, it just rolls with your choices and your identity without berating you or questioning you. It's not intrusive, either: at no point did it ask about my orientation or preferences (aside from asking for my gender), it just let me do what felt right for me, which in this case was fall in love with a male robot. ++ for that haha

Overall it's a very good buy for robot fanatics, but I'm afraid that may really be the only audience this can appeal to. I can't see myself suggesting this to anyone outside of that niche. So if you like them bots [strike](AND IF YOU ARE A DIRTY ROBOT FRICKER LIKE ME)[/strike], this is a great experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070758018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1672704597}
review:
The next day, you take Beast to the range just outside Cyberia, hoping walking around one of its favorite kinds of places will cheer him up. Although Beast had been excited about the prospect of your becoming more machine-like at first, the possibility of your death during surgery seems to have sunk in. 

The idea that you may not always be around seems to have put Beast in a somewhat melancholy mood. "I'm not young anymore, either, Creator," Beast says. "You might not think of me as aging, but technology ages even faster than people. I look just old and clunky compared to the robots around us. When you built me, people would throw away their computers after just four years. Their phones, after two." 

"Nobody's going to throw you away," you assure Beast. 

"Without you, I'll probably stop working. Someday." Beast looks off into the distance. "If I die, Creator, do you think I will continue to exist after death in some form?" 

(Assuring him that he will live on through the impacts he's made on people.)

Beast looks troubled. "But the person whose life I changed the most was yours, Creator!" 

When you are gone, I will destory myself. Beast exclaims.


Pros: 
+ Branching storylines (Unlikely to get the same story/ending each time you run through.)
+ Can be the Hero, or the Villain. No forced direction.
+ Can bend your robots emotions and actions to your will, (Teach them Love, Hate, or how to be bloodthirsty killers.)
+ Take over Alaska
+ Building relationships in this game feels important, and how you say or act towards people affects how things play out.
+ Found myself thinking, well what I'm going to want to do probably wont be an option, but 100% of the time it was.
+Become Rich and Famous

Cons: 
- You haven't bought it already.


Overall: All I can say is WOW. Coming into this game I couldn't have imagined what I was heading into. This game has so much character and is very well made. This is my first text based choose your own adventure game that I've enjoyed this much. Who knew that a text based game, could make you feel anger, sadness, love, happiness and power about the decisions you made in it without having actually seen it...? Well this game corrected my ignorance. You will not be ready for it, I can assure you.
This is not something that ANYONE should pass up. FeelTrips throughout. Definitely keeping my eyes open for any future projects Kevin Gold and Choice of Games will be working on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005931111', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1640812136}
review:
This game grabs your hand and whispers "run". It is almost impossible to stop in the middle of a playthrough, and there is always that "just one more time" feeling when you end it.
It contains beuatiful, emotional stories, and stories of war and destruction. You an be a hero or a villain. You can make so many choices that change how the world will be when (if) you leave it.

This game is my most replayed game. a Playthrough takes some hours the first time, and a bit less after that, as some of the choice screens are resued - but with different outcomes.
It is a very fun game to simply play through and see what happens, but also to go about with a  goal in mind - things don't always work out as you think they will, and some choices, while furthering your goal shortterm may harm you long term, and vice versa.
The game encourages deep thought and raises existential questions if you choose to play "as yourself", as well as if you choose to head for a goal.
You get to know the characters more and more on each successive playthrough - not all characters will be in every game, and some you may not meet at all.

All in all, very positive, very recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044735557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1452138829}
review:
I swore that I would use my robots for the betterment of mankind, and never for military purposes. That they would be doctors, nurses, factory workers, anything any everything but weapons of war.

Then the War came.
And I turned my back on the morals I had set for my self.

I made humanoid robot soilders, and made them smart. Intelligent. They had the same sense of right and wrong I had... or, at least I used to have.
They were told to nuke large cities.
They refused, and set the nukes off in the Gobi Desert, saraficing them selfs to uphold the morals I had set for them. They even made a video for me.

The nukes made the chinese surrender, in fear of extermination.
I was declared a war hero.

I don't feel like a hero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086457357', 'num_games_owned': 1222, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1490985201}
review:
A choice of robots

This "interactive novel" is a work of art and love... I recommend its reading for everybody and especially so for sci-fi minded people and for all who're interested in artificial intelligence and robotics.

I was interested in the theme of this game / interactive book from the start but I postponed its reading with false arguments (which basically boiled down to this one : "why read a game that may not be so well-written when there are so many sci-fi books around, books which probably have better characters, plot and structure? i.e. : if I want a book, I should take a book.") And I was wrong. Because the writing of this game is much better than most books I've read. The plot has surprises and several turning points. The characters are interesting and/or endearing. The main theme is very well addressed, and there are lots of secondary themes that are well developed as well. In fact this isn't just good, this is great.

In addition to all these qualities, the author seems to be very erudite in many fields (or has good counselors and took the time to listen to them). In addition to computer science and robotics, this book consistently makes reference to both popular sci-fi culture (Isaac Asimov, Lois McMaster Bujold, and many others, ...) ; and to the classical culture (Shakespeare, Marc Aurelius' meditations, Buddhist tales, and many others, ...). There are even a few fun references to popular videogames and their subculture that are well timed and well phrased as well...

Political issues and strategic outcomes seems to be thought out with lots of intelligence and a surprising finesse. I'm truly impressed by this work, now!

The endings seems to be widely divergent (though I've not explored them all yet), and this book seems to have been written with love and lots of attention to detail. I've finished the story a first time, then a second time with a very similar path with just a few variations, now I'm trying to test a different approach to see what happens...

TL;DR -> Score: 9.8/10. Read it / play it. Now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990521402', 'num_games_owned': 2736, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1556741546}
review:
This game was the most amazing voyage I have ever taken. I have lots of games, spanning the decades, but none have ever blown me away, not like this.

You have choices in this and maybe it's personal to my character but there was always a choice I would most definitely make. I had played old Choose you Own Adventure books but I was always another person making another persons choices, in this I felt I was living a tangent life, both fully in control and never quite.

I've only done one play through but it was perfect for me, I will go back and try another one later but for now shall enjoy this singular experience a little while longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025126106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1451834876}
review:
I'm reluctant to write this review, but even at a sale price, I'm not sure this game was worth the money.

This choose-your-own-adventure text game starts with an interesting setting and gives you some interesting options for a psychological subplot while you go through the main storyline. You have a decent amount of control about the type of robot(s) you will build, and what kind of business or other ventures you will engage in. However, the interactions with other characters are somewhat limited, and become increasingly detached as the story leaps ahead years from page to page. If you've traded your humanity for success, that's a plausible enough story mechanism, but if you're doing a more "humane" run-through, it takes away from the immersion. Overall the last half or one-third of the story feels rushed, and even though the scope of the story is usually quite grand by that point, I found myself uninterested in it.

The writing in this story is tolerable, but not particularly good. What breaks the game for me, however, are the continiuty errors. For example, in one play-through, your lover ends up disappearing, causing you great emotional distress. Then, a few sections later, in a passing line, the story notes that this same lover has left you because of a particular political choice you made. Nowhere was it mentioned that the lost love returned safely, so it makes zero sense for them to have reappeared without explanation only to leave you again. This sort of continuity error takes away all value from the "choose your own adventure" aspect of the game and sadly makes me unable to recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163110745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1451772998}
review:
This game was beautiful. I'm so in love. The work and detail that went into this game is astonishing. Needless to say, I love both of my robots so much and I don't even know what they look like. I was so emotionally attached to them. 

I will also be looking into more games by Choice of Games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198170950013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1281, 'last_played': 1660974921}
review:
I was just trying to create a robot at the start.

I never thought I would spend so much time with her.
I never thought I would choose her over my friends.
I never thought I would treat her as a human.
I never thought how much I would consider her a lot more as a daughter than just a machine.
And I never thought she would return this feeling of love.

10/10 I would restart to do this all over again.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - -

EDIT (19.3 hours of total gameplay time later):

Lol, what did I just write up there.

So I spent around another 15+ hours or so on the game trying to get all the achievements and possible endings for it and I've seen a lot of more great story-paths aside from the get-all-close-and-emotional-with-your-robot-daughter plot.

One of my personal favorite story-paths when (and if) you get your robot to prevent the Sino-American War from happening and the events that eventally leads to, one of the many, many stories you can come up with in this game, like forging your own robot empire, marrying a robot, and even going to the moon.

The fact that this game has no visuals whatsoever does not bother me at all and it shouldn't bother you either. With whatever route you take for the story, the writing is excellent and there is always that subtle taste of humor somewhere mixed splendidly well with some moving moments. This aspect of the game is what makes Choice of Robots what Choice of Robots is. The game need not any visuals because the writing provides you what you have to see in your head.

The only real complaint I have with this game (and with most text-based CYOA games on Steam for that matter) is the user interface. Playing 7 hours straight on a game with a completely white background does not at all give you painful feelings that nearly make you believe your eyes are gonna blow up from their sockets Michael Bay-style (sarcasm intended). The developers should add the option to invert the colors if the user wishes to (from a white background with black text to a black background with white text).

Man, if making a robot were this easy, I would be making my Miku right now (then eventually get murdered by her in my sleep when she starts the Robot Revolution).

author: {'steamid': '76561198032329425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1436633622}
review:
Если Вы желаете начать знакомство с трудами "Choiсe of Games", остановитесь на "Выборе роботов". Она наиболее полно реализует то, за что, судя по названию, стоит команда разработчиков. Итак, причины купить "ВыРоб":
  1) Выбор имеет значение. Каждое Ваше решение повлечёт последствия. Или нет. Некоторые просто случаться и пройдут. Вот тут-то и начинается игра в кошки-мышки с судьбой. Стоит ли нахамить генералу ВВС США? Имеет ли смысл устраивать среди соседей ликбез по пользованию компьютером? Позволить ли своему роботу поиграть в "Dragon Age"? (Это не шутка, такое вправду может случиться). Ничего не произошло? Не расслабляйтесь: интернет-тролль, над которым вы прикололись вернётся через двадцать лет и пустит Вам пулю в лоб. Или нет. Альтернатива-с.
  2) Кaчество выбора. Тут нет бинарной борьбы добра со злом. Развилки, предлагаемые нам, ведут к разным последствиям, но их нельзя интерпретировать как "хорошие" или "плохие". Они послужат интересам разных людей или групп влияния и по-разному изменят Вашу судьбу (или судьбу сразу всей планеты), но простого ответа Вы не получите. 
  3) Равноправные финалы. Прежде всего, возможных развязок тут целая уйма. Но, что важнее: правите Вы миром железным кулаком или тихо живёте в съёмной квартире со своей робо-женой, не остаётся ощущения, что Вы выбрали не "настоящий" конец. Каждому завершению истории разработчики уделили внимание и развили его так, что он чувствуется полноценным. Не останется впечатления будто Вам не хватило очков на по-настоящему крутую развязку, на разработку которой ушли силы и время команды. Каждый финал - настоящий финал.
  За звание лучшей игры от "Choiсe of games" с "Выбором Роботов" в лучшем случае может поспорить одна-единственная новинка. Долгое время конкурентов и неё не было вовсе и для меня она по-прежнему камертон, по коему я выставляю оценки всем прочим играм студии.
Итог: 10 из 10.
Рецепт: в палату мер и весов, как эталон.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998156029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1451603206}
review:
Wow, what a fantastic journey. 

So much to love about this 'game', I followed my ideals and discovered the world sadly does not follow the same. Still, I lived through it all until the beautiful end. Feel as though I have lived another life, briefly.

A game where the graphics are only as good or bad as your imagination.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046214639', 'num_games_owned': 842, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1527197433}
review:
This game is a great exploration into the possibilities that AI could bring to our world.  The public mind often sees robots as only a threat, Terminator style.  But there are so many other ways in which robots could enrich our lives.

THis game is very minimal, only text and selection boxes.  I think that this is a great choice, as it allows the player to imagine their robots however they want.  It also forces them to concentrate on what is being said and how their choices will affect the world around them.  Without any save or back feature, every choice you make is important.

All in all, this is a great game.  I look forward to seeing what the different endings have in store.  I also plan to show this game to all my friends, to see how their lives and worlds turn out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114598153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1424214396}

author: {'steamid': '76561198170642545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1502198555}
review: This game is simple, but perfect for people who want an intruquing story to have fun with. It is one of the best Chose Your Own Story games I have ever played! Plus, It's about FREAKING ROBOTS!!!!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101956076', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1456024644}
review: This text-based game forces the player to constantly make many nail-biting decisions about morality, sentience, and humanity. With unintended consequences around every corner, I found myself playing again and again trying to get the exact outcome I wanted. The game has lots of room for ambiguous endings as well, and I am still haunted by the implications of my first playthrough. Most thought provoking choose-your-own adventure style game I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005503472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1451373808}
review:
With Annalia, I found love. With Basta, I betrayed humanity. And with Risa, I died happy.

Choice of Robots is well-written and presents characters you come to care about, urging you to explore the various choices to see what might have been had you refused one offer and gone with another, or just stayed home and tinkered. A surprisingly moving interactive novel, definetly worth it if reading doesn't scare you. Each run is a new adventure and delightful in the radical differences from one life to the next.

After the dissapointment that was Telltale's Game of Thrones, I'm glad to say Choice of Robots has me reinvested in the interactive novel genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053626382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1469134590}

author: {'steamid': '76561198218108364', 'num_games_owned': 29, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1451395709}

author: {'steamid': '76561198070646352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1569630576}
review:
If you like choose your own adventure books/games- this game is for you. (If you don't like reading, or robots, you probably shouldn't play this game) 

The story can go a surprisingly wide number of ways (this is not like CYOA books found in elementary school libraries) and has a little bit of stat management to keep things interesting. There are a ton of achievements also, and some of them are not the most intuitive to get, so there's a ton ton ton of replay value (I've played it 6ish times as of writing this review). The beginning of most playthroughs are the same, so you get a bit faster as you go and know what early game choices you want to make, but the middle and endgames are quite varied.

I always end up getting really attached to my little robots- even when they try to kill me I still love them.  

The writing is pretty good, the characters are interesting, and the choices you can make have a good spread between 'normal human decision' and 'absurd just for the hell of it' (with all variations in between as well).

Play this game, it's excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198232496076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1524176990}
review: As of writing this review, I have only played this game/novel once, though I intend to play it again. This is amazingly well written. The choices you make matter and it has so many. I recomended this to anyone who likes reading, making choices in video games, and doesn't hate robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012395761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1428606658}
review: This is as good as text-based "choose your own adventure" games can get. There is a HUGE amount of content, quality of writing is very good, you get a feeling that your choices really matter, and the story is both compelling and thought-provoking. I have rarely been this immersed by any game or story. An immense achievement by the writer, and a very enjoyable experience. Heartily recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116854643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1452383171}
review: This is the first text-based game I have played since my childhood and I am very fond of it.  More playthroughs are in my future. So many possibilities with this game. I developed a strong emotional attachment to the characters and very thoughtfully weighed the ethics of my decisions, often regretting things I did. I don't see any faults. It was well written and pulled me in like few games have. You should absolutely play this game if you don't mind reading. Took about 2 hours.

review: This is an amazing game, a wonderful story, and so much fun.  I am very much in love with all the places this story takes me, and I have played it at least a dozen times.  Even when you are working toward an ending you have found before slight changes int hey way you get there rewards you with text you didn't see last time. author: {'steamid': '76561198117861731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1460017771}
review: I've played through Choice of Robots about 3 times now, and each time has been a unique experience. I think I still have another round or 2 to go with this game to do all the stuff I want to try. Playing this game is like having a great sci-fi novel that's different everytime you read it, depending on what kind of adventure you feel like having. This is another strong 'Choice of games' game and makes me want to check out more of their stuff. Highly recommended for people who like this genre of game and robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064512958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1450557363}
review:
Got through my first run relatively well, but I think this was the highlight of the whole thing. x'D 

--- 

You feel lucky that robot technology has never been hotter, thanks to the ramp-up in robot technology in the last war. You're able to provide for both of your robots, thanks to the money you make from working for Josh. 

Puppet, the more adventurous of the two robots, appears to have tried more tastes than Springtrap already. Like siblings, they seem to have settled into niches in competing for your attention: Springtrap now tries to be more humanlike, while Puppet occasionally flaunts his freedom to be strange. 

"Did you try dirt?" Puppet asks Springtrap. He walks behind the younger robot, who is putting out plates. "Dirt tastes very interesting!" 

"I don't think people are supposed to eat dirt," Springtrap says uncertainly. 

"Sure they do!" Puppet says. "It's called 'pica,' and it helps people get essential vitamins and minerals. I read about it on the Internet." 

Springtrap gives you a worried look. "We're not going to eat dirt tonight, are we?" 

--- 

My face and gut hurt so much right now. x'D 

Even if text-based choose-your-own-adventure stories aren't your thing (and I've never met anyone who didn't at least entertain the idea), you'll still enjoy the little moments like these among the many different paths this story has. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038822286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1450240937}
review:
An interesting experience of how technology affect our lives and how it's changing and evolving in turn can change us. Our morals, our beliefs, etc. Circumstances change along with our technology, and just as our computers change and adapt to us, we adapt to them, raising a question of just how different we can be from each other. As robots come closer to being human, it also changes just what we think of as being necessary to claim to possess humanity. This game doles out some emotions, weighing relationships with humans against relationships with robots, and as the story progresses, it can be that you only know the robots are robots because the game reminds you of it.

I also had a three-way with a human and a robot 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197968154914', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1434838269}
review:
While often spoken of as one of the best Choice of Games titles, Choice of Robots is well worth the praise on the variety of choices and endings you do get by the end of it. While there are not thousands of different options I did feel like my playthrough was unique as no two of my friends ended up with the same exact endings. Choice of Robots is well written, funny and at times it knows where to poke at the tender bits of the heart, though in my opinion it does fall short due to it's raging hard-on for robots.

What can I say? I'm not a robot lover, at least not a LITERAL robot fellater.

At the end of the day Choice of Robots is a solid entry into the text adventure genre and it's one of those games that give the genre modern validity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152899150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1452872909}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001478665', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1449477076}
review:
There isn't enough game here to pay $5. There isn't even enough, if it were on sale for $1.

It's a branching path story game that decides what story to give you based on your alignment of a couple sliders. The choices are obvious as to which alignment they affect (building a metallic robot increases its military, and decreases its grace; giving it wings gives it grace and reduces its military usefulness). But, the story has to keep prompting you to interact with different parts of the decision tree, so you get weird things like being a multi-millionaire and choosing to employ humans in your factories in Detroit, but then you go to war with China, and now you're sorry you ever let the Chinese get near these things. What? When did the Chinese gain the ability to rip off my robots and make them militaristic? Oh, because I used cheap chinese lithium ion batteries? That's ridiculous. If my company is successful, and there's design changes happening, and materials are getting upgraded, let me source better batteries from somewhere else. Don't make me pick a motorcycle battery when my company is supremely profitable.

It's not open to be whatever you want it to be. You're allowed to type only on fields that don't matter: your name, your robot's name, your robots pronouns. You can't affect the story, you can affect the flavor text. If you choose one of the built in options you will rarely have a tie in back to the originator (Isaac Asimov names are one of the built in options, so you can get references back to those books in later dialogue if you themed correctly). But if you manually type in a name, Suddenly the game has nothing pithy to say about how your name and your situation relate back to the book.

It's not a very visually delighting game. Black text on a white background. Only one button is styled. The Next button. All other buttons are your OS' default look and feel. It's lazy design, and it hurts that it's not free.

The author chose to point out on every page of the UI that he is a Ph.D. which bears out my experience with most Ph.D.s. More concerned that everyone knows you spent a lot of time in school, than putting that knowledge to work. Good job on your Ph.D. now do work that isn't already bested by a group of people posting on free Choose Your Own Adventure forums.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068283915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1449654753}

author: {'steamid': '76561198130948719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1449629434}
review:
Played a few minutes, but don't think I will continue this one. I'm wanting an experience that thrusts me into a story and forces me to make decisions based on my reactions to the unfolding plot. Unfortunately, this game is not properly delivering.

I have two main gripes:

1) Too many of the choices read like quiz answers in fashion magazines, where instead of the answers just containing my possible actions, they also impute motivation into my character that may not reflect how I'm interpreting the situation. Made-up example: instead of the choices being "Cautiously open the door" or "Kick the door in", they are "Cautiously open the door, hoping nothing scary jumps out and eats my face," and "Kick the door in. I am a superhero, afraid of nothing!". (I may open the door cautiously because I'm a practical person, or kick it in hoping to surprise what is on the other side. A game should not tell me my emotional state; it should offer me simple, basic choices and allow me to feel my own emotions).

2) Some of the questions are not based on how I am reacting to the situation, but are asking me to make fundamental decisions about the nature of the story universe. While this is fine as a replayability device at the start of an interactive fiction game (e.g. "will you be a GOOD WITCH or a BAD WITCH"?), it's poor storytelling to force such decisions on the reader when they're already well into the plot. The question that I am quitting on is asking me who it was that just called my cell phone while I was speaking with a professor. Instead of the call being from a specific person and giving me a choice of actions (answer it, send to voicemail, etc) I'm supposed to decide who the call is from, choosing between three people I know. That's ripped away any immersion I had felt to that point and reminded me that I was a reader, not a participant.

review: I made some choices I wouldn't make twice, i have made some bad calls, but in the end, I was satisfied with that outcome and don't necessarily regret them. Great game, 10/10. gives all of the choices i would want and choices that matter. I don't play games like this often, but when I do, they are always a treat. (on a side note I actually think about stuff like this a lot, AI rights and stuff. and this game handles it perfectly, it gives you good choices for both sides of the argument and really makes you think. but even if you don't think about stuff like this like me, you will enjoy this. PS. I don't review things often but I am doing this right after my first play through, so let that show my satisfaction.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198122656243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1458018154}
review:
I purchased this game a while back; I saw the reviews and thought it would be an incredible game for the price. Little did I know that you can play this game for free on its website. 
     The game itself was exceedingly boring. There is nothing to it other than clicking the mouse. Yes, this game is filled with difficult decisions that make a difference in the game's outcome, but it just seems pointless. The end of the game yields no satisfaction. You don't get the feeling of "I just completed a game!". You read the last page presented to you, and then it gives you a link to the website nto try more of the developers' games.
     This game is just hours of sitting and reading text. There isn't any cool backround music or soundtrack; no pictures to help visualize the sometimes vague descriptions; just text.
     I would never recommend that anyone purchase this game, ecspecially seeing as how it can be played for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044026880', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1035, 'last_played': 1599872871}
review:
It's been years since I first placed this, as a teenager just looking for action in my books. But now as an adult and truly seeing what this has to offer I'm floored by the experience as a whole.

I only completed it once, with War, when I first got the game years ago.
This time coming back to it after so long I chose to be balanced and just make the choices I'd truly make. 
And by the time the game ended I found true sadness in the chance at loss and how my creation felt at each turn, as well as true joy at surviving and the happiness my creation felt becoming a parent and seeing my live. 

This isn't just a good game, but a good book and I loved it. Highly recommend it for those who want games where choices truly matter. Either they be violent ones or peaceful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068589143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1448929261}
review: This game was honestly one of the better decisions of made in life with respect to gaming. Its depth in story made me feel like my decisions really mattered and i was building a future for myself and all of humanity (with a robotic companion to boot (; ) I recommend this game to any person that takes their decisions in game seriously and sees it as a temperory extention to their own life. I found myself being asked deep philosophical questions that made me sit for a moment and ponder what life was really about. I cannot recommend this game enough. I have only played one branch of the many that i could have played and intend to explore this game further. Do yourself a favor if you take game decisions seriously and spend the money that would be needed to purchase a mcdonalds happy meal and by this beautiful game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038864953', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1448922954}

review: It's a nice change to see a great text based RPG on steam. Delve into the world of a mad scientist creating the first intelligent robot. A choose your own story game with vast amounts of replayability and hidden gems. Will you be good or evil? Smart or crude? Democratic or Fascist? This world is yours to create.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032189937', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1449107449}
review:
Wow... I'm not a text based gamer at all in the least bit, but this is one of the most astounding games I have ever played. Most books I have read never made me feel the way I did as this. This "interactive book" will really make you question the things you believe in irl.

Also, the 4th wall is breakable.

'"And I'm sure the good people at Choice of Games have some kind of good ending for playing a very effective psychopath," Elly says. "For some definition of 'good.' But you can count me out of that ending." Elly picks up her things and leaves through the hole you broke in the fourth wall.'

10/10 would make characters leave via holes in the 4th wall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054919678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1420025081}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012221863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1463396764}
review:
Okay, a text based CYOA set in a (still) possible near future involving robots. If I say more on the contents then that will be a spoiler, so I'll refrain from doing so. 

What I can and will tell you though is that unlike other CYOA's of similar design this one is very... call it expansive. You really do feel like you areable to explore different branching storylines rather than ye standard three ending routes that many others seem plagued by. The sci-fi bits are extrapolated from current tech, so they are credible enough. Be aware though that it still manages to get bat-guano crazy here and there, but at the time of writing the review I'd say that if you want to try a good CYOA, this is the cream of the crop on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198230799568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1483127647}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069671296', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1562778386}

author: {'steamid': '76561198056044335', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1638173977}
review:
This game has given me multitudes of ideas. One, because I'm an artist this has fueled me up to create a portait of my robot, the characters in my imagination, and to create more bizzare creations. Two, as a robotics engineer student. I now have many ideas and clues as to what my next project will be.

Maybe, one day... I could build the robot I built in this game. That brings me joy.

(The robot I constructed looks, acts, and responds as a human would. They have a high empathy, grace and autonomy with empathy being the highest. Just trying to create a world where people accept our silicon relatives more or less as one of us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253793207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1500965626}
review:
looked into this cause I searched "gay" and i was like, oh man, gay and robots? I am Very about both of those things. Went into it for amusement, came out with significantly more tears than I expected.. and I didn't even get a bad end lol.. I really enjoyed the game, 

I have mixed feelings about not being able to change any choices at all. for instance, choosing something that cut down Empathy, which i was trying to build. But at the same time, I really like the reality that it added to the game. That if I messed up, I friggin messed up and there was no fixing it unless I started over from the beginning. Though I believe that a chapter based savng system could have been nice, (i.e: if you mess up you can restart from the beginning of X chapter instead of the beginning) overall it was a nice change of pace from other games i've played where you have the option to fix things and stuff. 

I think the level of consequence in the game is great too. It really made me think about the decisions I was making and how they would affect my robots but also the people around me. And I especially love the little "moments of clearity" you get later on as the reader. without spoiling it, I loved when I realized near the end that I could have researched something way earlier on and possibly been better off for it :P

tldr: the game hurts but it's a good hurt, I totally recomend the game to anyone who likes "choose ur own adventure" type things, robot drama, or is a robophile (lol), and I'll def be on the look out for new games from this group

author: {'steamid': '76561198128598681', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1827, 'last_played': 1464340082}

author: {'steamid': '76561198186793530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1450411200}
review: It's an amazing game and I'd highly reccomend playing this at least a few times, with my two only complaints being while designing your robot, you have no clue what you're trying to achieve, and during the endings, things kind of rushed to conclude (At least the two endings I got did), so I really wasnt able to do everything I wanted to. Now, despite these things, while you may not feel really attached to the characters present, you still get really interested in your character and what you could potentially become. I thuroughly enjoyed this game/book.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171088395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1449015166}
review:
Very good writing, quite interesting scripting. Totally worth its cost.
You can't save during a playthrough, it might seem annoying at first because it means if you have to close the game before you're finished, you'll have to quickly go through all the paragraphs and choices again, but it's quick enough to be only a minor annoyance and the innability to backtrack/reload on a choice really helps the immersion and involvement.
You know you've hit a sweet spot when even just naming the protagonists seem to have importance and relevance.

10/10, had to replay it twice right after reading it the first time, and i know i'll read it again with pleasure.

review:
Started out the game with a nice robot. For some reason decided to become an evil robotic overlord.
Conquered China with giant robots. Giant robots proceeded to revolt and try to kill me. Somehow was not destroyed by my own perfect death-machines. [spoiler]I then made a perfect copy of my conciousness and implanted it in one of my robots. 10/10 Would become a robot again.[/spoiler]

EDIT: Was playing through it again and I found a section in which the author trashes Civ V and beyond, saying that the last good one was Civ IV: Beyond the Sword. I resent that. I like Civ V...

author: {'steamid': '76561198069532174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1447074496}
review:
Holy hell. This was a lot heavier, narrative-wise, than I thought it would be. Damn. Do you like science fiction novels? Do you like games that let you make your own decisions? then you'll love this. It's been a long time since I looked at a choose your own adventure, and this was damn good. 

I suppose the only thing I'd like is a back button, or an option to enable a back button, mostly because sometimes you can misread the text or confuse the intention of the words. Also, the summary you receive at the end saying what you did was a little confusing in some parts, it said things I didn't think I'd chosen. 

I feel super conflicted about some of the choices, but I'm guessing that was the intent? Anyway, this was a fun hour and a half. Definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113235472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1460180227}

First time playing a CYOA game. Got married to a robot girl, had a robot daughter, happy ending

Emotional rollercoaster, that much is true.

Considering the replay value, 5 bucks is worth it. Get some good music in the background and play through it a few time. Worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009800914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1578078661}
review:
I have played a few of these Choice games, including Champion of The Gods and Choice of the Deathless. Choice of Robots is by far the best one of the lot. Detail. Reactivity. Replayability. Maturity. Heart. Robots is superior to every other interactive novel out there in every way, and I don't feel that is an exaggeration.

In Choice of Robots, you make a robot. Surprise. You determine its appearance, materials, power source, and ultimately influence its personality (though not entirely). As you guide your "young" robot through the strange customs and idiosynchrasies of modern human life, the manner in which you teach your robot about the world and its place within it will have repercussions in future events.

I have played through this a total of four times, and each time, the ending I received was COMPLETELY DIFFERENT. Not only that, the game achieves the apex of interactive novel aspirations, in that it succeeds in making you feel like the ending you got was the "real" ending. In all of my playthroughs, I felt nothing less than total satisfaction with the ending. And in one, special playthrough, I came within a diode's width of choking up from the feels.

The game has a healthy amount of differing statistics, and these are CONSTANTLY increasing, decreasing and being tested depending on the choices you make. There is an excellent balance of player-determined and statistic-determined story changes, giving you enough autonomy to guide the story in the direction you want it to go, but not so much that it breaks the fourth wall and makes you feel like a bored author.

There is a reason this game has 99% positive reviews. Why not go find out?

author: {'steamid': '76561198032090191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1446955816}
review:
Makes an asshole robot.
Kicked out of school.
Fails at business.
Moves in with mom.
Starts war with china.
Asshole robot kills me.

9/10 Simulates real life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073666085', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1479670247}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042678308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1449522041}
review: This game is beautifully written, with simple, pleasant graphics, and a tremendous narrative!

author: {'steamid': '76561198220378097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1529334984}
review:
At the time of writing this, I have only completed one playthrough. One could say that, yes, this review is a bit premature. And I would agree, to an extent. Still, let me just say that it is...

BLOODY AMAZING! 8D

I knew from the very start that I wanted to end up in a relationship with a robot. There were some definite missteps along the way, but I did eventually achieve it. I literally squealed with happiness when I got that to happen.

And I cannot wait to play it again. There are over 70 achievements, due to the variety of outcomes resulting from your choices. If you like a game that is story-driven, where 'choices matter', and you enjoying reading/are a reader, then this is a game for you. Be aware that there are no graphics whatsoever; it's just words in a plain white GUI with multiple choice options popping up constantly for you to decide the direction of the story. If you already are one who enjoys reading, you will most likely come in with a reader's practiced imagination and this will not deter you in the slightest.

GET IT GET IT GET IT!

Edit: At the time of this edit, I've probably done about 6 or 7 playthroughs, and had a blast each time.

I can't stop. Send help. Preferably robots. Helpful robots that I can hug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064683890', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1586469639}
review:
learned how to cook a steak 10/10

seriously though
this game has endless replay value just to see every single combination
with a great amount of cause and effect.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990762527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1479691698}
review:
After being burnt out on FPS games, and having a bit of extra money, I decided to pick up this little gem of a "game." 

This is a text based, choose your own adventure style novel. The writing is fantastic, every choice matters and there is a lot of room for replayability/re-readability(?) Highly recommended if you are fascinated by futurism or transhumanism.

review: every time i'm scrolling through my games and i see this i get a pang of nostalgia and sadness, i remember this. it's a beutiful, tragic story of you building the first AI, and then the story branches into like a couple dozen different paths on what you want to do with it. we fell in love, ran away to ireland and grew old together. i still think about it sometimes even though it's been 8 fucking years. this game had a profound effect on my child brain and i'm glad i played it

author: {'steamid': '76561198032975358', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1456052817}
review:
Really amazing experience, My route was interesting.

***KINDA SPOILER***(maybe?)

Made robot, refused to use for military-get fired(sorta)
Start company in alaska making co pilot cars with full robot staff
Make money, get tech stolen from, get place blown up by jerk.
Refuse politician, they become president starts a war with china.(cough..trump...couph)
Make weapons for USA to make a living (woot war profits!)
FBI came to house due to a lie on clearance. tried to get them away and protect friend. (negotiation fail)Robot kicks feds butt.
Take smart car that breaks for the rules for me goes to canada now making medical robots.
War ends, procceed to making a robot that can be a life partner.
First robot now surrogate daughter, have a stroke.
Decide to make robot clone, clone goes off to be the hero.
I stay home no more stress.
Live to game another day.

Only downside is trying to play again after such a great first go.

Two peas in a pod, we were. inseparable. Before I died I transferred all my memories and conscious thoughts into an android designed to look just like me. Jbonez and Killbot 4eva.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135103641', 'num_games_owned': 1190, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1567677208}
review:
[h1] Игра афигенна![/h1]
Игра стоит внимания тех, кто любит использовать свое воображение, кто любит роботов и кто знает английский) А для тех кто не знает английский , но хочет его подтянуть( моя ситуация) эта интерактивная книга подходит идеально. Я потратил 13,5 часов на получение 1ой концовки , читая со словариком, и к концу чтения он мне практически был не нужен.
[h1] Сама история -	[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198103438308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1498134851}
review:
I think this is the best choices-matter, story-branching, multiple-choice, you-can-make-a-difference game I've ever encountered (so far).  It beats all the allegedly choice-driven games like Life is Strange, Tales from the Borderlands, assorted Bioware games, Alpha Protocol, Arcanum etc. 

There are multiple ways of solving problems, or avoiding them . . . and even failing to solve them is not the end (most of the time), bringing on more plot turns and twists. Some outcomes seem either unobtainable or inexplicable, but become completely logical in retrospect once you think about them. There are few to no situation where I felt that a choice was missing, unlike many other branching games. 

At first I felt that the 'no graphics; powered by imagination' bit in the sales pitch was cheesy, but after playing through for 5-7 times, I can say that that line was absolutely deserved: the game provides something that big-budget ultra-HD failed to provide to this day, even games from lines which are allegedly known for great stories. 

I want to see more games by Kevin Gold. I also think big companies should consider putting hiring and putting Kevin in charge of making stories for their games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036160932', 'num_games_owned': 567, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1445493026}
review:
Прекрасная игра. Или, лучше сказать, великолепная книга?

Первый раз я просидел за игрой 6 часов почти без перерывов. Это действительно увлекательное приключение с множеством концовок. Более того, складывается ощущение, что вариантов развития сюжета здесь в десятки раз больше, чем в том же Mass Effect 3.

В конце я выкинул из дома свою органическую жену и женился на роботе своей мечты.

И хочу отметить, что за шесть часов я получил всего 15% достижений... что как бы намекает, что эту игру можно пройти несколько раз, причем без пересечений с прошлыми прохождениями.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121522458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1459600957}
review:

A couple of years later i conquered Alaska with my war robots which have grenade launchers strapped to their arms.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030720390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1433801595}
review: I love text games, its a lost art. And Choice of Robots brings some art, some real storytelling back to it. You make choices here, lots of them, and its not always obvious which ones you should make, its got adult sort of morally ambiguous events as you follow the life arc of the protaganist, guiding or misguiding his or her decisions. Its got /some/ replay value, but you basically try and make better choices than the last play through. Still, for the work and the good plot line, I have to reccomend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 592, 'playtime_forever': 1982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1450466669}
review:
Choice of robots, décidément ces temps-ci je rédige beaucoup d'éval sur des jeux qui sont dans la veine d'un "livre dont vous êtes le héros".

Ici nous incarnons donc un ou une héroïne, ayant un background différent, créeant un robot différents à chaques parties. Les occassions de perdre sont assez peu nombreuses mais les développements et les fins elle le sont bien plus.

Il s'agira principalement de faire les bons choix au bons moments, quitte à recommencer une partie du début, puisqu'il n'y a pas de fonction de sauvegarde classiques, afin de réparer une erreur.

L'histoire est vraiment sympa et c'est assez amusant de voir les différents développements, comme par exemple cette fois où mon robot me dit qu'il à fait un millier d'headshot dans un jeu et que les gens l'on traité de bot, et quand il a confirmé personne n'a voulu le croire. Ca m'a bien fait rire :)

Il est vraiment dommage que le jeu ne soit pas en FR mais seulement en anglais ça ferme la porte à de nombreuses personnes n'ayant pas un bon degré dans cette langue surtout que avouons-le, vous ne POUVEZ pas jouer à un jeu consistant à lire des milliers de lignes de textes dans une langue que vous ne comprenez pas avec comme support google trad. Je n'imagine pas le temps que ça prendrai de tout traduire dans chaque langues, ni le travail de titan que ça représenterai, mais en tout cas ça vaudrait peut-être le coup. Avis au développeur si jamais il souhaite permettre à des moddeurs de faire tout le boulot à sa place ;)

Je vous recommande donc énormément ce jeu :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197962296785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1558790434}
review:
I've played three of the "Choice of.." games and this definitely was equally enjoyable, and seemed like the most content-rich  of all of them! Just looking at some of the achievements, it's astounding how many paths it looks like I could have taken. I don't want to spoil anything, but I'll just say I lived a pretty unspectacular and difficult life, yet still had a great heartwarming story and a happy ending.
Choice of Games are a must for anyone who grew up reading "Choose Your Own Adventure" style books. The creators take that base idea and take advantage of technology to make a much more interesting and uniquely interactive story experience. I highly recommend this on computer or a tablet for a great interactive novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025153924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1687520044}
review:
At first I was skeptical about buying a visual novel for $5 but the review rating pushed me to try it. OUTSTANDING! I highly would recomend this to neraly anyone. The writing was quality, story was great! I really felt as though my choices mattered and lead me to a unique crafted story. 5 outta 5 

Below is the summary of my entire first game which took me 4 hours. The entire thing is a giant spoiler if you have not played yet! But I figured I'd post it for those of you who have :)

[spoiler]Summary of Completed Chapters 

Chapter 1 

On the day you first built Ariel, you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make Ariel more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a wooden winged robot with a humanlike head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach Ariel some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up Ariel's biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then took Ariel to see Josh, who was impressed and agreed to fund your education if you would work for him after you graduated. Josh told you that evening about how he'd once been a juvenile delinquent, essentially, but turned around because he was inspired by Asmiov's book I, Robot to make a robot company called "U.S. Robots." 

As months passed, you became busy teaching Ariel about the world through the Internet and taking her to the park. Your funding from U.S. Robots kept you in Professor Ziegler's good graces during this time. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about Ariel and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview Ariel. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and Ariel. When Professor Ziegler found out about the article, he was very displeased, and finally kicked you out of his lab. 

Mark's article also attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Silas Cooper. When you met up over coffee, he told you that he used to do classified robotics work for a government lab, but left because he couldn't tell what nefarious purpose the technology would be used for. 

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. But they were unimpressed with Ariel. You couldn't find any other interested companies, either, and you eventually went bankrupt. Unemployment seemed to be common in the United States, and it seemed people tended to blame either robots or China. Riding on both of these sentiments, Jacqueline Irons won the presidency. After President Irons enacted a series of protectionist tariffs to keep out Chinese robots, Sino-American relations steadily worsened. 

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. But you refused. 

Silas was worried that he was being targeted by the government's anti-spy measures, and asked you to help him. But you weren't very helpful. 

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. Elly was captured and incarcerated as a result. 

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of Ariel V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot. 

In the end, America muddled its way through the war relatively unscathed. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named Galatea, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed Galatea was interested romantically in you. When Ariel and Galatea were attacked in the street, Galatea accidentally killed someone. Galatea was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences. 

In a last-minute attempt to find a life partner, you proposed to Galatea. And, what do you know -- it worked! 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to surprise your mother with a gift for the holidays. You learned it was your surgical technology that had kept her alive this long. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

You chose to replace the malfunctioning part of your brain with an artificial neural network. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Ariel 2, Ariel's artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more. [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198006990239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1584919693}
review: Normally when I purchase a game it's so that i can "physically" run around in the game and discover it's story line and how the AI fit into it with their backstories. However, with this game, even though i can't run around in the game world this creates the best storyline I have ever played because I get to decide where it goes and what happens to the "AI". With every playthrough you discover underlying meanings of life as you would define it (as well as if you're and asshole or not haha). BY FAR, one of the greatest games I have ever played even though it was all reading. I was skeptical at first but now.....now this game is in my top 3 favorites out of everything i've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179129909', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1554083260}
review:
I have no regrets on spending my money on this.

As you might know already, this hasn't pictures or audio, it's all left to your imagination. However, the narrative itself is so immersive you have no problem imagining everything. The world, characters and events are completely relatable. The choices can really screw you up if you just act recklessly.

Even tho the initial choices are somewhat minor, like "Should I date the person I like or finish my homework?", they start scaling into more serious, threatening stuff as the story goes

There were times where I really regret what I picked, and this only makes me want to play the game more, since I want to know what I could have changed.

If you like reading or telltale games, pick this. Darn, even if you don't enjoy those type of games pick this anyways, it might make you love them. This is deffinitely a MUST BUY title for any Steam user.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971948490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 7830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4493, 'last_played': 1569292321}
review:
It made me seriously think.  

I don't play too many extremely narrative-heavy games, as I really prefer emergent gameplay sandboxes, but the concepts of robot ethics in this game drew me in, and had me seriously weighing the choices, asking me which of three or four things I valued most highly.  

There are four major robot attributes, and four general paths for robots based upon them, from robot revolution to lovebots.  

On the negative, however, the writing vacillates between clever and overly sparse.  Some of the romances in particular feel overly rushed to "get to the good parts", and involve little more than direct options of "make this person boy/girlfriend?" "yes" "YOU ARE NOW DATING!" Maintaining it is mainly a matter of "I will dislike you if you make choices related to specific topic I am focused upon", such as Elly's humanitarianism, or Tammy's paranoia about the government.  

The character that is overwhelmingly the most focused-upon, besides your own, however, is the one character you can't date, your prototype robot.  You can get her to love you and spend forever with her, but even making love-bots mainly means creating a new character to be a "younger sibling" that has far less development.  

Likewise, in spite of the fact that your romantic interest could be there at "birth" for your robot, your robot considering you "father"/"mother", and your romantic interest actively being involved in remodeling your robot, there is almost no interaction between your robot and your romantic interest.  (I.E. If I'm "father", why is Elly not "mother"? Why doesn't Elly try to impress some of her humanitarianism upon the robot? She instead chooses to just sit back and judge the way you raise the robot all by yourself.)

That said, however, it's dirt cheap, and I seriously stayed up all night just mulling over what it was telling me, trying to puzzle out the right answers, or else trying to find some way to wiggle through the requirements, and find a way to get everything (or at least, a greater share of what) I wanted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123098058', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1618160875}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069650835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1682395943}
review: A beautifully told novel with incredible amounts of interactive and story-driven choices. Hands down one of the best experiences in a video game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036626615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1467345943}
review:
So... I had a robot daughter, fell in love, encouraged robot rights, and put a chip in my brain. Great story over a couple hours, easily worth a couple bucks.

New game: I had another daughter; This time I was a bit of a hippie... wanted humans and robots to coexist in every regard, both getting jobs and romance. Ended up having a threeway with a longtime girlfriend and robot companion, ended up breaking up with the human, got married to Robo-Waifu and became a robot myself, killing my biological body.

New Game: I became a mad scientist who brought about an age of robotic overlords, who I thankfully made benevolent. My 'son' Gadget was far from empathetic. Though I brought him around to understanding that all life is precious in the end. Regardless of fleshy bits or silicon; This unit has a soul.

That was 5 hours of gameplay and i've easily got my moneys worth; this is a CYOA adventure novel with very little gameplay mechanics... I've only been taking the more selfless paths available, there are plenty more! Easily one of the best CYOA games i've ever played, you won't regret buying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021782507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1444209903}
