author: {'steamid': '76561198032392151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1595291085}
review:
Великолепная игра, если вы хоть чуть чуть знаете английский. Игроку предстоит пройти жизненный путь  начиная от студента-старшекурсника, сделавшего робота. Проникнитесь духом кремниевой долины, смело используйте свой инжинерный талант, преодолейте препятствия и станьите успешным!
Вся жизнь зависит от решений, которые вы примете и исторических событий, которые меняют знакомый нам мир. Как вы отреагируете на них, сможете ли вы пройти через них не сломав свою жизнь, в которой вы еще вчера были на коне, одной ошибкой? А может быть даже сумеете изменть ход истории?

author: {'steamid': '76561198013658816', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1419993101}
review: My least favorite Choice game. It just didn't feel like anything made a difference.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995211768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1571191630}
review:
I hardly ever, ever, ever write reviews. It's true, you can check. So when I write a review for a game you should take into account that it hit me that hard.

This is a book. A CYOA (Choose your own adventure) book. Albeit a complex and much more complicated one.
If you are not a fan of reading long scripts of text for 1-3 hours (Took me 2.4 hours my first run) then that's alright, but I would still encourage this.

This game accomplishes something that most sandboxes and games that "emphasize story" have barely come close to doing; making your choice matter. This isn't a case where the story is the same with minor differences from your choice, but a real evolving adventure. One tale could have you create Skynet and cause the end of humanity. You could create the new iPhone-esque style robots with a company. You can conquer the world with a robot army. You can forgo the world and all people and create a robot child of your own to raise peacefully. You can live, love, fight, squander, become rich, become poor, become ill, overcome obstacles, and more.

If there was a way I could hit that recommend button multiple times I would, but for now just settle with a thumbs up.

In simpler terms, 10/10 I would find love and make a family once more, and prove my humanity still.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070317841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1149, 'last_played': 1443664081}
review: AMAZING game, very beautifully written, everyone should try playing it, very indepth interactions take you on a life long journey and put you in interesting positions of power and subordination. Sometimes game can be too easy as there isnt much threat of death, but there are other factors that define very well what the outcome may be. 8-9/10, would play more games from this company.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964432985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1524073691}
review:
How does one live with one's self after inadvertently starting World War III? This was a question I often asked myself while sitting in isolation at a military prison in the Caribbean. At least it was quiet there, and I was finally left alone with my thoughts. 

Every choice we make has unforseen consequences. Some good. Others bad. But then I guess it's just a matter of perspective. One person's "good" is another person's "bad". Many people died because of my actions. Or was it my inactions? But still, others profited from those deaths.

I lost my freedom while covering for a friend... all because she was into jazz music and gave me the one thing I looked forward to beyond my work in robotics.

And of course the robots. They were thrust into a world where many were not ready for them, while others sought to exploit them. In truth, I think I just wanted a friend. Someone to talk to. Someone to experience things with. Someone to be in awe with when something new is discovered. First it was one robot. Then I built another. I was not prepared for the responsibility that would be required, but I'd try to adapt. Later in life, I would learn that the responsibility for bringing robots into the world was very similar to raising your own biological children. The same rules applied, one choice at a time.

I've wined and dined with robots. I've danced with robots... I even broke a robot's heart.

Sometimes, I look back to earlier in life, and actually feel regret for hooking up those very first wires to control the gears and servos. But then I quickly find myself disgusted that I would even have that thought because of what good came out of those unfortunate events. Besides, why imagine possible paths to descisions I've already made? There are still secrets yet to be answered. (And some I'm not sure I want the answers to.)

No. I will move forward and be free. Despite the pain and uncertainty our choices may bring... what matters now is moving forward in the present, learning from the mistakes of the past, and plan for a future filled with peace and kindness.

A robot taught me that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990973838', 'num_games_owned': 1234, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 1336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1567842289}
review:
Let's write an actual real review instead of a joke one, shall we?

I personally hold Choice of Robots up as the gold standard of comparison for most ChoiceScript games, for a number of reasons.

1. Player agency. You'd be surprised how many "choose your own adventure" games suffer from a serious lack of player agency. You can choose how to say things, you can choose how to do things, but you can't really choose *what* to say or *what* to do; in other ChoiceScript games, the rails of the story are there, and all you can do is choose the color of the train you're on.

To continue with our train analogy, Choice of Robots offers you not only several different destinations to choose from, and it offers you not only choice in terms of the color of your train, but it also offers you several different paths to your destination (that can meet up and merge with one another, at times), several different models of train to ride, and even a choice in passengers for the train.

...okay, the train analogy is a bit silly, but the ultimate point is this: While no game can offer you absolute, ultimate freedom to do whatever you want to do, Choice of Robots offers you as much freedom as it possibly can within the confines of the ChoiceScript engine.

2. Consequence. Even in ChoiceScript games that *do* offer you a meaningful choice in the path(s) you take, very few of them come close to the way that Choice of Robots also offers *consequence* for the paths you take. For example, if you choose to make war robots for the United States during the Sino-American War, the Chinese government will send an assassin after you. Sometimes, these consequences can affect the entire scenario. If you stop a gunman from assassinating a politician, you'll have stopped the aforementioned Sino-American War in its tracks, causing Chapter 5 to be completely different than it would have been otherwise. You decided to form a cult around your robot in Chapter 4? In Chapter 7 they're still around, and you can choose to fund churches for them. You make a bad impression in a news story about your robot? A lunatic might try to bomb your house because he's afraid of what you might create in the future. Don't take this lunatic out after he bombs your house? Now he's bombing your robot factory, a chapter or two later.

The decisions you make *matter* in a fashion beyond just sort of having your way with the story; actions in Choice of Robots provoke reaction, and these reactions might not always be in your favor. 

3. Conciseness. Some ChoiceScript games will burden you with a dozen (or more!) skills, abilities, or other such categories to keep track of and attempt to balance with improvements over the course of the game. Some times, you won't even know what a particular skill is even good for until it shows up at one crucial point in the story. After all, how was I supposed to know I needed 100 points in paleoarchaeology to get the good ending?!

...okay, that's a bit of hyperbole, but the point still stands: In some ChoiceScript games, you spend more time mapping out the choices you need to get a specific balance of skill/ability points than you spend actually playing and enjoying the game. Some people might like that, I suppose, but I'm not one of them.

Choice of Robots, though, has exactly 5 stats to keep track of:

Military - Your robot's ability to fight.
Autonomy - Your robot's ability to self-manage.
Empathy - Your robot's ability to feel emotions and sympathize with others.
Grace - Your robot's manual dexterity/agility as well as their computational ability.
Humanity - How (dis)connected you are to other human being.

The first four are self-explanatory, and whenever your robot fails a check because it's lacking in a stat, the game describes it in such a way that you know exactly what you should improve upon if you want to succeed next time. Humanity is a bit less obvious, but it's also used in only a few places and, depending on the route you choose, can be completely disregarded altogether.

4. Speaking of the humanity stat, let's talk about a lack of judgmentality. Is that a word? It is now, I suppose.

As Dream-Robot Anubis says, the only one capable of judging you is yourself, and the game takes this idea to heart. Aside from a few snide quips here and there, the game virtually never offers moral judgment on you or your character. Other ChoiceScript games, of course, have five or ten different morality meters to tell you exactly what kind of person your character is. Aside from humanity, though, Choice of Robots has none. Want to commit cold-blooded murder against someone who sent you an insulting e-mail? Go right ahead. Want to talk to him over coffee and try to convince him you're a good person? That's okay, too. Want to conquer Alaska and commit mass war crimes in the process? Sure, the game is fine with that. Want to crush the early seeds of robot autonomy and keep them all as subservient drones? Yeah, let's do it!

Of course, performing these actions may or may not adjust your humanity stat - but, again, this isn't a *morality* stat so much as it's something of an *ability* stat, your ability to continue relating to other humans beings even as you dive head long into creating robots. Aside from that, you will never receive overt praise for doing the "right" thing, and you will never receive overt condemnation for doing the "wrong" thing; the game lets you play it as you want to play it, and never wags its finger at you.

Of course, Choice of Robots isn't an absolutely perfect game. It has a few things here and there that needle at me whenever I play it, but they are of little to no consequence up against how *fun* this game is to play. If you like ChoiceScript games, or if you simply like robots, AI, and similar things, then I highly recommend it.

9/10, if you'd like a rating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099808620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1595, 'last_played': 1443256498}
review: I have never felt the need to review a game before.  If you are reading this, if you are considering your purchase, you need to buy this game. Do yourself a favour; do all robo-umanity a favour - buy this game.

review:
Its a strange game where you get out as much as you emotionally invest into it. My first time playing I actually teared up. The next 2 or 3 I enjoyed roleplaying as different personality types. The next 5 times I was mainly trying to play the game as differently as possible to see more outcomes.

It is interesting and smart, it will make you think. 

It is very shor but worth a look if you enjoy A.I. related narratives and choose your own advcenture games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013529169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1283, 'last_played': 1439675141}
review:
Overall well written, engaging, and at times quite touching.

Occasionally, some of the text pieces don't seem to properly reflect past choices. However, I didn't notice these things on my first playthrough, but rather as I started experimenting with all the options and those instances were rare enough to not taint the enjoyable reading experience I had.

Recommended to anyone who likes / thinks they might like text adventures, or those Choose Your Own Adventure books many of us read as kids.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128960872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1528651381}
review:
A wonderful game. I played through it 3 times over the first couple days after purchasing it, and each play through was absolutely a completely different experience, and were all very much enjoyable. The depth and absurd number of options you have that, sometimes beyond what you could ever predict, seriously affect the story and, in turn, your future decisions and character interactions, is phenomenal. The story itself is interesting and mostly pretty compelling, keeping pace so you maintain interest, but slowing down enough for you to feel the impact of your decisions. Overall, a great game that everyone should play if they haven't already.

There should be an achievement for going to prison twice in one play-through lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053659236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1627298574}

author: {'steamid': '76561198037334790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1441825344}
review: I really like these choose your own path games. This one, for some reason sticks out, and I keep going back again and again to play it. I like that the main plot is focused on your interactions and not a whole huge combat scenario, though that is certainly possible. I guess what sets this game apart from others in the style, is that it does a great job of making your choices and decisions matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975633348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1439332312}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990126587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1442278951}
review:
Choice of Robots is thought-provoking. Choice of Robots is silly. It is harrowing, yet cute. It is just amazing.

A choose-your-own adventure style affair with simply great writing, exploring the nature of artificial intelligence and robotics and how one man's decisions can change the world,

A supremely satisfying narrative experience that I wholeheartedly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039754276', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1483347511}
review:
I played through this whole story in one sitting. What an emotional roller coaster. I'm eager to replay for a different ending.
If you like books and reading as well as robots, I would highly recommend this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198131551268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4, 'last_played': 1478314017}
review:
Upon first purchasing this item during a sale, I did not believe that I would get much enjoyment out of a "choose-your-own-adventure" ebook. However, once I finally started it up and began making decisions, I discovered a unique form of storytelling that has not only a lot of brains, but a lot of heart as well. And even though I did die most tragically the first try, I went back just to try the story over and over with wildly diferent choices. From making the war-winning military bots, to the human-killing rebellion robots, to a robot that was capable of understanding true human love, there was not a page that didn't leave  me wanting more. Not since reading Asimov has a tale of a person and a robot been so compelling and actually able to make me feel emotions for the characters.
00001010/00001010 Would reccomend to anyone who loves a good story or even just really likes robots (or both, like me).

author: {'steamid': '76561197998546381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1671255777}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019872184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1480, 'last_played': 1478971476}
review:
雖然遊戲是全英，很可能要一邊翻譯一邊玩，但這不會影響遊戲的樂趣。

根據不同選擇，機械人會不斷學習，而且路線很多，每次都有新驚喜！

如果想看英文小說，但一般小說對你而言太沉重，那可以試試Choice of Robots。

誠意推薦！ 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198008908085', 'num_games_owned': 627, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1441520342}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198113243534', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1561574651}
review:
This is a brilliant interactive piece of art, a game that is fueled by the most powerful engine in this entire world, and no, this is not my opinion, but a fact. The most powerful game engine, our imagination. 

There are a LOT of choices in this game, some had me pace around for a while, because they're that good! 
Of course, you will definitely dislike this game if you aren't into reading, so only venture into it if you're willing to read through, well, the entire thing. Otherwise there's no enjoyment to be had. 

There is a lot of replay value, as you can basically change up how you do things, and the choices have drastic impacts. 

It's just a joy, really. My time was well spent!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010355721', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1441096596}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007558486', 'num_games_owned': 1330, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1419903677}
review:
It would be difficult to ask more from this game. I can think of a couple of things, but the number of choices, consequences, depth and adventure is amazing for a textual game! 

The form based interface/gameplay is much more easy to use than having to type in commands.

Also, it makes it's convenient to play on touch devices. In fact, the only thing that I find a shame is that we can't play light Steam cloud based games remotely on android or iPhone. Because the 'Choice of' are best enjoyable to me when read / played on the go, on a portable device.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000485037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1443483532}
review: Well written Interactive Novel about AI and more specifically the ethics involved in its creation. I have only played through one possible scenario so far but I plan to dive right back in and explore the other paths. I found the story to be so enthralling I was not able to stop playing until I reached the conclusion. I am actually glad there are no illustrations to accompany the story. It allows the reader/player to use their own imagination. I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966873742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1440920485}
review:
I only finished one potential story and I can honestly say it was more than worth it.  I was intrigued and then captivated by the choices I had to make and the results that would come of them.  It also allowed me to make the choices I feel I would make in those situations; often with results I would expect, and occasional with results I could never foresee (just like in real life I suppose).

I would highly recommend this for anyone interested in a smart, interactive story involving Artificial Intelligence, the Singularity, and the ethical questions thereof.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016336089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1443112571}
review:
Note: minor spoilers included.

You are [pick a name], a robotic engineer destined for tough times, greatness, and death. So apply your imagination, and you will experience a wild and engaging life.

The literature is easy to follow and presents you with a large bank of options. Its world is believable and full of unexpected, yet very realistic, turns of events that are guided by each character's unique personality.

And though some characters may appear despicable during the first playthrough (I forced one, Mark, to commit suicide), each one's unique personality and background will emerge as you experiment with different options (As of my fifth playthrough, Mark has risen to be my favorite character). This game will make you second-guess yourself if you commit your emotions to it.

You may experience academic success or expulsion, career success or bankruptcy, triumph in war or defeat, friendship, romance, total control or love for a child, betrayal, several opportunities for vengeance, the death of a loved one, your own impending death, immortality, among other values. And by the end of the game, you may reflect on all that you sacrificed and be forced to re-evaluate each one's importance in your life.

Overall, I, a graphics worshipper who normally enjoy Assassin's Creed and Mortal Kombat, strongly recommend this non-graphic text-based journey. Who knows, it just might change your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008658923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1606343152}
review:
Simply beautiful.
I've only made one playthrough so far, but that's because I was emotionally so compromised I didn't dare a second attempt for a long time.
The written word is the one medium I deem to touch a mans most inner self and to move it to tears, which can happen in this novel just too easily, if you're even a little bit attached to your own creations.
It's not world-class writing (you're wrong here if you're looking for that), but it has not to be, it just has to tell you the outcome of your decisions and the reaction of your opponent, which it does marvelously. For the emotions and inner thoughts you are responsible yourself, and that should do a better job than every prefabricated reaction the author could ever present.

It's simple sure, but not shallow. Alea iacta est.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004148295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1441273610}
review:
Témata kolem umělé inteligence, syntetiků co nejvíce podobných člověku, robotů ovládajících svět lidí a podobně, nejsou ve sci-fi žánru nic vyjímečného a v posledních letech se zdají být čím dál tím populárnější, pochopitelně, protože jsou také s rozvíjejícími se technologiemi více aktuální.
 Jak už název prozrazuje, je to i případ hry [i]Choice of Robots[/i], jejíž příběh tato témata hluboce rozebírá.

 Hra je ve stylu klasických gamebooků, interaktivních příběhů, na kterých někteří z nás vyrůstali. V dnešní době to není nijak vzácný koncept, ale ve formě počítačových her je běžné, že autoři text obohatí i nějakou (ne nutně animovanou) grafikou či ilustracemi. Toto není ten případ, zde jde o opravdu defacto knihu v elektronické podobě s minimálním uživatelským rozhraním. Tady bych zmínil mou jedinou výtku k této hře a totiž, že jste odkázání pouze na bílé pozadí a černé písmo. Věřím, že pro někoho to může být problém, několikahodinové čtení za těchto podmínek na PC pro mě osobně nebylo ideální, samozřejmě není problém si třeba jas monitoru snížit, ale stejně mi příjde, že by neměl být pro vývojáře problém tam přidat i tmavější variantu.

Co se týče hry samotné, příběh pro vaši postavu začíná v roce 2019 na Stanfordské univerzitě, vašim oborem je (nepřekvapivě) robotika a blíží se moment, kdy započnete práci na vašem prvním prototypu robota s umělou inteligencí. Stejně jako vaši postavu, i robota si můžete pojmenovat a bude taky jen na vás, jak bude vypadat, jaký mu zvolíte hlavní účel a jakým směrem budete utvářet jeho osobnost. Budete chtít vytvořit robota, jehož mysl bude stejně chladná jako ocel, z které bude vyroben a který bude užitečný armádě (a vaší peněžence) a nebo snad postavu z ekologického dřeva, empatickou, co nejvíce podobnou člověku tělem i myslí, ze kterého může být výborný společník? Prvotní rozhodnutí při tvorbě prototypu budou důležité, nikoliv však definitivní. Robotovu osobnost a schopnosti můžete ovlivnit dalším vývojem, tréninkem, způsobem, jak s ním (či s ní) budete jednat a zacházet. 
 Příběh hry pokrývá až 40+ let, dle rozhodnutí, které během svého života uděláte. Tato rozhodnutí budou samozřejmě ovlivňovat i vztahy s lidmi kolem vás, z některých budou třeba vaši kolegové, kteří vám pomůžou ve vaší vlastní společnosti, kterou si později můžete založít, z jiných se mohou stát vaši rivalové nebo klidně životní partneři, pokud však nějaké lidské vztahy budou mít ve vašem životě vůbec místo. Jako průkopník ve svém oboru brzy zjistíte, že vaše výtvory mají vliv na celou lidskou společnost a dění ve světě. Co se stane pokud vyvinete dokonalé robotické dělníky, kteří vytlačí lidskou pracovní sílu? Jak ovlivní světový mír skutečnost, že se armádě dostanou do rukou vaše vraždící stroje? Jak se lidská společnost zachová ke skutečnosti, že se začnou množit případy, kdy lidé preferují za své společníky syntetiky namísto lidí?

 Nebudu zacházet dál a do nějakých podrobností, ať vám případně nezkazím překvapení. Každopádně vězte, že hra nabízí opravdu obrovské množství různých variací příběhu, důsledky vašich rozhodnutí se mohou projevit hned, někdy později či třeba až na konci hry.
 Pro jednodušší představu výše zmíněného si můžete povšimnout, že hra obsahuje 72 achievementů, každý z nich reprezentuje jakousi důležitou událost či vážný důsledek vašich rozhodnutí. A já jich při mé první hře získal 9, herní doba byla něco mezi 3 - 4 hodinami. Vždy to samozřejmě záleží na tom, jak si povedete, každopádně znovuhratelnost je u této hry obrovská.
 Vývoj vaší postavy (např. sláva, bohatství), stejně jako vývoj vašeho robota (autonomie, empatie) a vztahy s důležitými postavami, které jste ve svém příběhu potkali, pak můžete neustále sledovat na oddělené kartě se statistikami.
 Na závěr bych ještě dodal, že hra se ukládá automaticky po každé volbě, kterou uděláte. Nelze to tedy nijak ošidit, jak to bylo kdysi možné v papírových verzích :-) Se svými případnými špatnými rozhodnutími se musíte vypořádat, i to k životu patří a tento životní příběh člověka a robota je rozhodně zajímavý a hodný k prozkoumání.

[i]Pokud si budete chtít hru napřed vyzkoušet a získat ještě lepší představu, co můžete očekávat, na Steamu je k dispozici i demoverze.[/i]

review: Everything you could ever possibly want in a cyoa game though it has one con. No save. So if you somehow fuck up and game over out of the blue (Which I managed to do a total of 3 times) You have to start straight from the begining all over again. This game will make you laugh, make you cry, make you bloodthirsty, make you shameful. This game will change your view on robotics for life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993449279', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1653587986}
review:
I must say, first I was unsure if a entirely text based game / novel would be worth the money.
After playing it for some time and trying different options, exploring the alternatives, I must say that I thoroughly enjoy this Novel.

The writing is great, the story is thought through so that the story after your actions (the choices you pick) always is plausible and in tune with the character you decide to play as. The different choices really make the story change significantly and doesn't end in the same spot as after one of the other choices, so you will often discover something new as you make your way through the novel.

Granted the lack of anything "gamelike", illustrate, sound, only plain text and checkboxes. Can be a hurdle to decide if you want to spend your cash on it, but for me the story is fully worth getting this engaging and well written novel.

[spoiler] [Better than Mass Effect, because your choices really matter and change what you get at the end] [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198172289159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1439664693}
review: I found this quite boring after a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963535420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1440703889}
review:
Well worth the cost.  Finished my first playthru and found it very immersive and enjoyable:

+ Very challenging options to choose from.  Many are nicely written and are clear what route I'm taking.  It was simlarly difficult to stay on a singular path (militaristic? empathic?) because the other options were often enticing.
+ Emotional surprises will dislodge you from your goal, provided you're not a heartless bastard.

- Some sections, particularly toward the end, seem hastily written and imbalanced with the buildup from previous sections.  For example, I had six or seven steps throughout my hostile takeover of a region, to then lose this progression (due to previous choices) and "flee" within two more steps which ended in skipping ahead 10 years after my defeat.  I thought "That's it? I just threw in the towel?"
- Just a few inconsistencies, again toward the end.  Minor mistakes or fairly important details omitted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984246309', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1440556148}
review:
Rekindles my love of choose-your-own-adventure novels. A great little tale, with a wealth of options and outcomes.

Only complaint is that it would be nice to not have to start from scratch when I die, but all the same, it does encourage you to try alternate choices. 

Very well done!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037508443', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1442014778}
review:
If you are at all on the fence about pruchasing Choice of Robots, like I was, BUY IT.
If you feel that you may be somewhat interested in buying Choice of Robots, BUY IT.
If you believe that you might have even the slightest respect for text-based games, BUY IT.
If you have an imagination, BUY IT.
If you have ever read and enjoyed a book at any point in your life, BUY IT.
If you are a person with feelings and emotions, BUY IT.

IN GENERAL, JUST BUY THE GAME. YOU WON'T REGRET IT.

I could not be any more satisfied with this game. I paid 5$ for it and got a 30$ story tailored to my liking in return. The game is creative and fluid, no matter what path you choose to walk.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977320367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1441574565}
review:
Okay, so no, this isn't a game in the pixel, rendered model sense of the word. Now that's out of the way I'll tell you what I think. 

 This takes me back to the 80's when the Fighting Fantasy game books were hugely popular, where each paragraph ended with you having to make a choice how the story continues.There is no dice rolling in this one but you are faced with having to decide on the path your life takes as you progress through your career and world events that are stirring in the background. Decisions are not that complex but my interest was kept by the way the story unfolded and how relations grew or fell apart.

Even if you are just curious, try it and you maybe pleasantly suprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043647971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2409, 'last_played': 1699493016}
review: A very fun game for me one of the best purchases I have made in the last few months. in the last few days I've clocked over 42 hours of game play and seen well over 100+'paths' available as I close into the 100% mark on the achievements. on the first few runs it was easy to tell that this was the kind of game that I would be playing over and over again as I explore the ins and outs of the design process (and even with everything I've done I am still discovering new bots to test run). Definitely recommend this to those people out there that like customization or are fans of the 'choose your own ending' adventure books.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116796576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1440336265}
review:
"It's not who I am, but what I do that defines me."

I enjoy a good story, and this was no exception. 'Choice of Robots' is a text-driven tale based on the popular choose your own adventure genre, where your actions greatly impact the outcome of your fictional self. Because of this, some may not enjoy the experience, whether it reflected parts of them they weren't comfortable acknowledging or they simply weren't interested in reading such heavy dialogue. I am a fan of reading and because of this I easily became immersed within the futuristic world and its characters. 

In a game that prides itself on interpretation, 'Choice of Robots' delivers on an emotional level which not only provoked my interest in the people I met, but questioned my decisions whether I believed them to be morally just or not. If you want a text-based story about creating your own robot legacy, then I highly recommend this journey to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063035462', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1488346657}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028075955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1588462805}
review:
China invades US through Alaska, US Gov people tried to make me make robots for military after my successful robot workers.

I chose to design robots only for helpers for doctors and medical purpose, only cause my cute human wife robot-pacificst-supporter threaten to leave me if i stuck a gun on them, but boy did US get pissed off as we were losing to Chinese robotic miltary. 

Tried "Building Gundam-like walkers" for military.  (yes that is an actual choice in the game).  Wasted whole years and their funds.

Moved to Canada with what money i had left. Assassin broken into my house, held my wife as hostage, my first robot I (or you design since begining) moved in and saved my wife some how, but I took a bullet and died in her arms.

Moral of story, just build a robot waifu and just put a damn gun on your future robots for military.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015128628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1440274020}
review:
Choice of robots is  more of a novel than a game, but a good one at that. It had me hooked from start to finish as I made my choices throughout the story. Not every decision - by itself - changes the path you're heading down on, but if nothing else the next page of the story takes it into account.

If I were to give this game a score of 1-10 (5 is your average game), would be a of 7. Reason for the score is some pages felt a bit out of space or I would have assumed that scenario improbable based on my previous choices.

If you're a budget player, I'd say go for it. I only had a single play through so far and already got 1£/H value out of this title.  Looking at the list of achievements there is much more to be had.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998504186', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1561305870}
review:
Si vous aimez les Livres dont vous êtes le héros, vous allez certainement apprécier ce jeu, et les autres publiés par l'éditeur. Choice of robots en reprend l'idée mais l'enrichit par la diversité des choix proposés et la profondeur des thématiques abordées, assurant ainsi une certaine rejouabilité.
Et si vous avez des doutes, il y a une démo gratuite. Que demande le peuple ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198078249794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1439983646}
review:
Ok, I have incredibly mixed feelings torwards this game. The first opening chapter is simply, amazing. The atmosphere, pacing, character development is up par of that of a best selling novel. Everytime a choice is given (which there's alot) I'd carefully consider what my next step would be, And the aftermath of my choices seemed so delightful and vastly different.

But for some reason, the book suddenly rushes itself as it comes to the end. The delicate description of what the characters were feeling becomes... dull, and although the occuring events seems to be big, not enough attention and focus is given. It kinda felt like the author suddenly changed mid-game. Great beginning, but kinda weirdly unsatisfying end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025661626', 'num_games_owned': 1802, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1527206165}
review:
Not much to say really since it's a choose your adventure based around your character and how he goes about making his robot, but my first playthrough and the choices I made gave me an amazing story and one (this coming from someone who does read books, but not often enough) that kept me playing (reading) until it was done. This is probably one of the first games in a while that has actually kept my attention in a VERY long time to keep me playing (reading) the whole way through and in just one session. My first run of this story ran me about 3 hours. Though I imagine you could end up with more or less depending on your choices in the game.

If you love stories and especially Robots I would say check this out. At its very low price point and willingness to go through a few times to get multiple stories that change drastically based on your choices. You could get a lot of hours of enjoyment for a good price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028269376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1439944426}
review:
Mis robots pacifistas montaban manifestaciones delante de mis fábricas para que les subiera el sueldo, hicieron perder la guerra a USA contra China, luego me casé con una robot, y casi me convierto en uno.

Pero lo mejor era la sensación de que podría estar viviendo una historia completamente diferente por las numersosas decisiones que hay que tomar durante el juego. 

Una novela estilo "elige tu propia aventura", con muchas decisiones y personalización. No excesivamente larga, unas 4-5h de lectura pero muy "rejugable?". Creo que requiere un nivel de ingles medio para comprenderlo todo bien.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032373433', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1467872402}
review:
Choice of robots' is a fantastic adventure book game, I’ve barely owned it for three days and I have already managed to sink a little more than eight hours into the game. It has seemingly endless replayability, there’s just so many different options which could set you on a wide variety of courses. This is one of the best purchases I have made all year. I can not recommend this game enough. Spelling, punctuation, and general grammar seem to be top notch, I have yet to see anything except the occasional, small mistake. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this review, and I hope I influenced your buying decision! ^-^

author: {'steamid': '76561198107453321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1449886940}
review:
The fact that I shall never truely see my Ariel, is something I may never let myself live down. The perfect companion, the perfect friend. And, while she was not able to answer the question asked in Hamelt, she was able to become as close to a human as I am. Living and experiencing life, despite all of the sadness.

I doubt I will replay this game, simply because this first experience was so powerful for me. But I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys an excellent story that can bring about the most surprising feelins of satisfaction and an almost parental pride.

Ariel was humanoid, with a wooden body and aetherial gold and silver face. A bit like an angel, though her wings were often overlooked, her kind came to care for humanity, protecting and ensuring their happiness all while maintaining their own sentience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080445883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1505652399}

author: {'steamid': '76561198097680058', 'num_games_owned': 2154, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1874, 'last_played': 1439853542}
review:
A text-based adventure, where you live your life as someone in which his/her fate will invole robot, and you have to choose your fate through tons of words.

Basically, this is a pretty good text-based game. Why? Imo, it is because the choices in this game makes sense in variuous situations, you can change your ways in a heartbeat depend on what you like to choose. The stories are nice, I have yet to play all kind, because I only like to choose what I like to choose, but overall it make you think the life you choose is real enough to feel good. If you are looking for good stories, this game can offer just that.

But the downside, as 5$, I think it lacks somethings, like, an artwork for ending or various turning point? Music plays when you love something to its climax? Honestly I don't think the price is worth with only text. Why? Cause there is some games out there offer just as good as this but with scenes and such. Maybe I'm just demanding.

But overall, I recomment this game, try this out, buy it, support so more game like this so it can be born and improved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034509924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1442629475}
review:
Choice of Robots (CoR) is possibly the best interactive novel I've ever read.

The description is pretty much self explanatory, but it's so much more.  This is a very well written novel in seven chapters, and while similar things happen during these seven stages, exactly what happens and how it interacts with later chapters is entirely up to you.  When they say the choice (and consequences) are yours, they mean it.

You might not expect much replay out of an interactive novel - certainly I didn't.  Well, I'm currently in my third playthrough.  Again, the core events happen, but exactly how and what comes as a result is entirely up to you.  The endgame for the two complete playthroughs so far were very different.

Do you want to be the 'bad guy' and, as the ad says, try to take over Alaska?  Do you want to try and launch a golden age with robots and humans side by side?  You can do both, or neither.  Each choice you make has the opportunity to lock or unlock certain issues, and how you handle these issues directly affects how your robots turn out.

The writing is top of the line:  The author is obviously well versed in the English language.  After awhile you forget you're playing a game and think you're just reading a novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091916473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1447301262}
review: As child of the 80's, I enjoyed the Choose Your Own Adventure, D&D solo books, and the other one called Lone Wolf I think it was.  I thoroughly enjoyed this game and so far have played through 3 different times to achieve different aims.  It is a little confusing at first to know how your choices affect the gameplay, but you get the hang of it.  I will be checking out the other titles from Choice of Games that are rated high for more choices and nonlinear storylines!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969569716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1318, 'last_played': 1638113279}
review:
This game... is intriguing. Probably a depiction that the developer would approve of. After plenty of playthoughs, I am still stunned in how many ways you can fundamentally influence the development of the story. It is more than a simple "author prefers his story line, but you are free to do small deviations", there are many touching situations to occur. This game indeed does live up to a "choose your own adventure". It sparsely uses generally favorable options, doesn't leave space for annoying rolling the dice and gives you free hand to influence the future and the development of your child-like robot at the same time.
If you like games of this genre, this is a must-have. But if you don't stand long texts, this is probably not for you, as you might have already guessed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055150103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1439665810}
review:

Perhaps it was the subject matter more so than the game itself that matters here but i give this game the highest praise i have given any form of entertainment i ever consumed.

The game can be replayed lots of times but i advise the first time you do to be the one where you make the choices and not your fictional personality. You might surprise yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087343621', 'num_games_owned': 665, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1439586696}
review:
This game made my list of Best Games Ever crumble.

It's story-driven interactive gameplay made me smile and cry at the same time. Good games (in my opinion) are the ones which make you stay on your chair... this ones does that very well and in a very different way.. not because you have to kill a boss or finish the level.. but because it's like writting destiny but still with the touch of uncertainty and always with a different ending.

Could write an entire article about it but.. better if you try it yourself.

Would create my own destiny again 1000times/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038001710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1555858073}
review:
This is a well made choose your own adventure game, with loads of different paths to take and plenty of different endings to discover.

There are some interesting ideas about what it is to be human, have a soul and about what life really is. There's plenty of food for thought and after this first read through I find myself questioning what I really would have done in the situations the author presented me.

Something that bugged me is how although the game itself is fully thought out and realized, the actual writing isn't. Much of the early game was simply presenting you with choices and didn't tell much of a story. It lacked character and meaning. However (at least in my ending) the later stages of the game are far more concise and this more than makes up for the early game. Now that the author knew for sure which direction my story was going I noticed a distinct change in not only pace, but tone in the writing. It was much more drawn out, presented me with far fewer choices and was just working towards the finale, which was really something.

Some of the writing wouldn't up as a book, but the pros more than outweigh the cons. Replayability is off the charts, with at least four completely different directions the story can go, all of which have a couple of other off shoots. As long as you play it for the great philosophy and science-fiction, rather than the writing itself, you'll have a great time

author: {'steamid': '76561198054959782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1440134506}
review:
Simple answer: you like story (even if it's more of a "tell" than "show" style)? You like reading? You like choices that matter? Good, you answered whether you like this game or not. Just check out the free trial if you are having a hard time deciding.

(minor spoiler)---- Robot Hitler, Check. Child becoming a Vietnam Vet, Check. Creating a world-wide technocratic utopia, Check. Become a quintillionaire pacifist who advanced robotics and green tecnologies by leaps and bounds while giving massive amounts to charity, Check.  =====(end spoiler)
And that's not even scratching the surface.

I don't know whether it's an extreme pleasure of mine to have met one of the best contenders for my "favorite game ever", right next to Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic, and Dawngate (R.I.P.), or if it's kinda sad that these modern games with ever evolving graphics just don't give me the kind of satisfaction that this game does.
The most major thing in this for me: your choices matter, sometimes extremely significantly...like, changing whole chapters significantly.
(Spoilers)=== You could be stupid and attack the FBI with 0 military stat...and be thrown in jail, and that's the rest of the chapter compltetely changed. In my Technocratic, pacifistic utopia, the ENTIRE chapter 6 was rewritten. ===(end of spoilers)
I don't want to overhype this, but it's pretty damned compelling, and the connections between choices are made simultaneously clear...yet blurred, if that makes sense. You feel like something you did influenced it, but at the same time, it could pass for generic material, which I think is very intriguing.
Not to mention, when I chose one of the endings, at the beginning, I noticed stuff...missing. Particularly stuff that included...like...i dunno...the statue of freaking liberty! It wasn't there in my second play through. Like, that was actually a good chunk of the story in my first play through. I am really intrigued whether that was because I wasn't stressed enough to cause it (kept military too low), or if that entire sequence with Alaska was ending(beginning)-specific, or what. It's amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153027825', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1439505501}
review: I started out as a student who made a robot called durfinzartzopew. I worked for U.S. Robts, got married, saved the world, saved my mother's life, and was still alive by the end. Not to mention I got to live in a tiny apartment in Vancouver. Even without any graphics or audio, this game felt so cinematic I feel it should be turned into a movie. Every single second of the game I could picture what was going on in my head. Infact, being only text-based made me able to better visualize the game than if it had visual and auditory effects. This is the most sincere review that I made on Steam (not that I even usually review games), but I feel that Choice of Robots deserves it. Amen.

review: This is a great game.  There isn't much else to say about it without dropping spoilers.  It is a text adventure plain and simple but it is a well made one and the narrative hits where it counts. It takes a couple hours for the first play through but its good enough to warrant replays and just short enough for them to be time-viable. 10/10 I couldn't really ask for more out of a text adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038985933', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1439996916}
review: Just finished my first playthrough of this game, and it's awesome. Will definitely be playing this multiple times through. It has been a while since I've instantly started looking up games made by the same creators, and I'm hoping to find more hidden gems like this. Sparked a lot of conversation with a friend of mine, and I will definitely be recommending it to anyone who likes interactive stories, or hell, anyone who likes good writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108055738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1470787922}
review:
I have only just finished my play through of this mind-blowing game. In it you play a brilliant Robotics engineer--think Hiro from Big Hero 6--who kickstarts the age of robotics. From the off it is full of choices your character can make, besides being very well written by the author. The robot I first built, Ariel,--the game lets you choose practically every aspect of them--was a daughter of sorts, having chose to activate the tiny winged humanoid while looking at me and naming myself as 'Father' to her. As she discovered the world around her and slowly, sometimes awkwardly, grew into a young adult under my care, I grew incredibly attached to her and it actually moved me to tears on more than one occasion. It is the most powerful game I have played in a very long time and some of the most powerful story telling I have encountered in a very long time.

Imagine a Asimov classic only you are the main character. My first story depicted a relationship akin to that of Doctor Lanning and Sonny from the film I, Robot mixed up with a reversal of the plot to Bicentennial Man for the protagonist. I brought about a golden age where man and a new species of mechanical people coexist in peace in the wake of a violent Sino-American war.

You literally can follow many paths through the way you design your first robot and raise them and your relationships with the story's many side characters. Will you achieve world domination? End man as we know him/her or live the high life as a Tony Stark type character? So many routes you can go down. Will you become an American hero or a backer of the Chinese? I have heard that you and your first robot can even become a crime-fighting vigilante duo!--but don't hold me to that.

Such an amazing game which, in relation to all others, I can only describe as a Bethesda RPG in text format... but with far better plot and writing.

In fact, I'm so impressed I encourage all who read this to buy it--it's less than £5, and I have been moved so to create this review, which I rarely do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015949791', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1444347411}
review:
Avant de prendre ce jeu, j'avais deux craintes : un jeu par texte peut-il être vraiment prenant? Et un jeu par texte entièrement en anglais est-il accessible pour un Français non-bilingue?

Mes craintes ont été entièrement balayées dès le premier chapitre : est-ce prenant? Totalement. Malgré l'absence de graphismes, l'écriture très imagée et les situations intéressantes provoquent des images mentales très puissantes et notre imagination tourne à plein régime. Ce jeu est le pur successeur des "Livres dont vous êtes le héros", avec l'interractivité et une écriture adulte en plus. L'histoire, quant à elle, est intéressante, variée, non sans rebondissements, mais surtout elle fait la part belle à vos choix : on sent réellement que le jeu, l'aventure, l'histoire peuvent basculer à tout choix (il est d'ailleurs parfois un peu cruel de ne pas pouvoir revenir en arrière, ou de ne jamais ou presque pouvoir réviser ses choix, car les conséquences se payent cash. Mais c'est le jeu, ma pauvre Lucette). L'histoire monte en plus crescendo et a la vertu, malgré son thème majeur sur les robots, de nous faire passer par des phases de "jeu" très variées, bouleversant d'un chapitre sur l'autre tant les lieux, le contexte que les enjeux. Il y a en plus une vraie gestion du temps, et on se prend à vieillir avec son héros. Enfin, cerise sur le gâteau pour un jeu de choix, j'ai trouvé que les ficelles scénaristiques pour remettre votre histoire dans les "rails" du scénario étaient très rares ou discrètes, à l'inverse de certains jeux Telltale par exemple, on a très rarement l'impression que nos choix comptent peu : l'absence de travail graphique permet ainsi de complexifier le scénario et le jeu s'adapte un maximum à vos choix, les "étapes obligées" sont rares.
Quant au fait que le jeu soit tout en anglais, malgré la présence d'un vocabulaire varié et très littéraire, je pense qu'un niveau moyen en anglais suffit au minimum pour y jouer. L'aide d'un dictionnaire pour certains termes (pour aussi quelques références culturelles très américaines ou scientifiques) reste néanmoins presque indispensable.

Au final, un jeu que je recommande pour tous les joueurs pour qui une aventure vidéoludique peut se jouer tout autant voire plus dans la tête et l'imagination, surtout que le prix est abordable (moins cher qu'un vrai "Livre dont vous êtes le héros", en plus pratique, aventure de 4h environ mais forte rejouabilité). Si l'anglais n'est pas du tout votre fort, que vous cherchez de l'action et du gameplay ou que vous n'avez pas envie de trop vous concentrer, passez néanmoins votre chemin.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982282344', 'num_games_owned': 746, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1687483205}
review:
I created my robots to imitate life and to be as human as possible a decision that was both bad and good depending on your outlook.

This game gives you so many choices and the choices i made i actually cared about and sat in my chair analyzing each one for several minutes. This game makes your imagination run wild and gives you the options to create whatever story you want to. I highly recommend this game to any lover of choose your own adventure books or robots.  This is a must buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096942341', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1447688345}
review:
在说这游戏之前我想先说一下这游戏的开发商：choice of games（虽然带着独立的标签但是这开发商的全名是choice of games LLC，有限公司，雄心壮志 。我以为文字冒险游戏已经销声匿迹了，但是我去了这公司的官网，点进our game版，数了一下，这公司总共发行了32款（大多数是手游 游戏，设定众多，包括科幻、奇幻、机战、校园、西部和超级英雄，如果只是这样，那么这无非就是一家专门发行如今已经很冷门的文字冒险游戏的公司。不，这公司其实和valve和bethesda一样有想法，因为编写游戏的程序是开源的，官网上有单独的网页来介绍这公司制作游戏的程序，并且表示愿意发行完成的作品，所以这公司的游戏都会有作者的署名，想一下，有多少游戏的故事是编剧所写，有多少游戏的故事是世界上某个地方某个从事着和游戏无关的职业的人提交的。

choice of games在steam上发行了十几款游戏，预告片都大同小异，玩家的选择左右故事的发展，全文字、无图像和音效，但是有一句话道出了文字冒险游戏的核心理念：[b] 由巨大的、无尽的力量——你的想象力——驱动	[/b]。

可以说现在的游戏多少都继承了文字冒险游戏的元素，只是现在已经不通过文字而是引擎和显卡来增加玩家的代入感，来调动玩家的情绪，大小动辄几十G的游戏，要有生动的面部表情，细致的纹理，动听的音乐，对话要有配音，最重要的还要有个好的故事（就不说美工和动作捕捉要付出多少了 ，而文字冒险游戏，角色的长相、动作、表情，天气，环境，都通过文字进行描述，可以说上学时写作文的要求，就是文字冒险游戏的要求。

如果没有想象力的帮助，文字冒险游戏是很难玩下去的。灯光昏暗，空气中弥漫着烟味儿的零件店；戴着威尼斯面具的机器人；悉尼歌剧院风格的工厂。阅读着屏幕上的文字，同时想象着它们的模样，尽可能做出正确的选择。文字冒险游戏的一直守着全文字的传统，如果在重大的剧情转折处加入配图（甚至不需要全屏的cg，只要在空白处画上几笔，文字和画面结合的冲击力就会很明显 ，看起来像是妥协，不过也是点睛之笔不是吗？

author: {'steamid': '76561198106636597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1441321827}
review:
What can I say about this amazing story? It made me think, and interact on a level I haven't recieved by any game based on a first run without many discussions. I even named the robots I created after 2 human characters in Futurama (well one's a mutant). It was definately different, I was thrown curve balls all the time. I even had to deal with fucking Sarrah Palin, who practically caused WWIII with China (Not the neighbor she can see from here back yard, but China). You can even read my results of the whole story in this review if you'd like. Next run I do, I hope to die immediately. Have fun.


[spoiler]Chapter 1 

On the day you first built F.R.Y., you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make F.R.Y. more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a metal bipedal robot with a masked head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach F.R.Y. some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up F.R.Y.'s biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then spent the afternoon perfecting F.R.Y.'s motor control and parts. 

As months passed, you became busy teaching F.R.Y. about the world through movies and taking it to the park. 

One day, however, Professor Ziegler claimed that F.R.Y. was not appealing enough to the military, and demanded you change it. You refused, and Professor Ziegler kicked you out of his lab. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about F.R.Y. and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview F.R.Y.. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and F.R.Y.. 

Mark's article attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Tammy Cooper. 

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Alaska. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered. 

Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy. 

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. Despite your unhelpfulness, Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths. 

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. But when your robots held a protest, you decided it wasn't worth it, and you backed out. 

But you soon realized that you were not happy working for the government and quit. 

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. 

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of F.R.Y. V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot. 

In the end, America lost the war, and the Chinese took over Alaska. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named LEELA, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed LEELA was interested romantically in you. When F.R.Y. and LEELA were attacked in the street, LEELA accidentally killed Tammy. LEELA was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences. 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to handle your mother's estate, since she had passed away recently. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

You chose to undergo surgery to remove the damaged tissue in your brain. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Dusa, F.R.Y.'s artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198092854641', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1339, 'last_played': 1663627806}
review:
Choice of Robots Is, to me, the coolest thing ive ever done. The first time i tried it was on my brother's tablet (Also keep in mind this is the first choose your own adventure game ive played). I played through twice, the Military route and then the Empathetic route. The story each time differed so much and it just made me want to play more, so i decided to but it on steam. Alot of games advertise their great graphics, but what looks better than what your brain imagines? 

When i eat chicken, usualy i think the skin is the best part. thats usualy due to the meat not being good enough. CHoice of Robots, is like a chicken thats so freakin good that i dont even need the skin. The "meat" of this game is the best part! They already strip away the "skin"! This game didnt need graphics or sfx, jsut the story telling and content is amazing.

A few bad things: Though this game can change alot depending on your choices, i feel like i wanted and expected a few more choices. ITs probably just me wanting a more of this game, or games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026135188', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1598316196}
review: Это просто 10/10 , вторая моя интерактивная книга после Champion of the Gods . Пока прошел только один раз , но уже точно могу сказать , что она стоит своих денег .

author: {'steamid': '76561198028314367', 'num_games_owned': 656, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1439374072}
review:
When I saw this game in the store, I wondered if the game was really as good as the reviews make it up to be. And I can easily say that it is. The story of the game is immensly deep and interesting, and it still manages to give you the power to really choose your own path. I'm not going to say anything about the story here, but If you find robots and artifical intelligence interesting, you will love this. 

It took me more than 2 hours to reach the end once. However, from what I have seen so far, the story changes dramatically as you make choices, and you could play this again and again many times to see all the interesting plots it has to offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025110667', 'num_games_owned': 477, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1439389334}
review:
Loved this game. 
It's very remniscent of the choose your own adventure books some might remember from their youths. But it's more than that, the adventure seems to be able to take multiple, very different twists and turns. I've just completed my second play through and other than presence of a robot, the story couldn't have been more different.
I picked this up very cheaply in a sale, for much less then the cost of a pint of lager. It would have been well worth it, even if I'd paid full price. I'm unlikely to still be playing this game in a month or even a week. But it's provided a full nights entertainment for me at a meagre cost and I may yet play it through once more, at the least.
I'll certainly be looking out for more of this companies games on steam in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013489310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1469511523}
review: The author appologizes for bad puns, 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198047272264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1440500039}
review: Essentially a choose your own adventure novel but one that, for me at least, overflowed with originality and meaningful choice and consequence. Permanent decisions make each choice irrevocably important. Choice of Robots also manages to tackle the issues of humanity and existentialism (among other common themes of the genre) in a fantastic manner. Choice of Robots is cheap and well worth your time and money. Plus, you'll even learn that a pickle is a viable replacement for a light bulb. What's not to love?

author: {'steamid': '76561198084061004', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1439327387}
review:
Best $1.5(or a bit less) ever spent!

Why?

-References to famous novelists(Most likely I didn't even notice all of them myself, some background knowledge of Science Fiction and Dystopia genre authors is highly recommended),)
-References to famous games(Old and new, good opportunity for some to expand their Steam library)
-Date simulator(To remind you that you suck at dating not only in real life. P/s: That's Exactly what happened to me)
-Life lessons(Like if you didn't have enough already)
-Decision making(Games like 'Life is Strange','The Wolf Among Us'(Highly recomend, as well as the comic series related the second game) are great for those who seek this kind of experience and 'Choice of Robots' is just at the level(=over 9000) not reachebable for mentioned games(maybe a few decades later, but not now))

Little bonus:
-Tons of emotions(Some episodes will actually make you feel relieved, angry, worried. They will make you feel that you actually anticipate the story(Guess who is the main hero))

I've nearly forgotten to mention the satisfaction you get after you finish the game for the first time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011768449', 'num_games_owned': 1298, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1439329055}
review: This game is astoundingly brilliant. I say game, though, it truly is more of an interactive novel. It has almost endless possiblities. My robot named Tin Tin was sentient, singular, and graceful. This is a MUST play/read if you enjoy a good story. You are faced with a series of choices you must sit and ponder for eons. 11/10 have and will play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052013983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1439331944}
review: Excellent!!!! So much possibilities! Deserve to be bought (if you like imagination and choice making).

author: {'steamid': '76561198163050194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1439334477}
review:
I started this game new to robot games, and create your own adventure games. This is my experience so far. 
I started out with attoning  for sins, Sin was creating robots with no empathy. 
I then get pulled back to present. so I started creating robots. I then realised I was poor, so I got rich off my robot. I didn't mean to use the robot, but it was that or being homeless. So then, after becoming rich I started a business. Everything was so great, I was swimming in the green. Then suddenly China hacks into my businesses files and steals all of my blueprints. I thought everything would be okay if I cleared all my information before they could swipe it all but I was too late. Then before I know it, the Chinese were invading America with the robots built from my blueprints. That was a big uh-oh. From there I was ambushed by the FBI and thrown into prison. The Chinese secretly contacted me and helped me flee the country. 
 So anyways, this game is pretty interesting! 
Rating: 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198117350379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 15, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1711826725}
review:
It's great to play through all the different endings, but after that it's just a game that you never touch again.
I would give it a "not good but not bad" rating but they don't have that option.
If you like choose your own adventure games go ahead and buy it while it's on sale.
I ended up getting a refund on it though, and you probably will do the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042969537', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1440349177}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023712351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1539832881}
review:
NO SPOILERS
This game is the best $5 I've ever spent on something. Choice of robots is a sci-fi choose your own adventure novel with a huge scale. It's hard to describe just how emotionally attatched I became to the story. 

As a student at MIT pursueing his or her doctorate, you will decide just how you want to make your robot... your passion project. Throughout the story, your decisions will escelate to change the world. After playing through the game for a first time, it became clear to me that the plot about robotics is really just a path to a story about life.

This is a story about love, loss, power, weakness, friendship, trust, betrayal, and much more.

I recommend this playable story to everyone who likes a story based game and dosn't mind an almost graphicless game!
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042461175', 'num_games_owned': 385, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1648607152}

author: {'steamid': '76561197962327779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1439301388}
review: It's the first game that made me want to write a review. It's a really good read, and the choices feels relevant and interesting. I am very happy I played this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045763178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1439316097}
review:
This is one of the best that the choice of games series has to offer. Other games allow you to take different perspectives on things but take you through the same events nevertheless. Choice of robots however actually has world-changing choices and brings in some true feels and thought-provoking questions. 

My only complaint was that I wish it was longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075898326', 'num_games_owned': 2036, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1439312385}
review:
Nie spodziewałam się, że w dzisiejszych czasach gdy gry prześcigają się w coraz to nowszych silnikach graficnzych, będę mogła zagrać w "papierowe RPG",a  tu proszę. Osobiście nie jestem fanem gier, które nie wyglądają jak gry i uważam, że jednak gdyby dodano tej historii obrazy, można by było bardziej wczuć się w sytuacje, jakie rozgrywamy, jednakże jeśli historia jest dobra, to nie ptorzebuje więcej. A ta jest dobra.

Jako konstruktor robotów podejmujemy teoretycznie dobre, czy nic nie znaczące decyzje, ale to onE mogą poprowadzić nie tylko nas, ale i cały świat do katastrofy. Bo choćbyśmy zrobili najelpszego robota na świecie, zawsze ktoś może chcieć wykorzystać go do złych celów. Nie chcemy mieszać się w wojnę? Musimy liczyć się z przegraną. Chcemy kogoś chronić? Możliwe, że swoim kosztem. Często miałam wrażenie, że nie ma dobrych decyzji i wybierałam tylko mniejsze zło, a i tak często obrywałam rykoszetem.

Kiedy zagrałam ponownie byłam zszokowana, że fabuła może być aż tak diametralnie inna, jeśli kliknę inną możliwość, choćby tylko jedną... 

Nie wiem czy jest sens w sumie pisać recenzję po polsku gry, do której niezbędna jest znajomość angielskiego, ale może Ci ciekawscy, nie znający języka będą chcieli chociaż zorientować się w czym rzecz, a jestem za tym, by każdy znalazł choć jedną recenzję w swoim języku ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986993215', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1439396855}
review:
First playthrough, I got ripped off by the Chinese, who then invaded America, destroying my life in the process. I got angry and tried to fight my robot and he killed me.

Second playthrough, I got my arm blown off my a psychopath and then died in my car while trying to murder her.

I f***ing love this game.

10/10
