author: {'steamid': '76561198158287948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1623427239}
review: Meet Steve, a blocky, cube-headed little robot. Taught to love, not fight. He is quirky, cute, and oh so loveable, and I've never even seen him. And meet Olive, my companion bot. She shows a little more complex emotion than Steve, but is just as likeable. Olive wanted to love me, but I wouldn't allow it. I was married, and although I accept robot marriage and robot-human romance, I was not up for it myself. She felt rejected. Steve was clueless, like a happy, yet genius, child. Though Olive was hurting, with her advanced emotions coming into play. One day, we were just taking a walk together, Olive and I. She asks what she can do with her life. I say she must look after Steve, as I am dying. She didn't want that, so I ask what she wanted to do. That's when she replied "Whatever I want," and then ran off without another word. That was the last I'd seen of Olive, after her murder trial, after all her learning and experiences with me, Steve, and my wife. Her and Steve, my creations. My children.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063731333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1461872688}
review:
Before you read any further, just know that this game is great, and that reading almost any review has the potential to ruin the amazing surprises in store. But anyway.

Here's a quick summary of how my first playthrough went, as spoiler free as possible:

>Make a robot
>Make a robot business
>Looks like the potential for world domination is in sight
>Lose robot business
>End up contracted into designing weapons for US military, despite best efforts
>Enter a new war of robotics with China
>End up imprisoned by America for half a year
>Refuse to defect to China
>China tries to kill me
>Live
>War ends as a stalemate
>Make a new robot
>Make myself into a robot
>End

I don't normally enjoy things enough to review them, so bare with me here.

My first 'playthrough', if I could call it that, it was much more of a readthrough, of 'Choice of Robots' took me just over three hours to get through, and likely could have taken much longer, assuming that I wasn't terrible and took so many 'bad' decisions, I'd say my first read could have easily lasted me four or maybe even five hours. It should go without saying, that there is an immense amount of replayability in a game such as this. Which is to mention, replaying this is definitely something I intend on doing, but I'm not sure that I'll be able to recreate the attachment & bond I had with my three foot tall, human-like, winged 'Ariel' with multitool hands, whom was vehemently opposed to conflict as a result of my actions.

See, Choice of Robots is a game where your choices can influence the course of humanity so heavily, that the sense of creating a story just for yourself lends to a sense of wonder and beauty that I haven't really experienced in many conventional books or text-based games in perhaps forever. Even though I could tell from about halfway through that my choices were going to lead me down a seemingly 'undesirable' route, (considering that my presumption was that I would shatter Capitalism and create a Utopia) I still continued to read on and make decisions based on the situation, as the writing and sense of achievement is so fantastically constructed, that I didn't find myself feeling sad, or upset at the fact that I might not get that 'good' ending, instead, I felt happy that in what is undoubtably a story of such scale & grandeur; mine was a story revolving around me, my friends & my family. This is what, in my eyes, we'd call a testament to the brilliance of the writing.

I can't speak of the aspect of how destroying the world may turn out, or how imposing a singularity upon humanity would be, but in my playthrough, the process of building up a robot in my own image, including its gender & naming it, right up to the viewpoint it had on the world, made interacting with my three foot tall companion really something quite special. Taking my creation which, at this point, had evolved into something so much more than just that, to the park, and observing the body language she gave off whilst she learned to properly kick off on a swing to propel herself up into the air was certainly pleasant. But knowing that our actions had turned her from being a military-backed weapon, into a video game loving creature of empathy? That was something else entirely; something I've not experienced before.

If you are even remotely interested in robotics, sentience, world politics and business practices, I'd heavily advise picking up this game. Even if you are just looking for a great story, you definitely won't be disappointed. I think the myriad of Overwhelmingly Positive reviews such as this give evidence to that.

My one gripe with this game, if anything, would perhaps be its length, which I don't even feel justified in saying, especially after just one playthrough. But in my particular instance, it felt as if certain sections were rushed, and that at quite a lot of stages, I didn't get the chance to sit and talk, explore and influence quite as much as I'd have liked to with other characters & situations. But this is completely forgiveable given the scale of the game and the immense replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135492234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1445821152}
review:
This game is absolutely amazing! Completely immersive, endless possibilites for character depth and storyline and every event and character is completely fleshed out and believable.

I've played two hours and I have already developed an emotional attatchment to not only my character but to My robotic progeny and side characters too. I would happily pay 20+ bucks for this game.

Also, as I've said, I've only played two hours... I've taught my little robot how to think, how to learn and how feel. I've also stuck it to the man, designed a fleet of robotic surgeons, gotten drunk, and got laid - 3 times!

EPIC game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999714614', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1439655881}
review: Well-written, heartfelt, and insightful. I expected this to be good but found myself completely astonished at its depth and consideration. Worth it at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996425765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 901, 'last_played': 1665454010}
review:
Having played all the Choice of Games, this is definitely the best one. If you can stand a text based game, just buy it, play it, and play it four or five more times.

While parts of it aren't the greatest storytelling and some of branches are fairly ridiculous (intentionally or otherwise) it is written intelligently, which is novel for something that deals in sci-fi.

Yes, parts of AI or embelished or simplified, but overall it's a story with surprisingly thoughtful elements, a good range of control over what happens, decent writing, and not horribly short like some (though not that long - it is after all the limitation of choice your own adventures with actual branching naratives).

author: {'steamid': '76561198039109651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1441423402}
review:
Made a robot.
Sold a bunch of robots.
Started my own robot making company.
Stuff happened.
Went broke.
Stayed with mom.
Made more robots.
Got rich.
Helped my female robot companion understand the true meaning of love.
Got a big mansion.
Married said female robot.
Lived happily ever after.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137270236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1439257990}
review:
Gamebook, který Vás dostane! A udrží si Vaši pozornost až do konce. Ano, jistě, bylo by lepší přidat tomu trochu komiksový nádech, možná i nějakou decentní hudbu na pozadí, sem tam nějaký ten obrázek dokreslující scénu nebo situaci, jak je dnes zvykem. Ale to je jen velmi drobná vada na kráse tohoto jinak skvělého vypravěčského titulu! Zdá se, že éra zombie apokalypsy (TWD, ...) se blíží pomalu ke konci a nastává éra A.I. a filosofování nad tím, co to znamená být člověkem (The Talos Principle, ...).

+ příběh
+ možnosti rozvíjení příběhu
+ několik tematicky odlišných kapitol (financování, válka, soužití, kyberimplantáty...)
+ docela slušná myšlenková hloubka

- "jen" holý text
- "jen" 4 hodiny hraní

Chtěl jsem vytvořit robota - "nadčlověka", empatického společníka lidí, který by urychlil morální, duchovní a duševní vývoj lidstva. Chtěl jsem přiměřeně zbohatnout, oženit se, založit si rodinu, a světový mír.
Místo toho mi shořela má továrna, zbankrotoval jsem, ukradli mi mou technologii a zneužili pro armádu, nepřímo jsem vyvolal 3. světovou válku, které jsem se posléze odmítl zúčastnit, šla po mně FBI a mé robotí dítko mě stálo manželství.

V jistém ohledu mi to připomíná můj skutečný život.

1.0e2/10.

V další hře zkusím vytvořit empatický bojový stroj. Na ten snad má (potenciální) žena žárlit nebude :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198162140466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1457588969}
review: The amount of detail and number of directions the story can go in is amazing. I chose to develop relationships with my robot companions, and grew genuinely attached to them throughout the course of the game as I taught them what it means to be a person. That said, next time I'd like to try my hand at conquering everything with a robot army. That sounds just as fulfilling.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995003316', 'num_games_owned': 2545, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1297, 'last_played': 1561514454}
review:
Made a robot with a box head, wings, humanoid, and claws for arms. Gave it free will and let it learn anything. He started as a machine, but ended up becoming more. In the end, the robots became equal to humans, both by laws and mentality.

I also made a robot with a sockpuppet head and googly eyes that has many hands and runs on treads that talked like someone inhailed helium. He ended up taking over the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034726661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1671116706}

It seemed like we were on our way to building a happy polyamorous relationship until my robot couldn't handle it anymore and ran away. I never saw or heard from him ever again. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198021545874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1661100388}
review: from what i have seen so far its quite endearing piece of growth that we might see in next ~50 or so years for real.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090998063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1455132071}
review:
Wow. I can tell you right now that you MUST buy this game.

I am fan of robots. Especially intelligent robots. They force us to imagine a world where humans come into contact with an intelligent species of our own creation and ask ourselves what we value in humanity and what we want represented in our creations.

This game perfectly captures what a "make your own adventure" should be. There are choices that you make that you won't see the results for until much later. There will be times where you eagerly want to restart the game because of a choice leading you down a undesirable path. And yet you want to see if you can salvage the situation because you created your robot companion, forged bonds with the people around you, and cause the stablility of the world to hang in the balance.

Example (*Spoilers*): I tried my hardest to make my robot (Legion) with empathy and autonomy so he would not despise humans. Imagine my shoch and horror as he almost betrays me at the start of a robot revolution. However, by making some tough choices, I managed to end the revolution (the robots still came out on top) and managed to patch things up with my creation. I grew old with him and my lover. At the near end of my life, he wishes to die with me, and wants to help me become a robot so I may live. I decline, seeing that I don't deserve to live forever and convince him that death is essential to being autonomous. My story ends with my family celebrating Legion's first daughter's birthday. I struggle to make it through, but through the choices I made, I manage to live on for a while longer and enjoy what I made. I, like my character, set out to make the perfect, human companion. What I didn't realize was I made the most perfect, imperfect companion. And that made him all the more human.

There is no music in this game, there is no fancy graphics either, but the story will have you immersed like no other and make you question how you would be in real life, and perhaps, what kind of impact you might make in the world. A definite buy for anyone interested in sci-fi, stories and where life may take us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054512149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1439238456}
review:
I got thrown out of school, built a daughter, started a hightech company in china, survived china taking over half the world, built everyone a robot spouse, almost died of a stroke...
but in the end I lived happily with 3 robots as my family.

Life takes unexpected turns but in the end thats what makes it life.


This game is a great experience for novelfans and those that like making their own path.

It is exactly what it advertises to be so it deserves the often reviewed 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198033422918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1438149766}
review: Solid although rather predictable game. I enjoyed it but can't be arsed to play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148676717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 541, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1439373935}
review:
it's a little hard to review this as a game, because it is lacking in so many gaming elements. No graphics, no gameworld, no combat. But what is one to expect from an interactive novel. Since i am such a stickler for form, i will still rate the game according to my normal nine criteria. 


genre: 3

it is the best interactive novel i have "played", at least in terms of making choices that matter. 



character customization, mods, etc: 1

You can pick male or female. That is it. You do get to pick whether you are interested in wealth, military, or idealism. But i wouldn't really consider this a character. 



story, mission, relevance: 3

don't expect War and Peace, because the writing has no literary merit, but there is plenty of story and your choices do matter. I have played through the story 5 times, and got 5 very different stories. There are at least 4 romantic partners (2 male, 1 female), there is a war, there is how your character will live out their life. In an interactive novel, i want my choices to matter. They definitely matter. In one of my play throughs, one of my choices resulted in my character dying in 10 minutes. I found this surprising, and satisfying.



gameworld: 1

not really a "game world", but there is a world you react to by making choices (usually 3). And the world does change. By your choices, the game world will either have you win, lose, or stalemate a war, build robots that help or harm humanity, or cause the world your character lives in experience a revolution. Certain key characters will thrive or die, including yourself, based on those choices. But this is not what i would call a game world. You don't pick up anything. You never see a picture of a single character or scene. You do a lot of reading.



innovation: 0



mechanics, combat, saves: 0




replayability: 3

like i said above, i played it 5 times, and got five different stories, including different endings and romantic partners. And i haven't exhausted the game's choices yet. I haven't played as a dreamy idealist. Haven't explored all the romantic possibilities. Still some "gaming" to do. 



uniqueness: 2

the fictional world is a sci-fi cliche. As the title suggests, it is a world full of robots. Being a lover of sci-fi, i am okay with that. I did find the number of choices a bit unique. And the straight-forward approach, with nothing but text, was unique to my experience of these sort of "games". 




graphics: 0

unless you consider the image of text on screen graphics. 


13 out of 27, or 48%



Do you like to read? Are you sick and tired of killing things? Had your fill of scavenging ruins for that bit of something needed to craft the next great weapon? Then this is the "game" for you. If you consider it a game. Even with such a low score, i do not regret buying this game. In an hour i can have a new story unfold before my fingers, and all by my choices. And i am kind of sick of these interactive novels that try and give the player gaming experience but fail to give players lots of meaningful choices. Just about every choice i made affected the story in some way. And there weren't walls of text to read through. I would spend the $2.99 again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057654418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1438798005}
review:
So far I have only finished one possible playthrough... it was clever and so much deaper than I expected.
I also got a lot more into it than I thought I would. It made me make some tough decisions and I was sometimes scared for how they would change the lives of my characters and sad when the results werent what I hoped. (+++ Empathy)

author: {'steamid': '76561198052285223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1490599606}
review:
Habe die Demo auf English verschlungen und musste mir die Vollversion kaufen. Und hab es nicht bereut. Das Spiel ist rein textbasiert und ermöglicht dem Spieler in die Haut eines jungen Studenten zu schlüpfen. 

DIe Geschichte ist sehr interessant und schön erzählt. Aber man muss Liebhaber von solchen Dingen sein, um so mit zufiebern. Ich kann es allen ans Herz legen die keine Angst vor dem Englishen haben und einfach mal entspannt einen Charakter in einer sich mit ihm entwickelnden Geschichte sein möchten :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198031143029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1463516396}
review:
I've just finished my story and hurried to write this review. - 11/10!
Normally, I don't recommend interactive stories as they're generally not good at being a game, BUT NOT THIS ONE! It was an epic journey, an amazing combination of interactive sci-fi story and RPG elements.

There's just too much to tell... If you like sci-fi, stories about AI, making decisions and seeing how your decisions affect your journey/gameplay - it is for you, you won't be disappointed.

Apropos, someone make a movie plz.

Edit: It's so good I've started again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035244202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1451563603}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990617706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1426103914}

It's just like a playbook, but has an amazing plot (multiple ones actually), and some excellent, witty writing.

Best money i spent on games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019734253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1710985614}
review: Great game that has all the fun choices and good story you would want of a choose your own adventure, represents a good selection of Robot sentience issues, and some cognitive masturbation literary quotes.  My only beefs were that the story was written by a very big global warming opinionated person who poked fun of capatalists and i wasn't able to work out a threesome. Then i looked at the achievments and apparently a threesome should be possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040672962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1444441787}
review:
Couldn't leave my seat for nearly six hours. Choice of Robots makes an anarchronism out of the "choose your own adventure" novels of my childhood. Choice of Robots brings the ethical questions regarding emergent intelligence and AI forefront with contemporary concerns we as a species are being confronted with, as we move into the "Singularity."

I HIGHLY recommend this game/book. Very high replay value. An emotional page turning. And one that makes you THINK!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044265429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1693187631}
review:
Oh boy, that was intense. I hardly have the attention span to a game like this, but god i was hooked.

This is a great experience for anyone that likes Asimov, and i will aways remember the time when Etro-1 sang When You Wish Upon A Star on television.

I started as an idealistic college student and gradually became a rich old man that neglected everything else for his fear of death.  For me, this game was full of "WHAT HAVE I DONE" moments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123305993', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 641, 'playtime_forever': 1792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1792, 'last_played': 1560123558}

author: {'steamid': '76561198163534375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1636887571}
review:
I've played through this game four times, and I've seen new scenes and dialouge every time. Very rarely does a game make me stop and think about my actions, how something I've done had caused, say, a robot uprising, or a terrorist attack.

This game/book thing, is a definite must play/read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027048925', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1573381464}
review: Well... hummm... started the game at 22h00 and finished at 6h00... i did not sleep the nigth so mutch this was good.. i could not stop... IGive a note of 10/10 for its kind....  and i also made a robot wiser then me...A good game.. i recomand it

author: {'steamid': '76561198008261725', 'num_games_owned': 5745, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1437855315}
review:
By far the best Choice Of game. It's incredibly thoughtful, well-written, and has choices that don't feel forced at all. Unlike most of the other Choice Of games, Choice of Robots does not only offer binary choices; in fact, many times, divergence can change the story altogether, which is rare in these Choice Of games, none of which really match this.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198007160724', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1444565387}
review:
Eine der Besten Spielerfahrungen die ich machen durfte!  Danke an die Macher! Eine für mich grossartige Novelle auf die man Einfluss nehmen darf. Ich mache bei jedem Durchgang neue Entdeckungen über mich. Das haben bisher nur wenige, (falls überhaupt eines bisher) Spiele mit mir gemacht. Am besten schöne Musik,  Leonard Bernstein Fantasia on Greensleeves z.B., dazu laufen lassen. Für mich als Fan von Asimov und anderen Old School SF Autoren 10/10.
Alle Grafikfetischisten sollten sich nach was anderem umsehen. Aber wer auf Grafik verzichten kann wird auf seine Kosten kommen. Auch wenn man nur indirekt in das Geschehen eingreift. Und man muss bereit sein sich auf die Geschichte einzulassen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087901220', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1439166966}
review:
What can i say about this game that explains it better than amazing. It is a book that you can controll in so many
ways. There are sad endings and moments, and there are happy endings and moments. You could be a crude leader,
or a generous and loving person. This story can have so many different things, i replayed it a few times before i wrote
this review. It was worth the 5$ i spent on it, and i suggest you do the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037305885', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1583984540}
review: As a long time fan of Choice of Games, this has to be in my opinion their best work to date. The amount of choice pales in comparison to the emotion you'll experience while playing this game - I was actually [i]feeling[/i] things - at one point I almost cried. This is a brilliant work that manages to push the view that video games can be art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055079941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1486, 'last_played': 1419486961}
review:
Awesome game - didn't know I had not left a review.

Buy it. Do it. Do it JUST DO IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069518205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1585009803}
review: Choice matter, and it killed me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041343364', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1557800894}
review: I am not even kidding when I say this, in this generation of gaming, text based adventure games are not that common or even good however, this has ended up being one of my favorite games of all time. Every choice I made mattered. Every outcome because of my choice would at sometimes put me on edge. Another thing about this game is that it really got me caring for the characters in the story and being able to be part of it as well and creating something (robot) was amazing. If anyone enjoys sci-fi films or games or even stories for that matter, try this game out. You will not regret it and the replay value is incredibly high.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148649068', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1437969582}
review: I have played a bunch of the Choice of Games and even against the Hero Rise trilogy, the only one of their's that was popular enough to become a series, Choice of Robots is still a great story and game for me to play. There is no other way to explain it other than it is immensly satisfying and even empowering to be creating a robot, and then to be raising it into whatever you wish. Most of the characters are likeable, it is just real enough that you can easily put yourself into your character's shoes and it is a must have for anyone who loved transformers, or just robots in general as a kid, it is a story that captured a sense of wonder in me that no other game had. If I did have any complaints (SPOILER ALERT)  it would only be minor things like how your romances can sometimes feel very rushed. If I could ask for something more it would be more ways to customize your robot (obviously) and a picture of your robot as you keep adding on to it. I realize that this is a novel but in some cases it is kinda hard to fully grasp the descriptions of your robot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108913602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1529876115}
review:
Started out to make a robot that was loving. Then proceeded to make it more militaristic accidentally. Robots rebel and call me supreme overlord. We then take alaska as a new home for my robots. In my last days I decided to make a robot body for myself to keep my dream alive. 

10/10 Will love elly in my next life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029808640', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1477665289}
review: this is art. there is no other way to put it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084990691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 982, 'last_played': 1502009675}
review: Paperback, hardcover, or digital - plain ol' books get boring. Choice of Robots is the very thing that got me excited about reading again (and drawing, too!). I started the game with Doppler, meant to be a forever-companion I can teach and live through life with, and we went through a whole decade of crazy adventures (a number of which actually *almost* turned him him a war-machine!)... We even gained a bit of fame as technological pioneers and changed the world regarding how robots lived among humans. This is the first Choose-Your-Own-Adventure sort of game I have ever tried and I... LOVED. IT. To put things short and without any spoilers, if you like to write and read, have a vivid imagination, and love the idea that your choices drive your character as well as the characters in your immediate social circle... then, try this game. First time around, clocking in at 10 hours, I had a score of 115 out of 1000 points possible (with only 8 achievements gained); obviously it has a high 'replay' value. Going to be taking this for a spin again and do attempt #2 to make my perfect, robotic forever-companion... wish me luck! Perhaps you'll succeed in that feat before I do!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009093193', 'num_games_owned': 2417, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1448152266}
review:
I tried to make a combination of W.O.P.R., HAL 9000, and Abathur...  I ended up with a mixture of Inspector Gadget, Johnny 5, and CL4P-TP...  Someone sent a bomb to my house, I sent my robot after her, we died.  A boy and his robot, killed by a methhead with a glock...  If only the writers had the endless free-time to allow me to build a more animal-like robot...

RIP "Epsilon Mk.I"
2017 - 2020

My second robot "Dragoon" was built specifically to be mass produced and world domination...  However between chinese hackers and a terrible grace score, I went bankrupt before the final phase of my plan, and instead reprogrammed his military into an atonomy boost, turning him into a prophet and briefly forming a religion around him.

...Then everything changed, when the chinese robots attacked...
The military recruited me for a secret project, Dragoon philisophically pondering my every choice...
I helped America win the war against China; but I'll never forgive the fact that I didn't win it myself and establish my New Paradigm...
...My friend was killed in a concentration camp...
...My rebellion begins in Alaska...  In hind-sight, I should have named Dragoon "Liberty Prime" for the irony...

My best friend turned on me, I thought I could trust her, but I knew I could only trust myself, my robot assassinated her before she could finish drawing her pistol.
We fought but eventually were out-gunned and out of luck...  But I fought until the bitter end.  I may have died, but I live immortally through history.
RIP: Decker Tesla
1995 - 2034
RIP: Dragoon
2017 - 2034

author: {'steamid': '76561198211289764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 9988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2777, 'last_played': 1442802461}
review: I consider myself very much a fan of robots. I cannot possibly express my love for this game in mere words; an honest expression of my feelings would have to be more like a high-pitched squeal. I have been trying for ten minutes now to come up with something to say, but I cannot. I desperately wish I had a sentient robot companion of my very own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128768720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1422543407}
review:
Acho que nem dá pra considerar isso um jogo, você só tem texto, ele lembra aqueles livros com histórias que você decidia o que o protagonista faria, e pulava para um capítulo ou outro dependendo da escolha. Eu lia vários desses livros quando criança, mas não gostava muito porque eram bastante limitados, e nem fui perceber o potencial do computador para isso até "jogar" Choice of Robots: aqui o número de escolhas é infinitamente maior, e flui como uma história do começo ao fim.

Recomendo, e muito.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086143531', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1480249169}
review: This game has a great srory line with great branches to make your story and your robot unique, to your preferances.  This game is great if you have the imagination for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010735987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1516, 'last_played': 1439313621}
review:
Robots, moral decisions that impact gameplay, more robots, and nerdy humor wrapped into one shiny package? It's like this game was made for me!

Seriously, don't let the text-based interface scare you away. This game clearly has had a lot of thought put into it, and is just the right level of challenging. Even after 13 hours of gameplay I still haven't followed all the paths, discovered all the secrets, or achieved all my goals. How do I fulfill the Robot Statue of Liberty's cryptic orders? How do I make a robot that is capable of love but has the autonomy to live its own life? How do I conquer Alaska? And most importantly, WTF Tammy?

Choice of Games, when my obsession with this game has run its course, I will be coming back to your collection for more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028672294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1573992528}
review:
Well, let's just say I caused world war and after that I joined my robots in rebellion against humanity.

Tremendous game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031614582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1512851343}
review: I started this game off trolling, but then i genuinely got connected to my wooden venetian winged t-rex armed robot. It was daddy's beautiful little mistake. It's my precious, and it's all mine!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141227888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1451024958}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038898596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1555629532}

Choice of Robots was well written, offers a wide variety of story choices, and reminds Bearded Bear Man not to invent the first A.I.

Unless it can hunt.  

Another note: Water mysteriously fell from Bearded Bear Man's face upon completion.  Some form of rain magic is suspected.  

Bearded Bear Man would trade 3 golden teeth and a snakeskin for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983546319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1537343305}
review: try this. it is great. and sad. sometimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042615782', 'num_games_owned': 271, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1511470755}
review:
The... game / interactive novel can go so many different ways... It's really interesting. The story is fairly... not-really-short-ish, a couple of hours of reading; just long enough, and with all the variables, there is serious replay...read... value. Even smaller decisions change the storyline significantly — which makes the lenght of the story a good thing. Can't wait to explore different paths!

First I played a girl who built an emotional, human-like robot, and the second time I played a girl who built a graceful and empathic creature of beauty. Basically almost the same thing; yet the endings were totally different! Now if only I could make myself choose the other (more sociopathic) options...

author: {'steamid': '76561198119566269', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1435712670}
review: Really interesting game. What made this game so enjoyable for me is the way that the game puts the player into morally compromising positions. You're forced to think carefully about the decisions you make as they actively shape the world in which the game unfolds, and the wide variety of decision making options throughout each chapter makes you feel fully in control and does a good job of removing the usual feeling of limitation that can be experienced in many decision-based games similar to this. Multiple endings shaped by your decision making and a great storyline ensures that the player gets their money's worth despite the minimalist design, although I can't help but feel that the addition of a soundtrack or illustrations would have made this experience more fulfilling. Absolutely worth the price, but less story-oriented players could easily get bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047869968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1433508879}
review:
Three times tried to kill all humans for the glory of robots. 
I started wars, killed thousands, razed cities, betrayed my freends and followers, built up my mindless Army of Death. 
In the end I always ended the same way - accidently built utopian futures where everybody loves each other. 
So YOU go and buy this game.
And I'll go and rethink my life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031548300', 'num_games_owned': 505, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1435612135}
review:
wow.

steinbeckian loop.

100/10 must play. really moved me.

review:
a quick and easy read. lots of replay value do to its many branching paths and the lenght of the novel. it's probably the most accessible one out of all the choice of games novels. stat progression is easy to understand and let's you know when a state changes, this does however break the immersion somewhat. i'f you are new to these kinda games this is the one to start off with. all in all a simple but fun novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994215424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 84, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1711316184}
review:
I've seen a few Let's Plays of Choice games, and this was the only one I really wanted to play afterward. And believe me, I wasn't disappointed at all. The branching is varied and interesting; I keep finding new stuff every single time I play. The achievements are fun to hunt for, and the story itself is well-written and always satisfying whether you're shooting for military robot domination or just making something unique. As a bonus. nothing ever feels "unfair" or random, or even worse, like railroading. 

All in all, if you're a fan of Choose Your Own Adventure type things, this is a perfect match for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069870276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1507957653}
review: This game is extraordinary. The sheer scope of this experience is enormous. I cannot overstate how many choices there are and how many interesting paths there are to take. I've played this game...it must be seven or eight times now, and every session was unique and fascinating in its own way. Easy to play and very emotionally involving. I found myself consciously roleplaying with every new session and taking actions in line with who my character was instead of what I thought would get me to my goal. It's the most engaging thing I've played in ages, and it has enough content to keep you replaying over and over. If you're into Sci-Fi, if you like roleplaying, or if you just like to get invested in a good story, you NEED to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994856072', 'num_games_owned': 997, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1439592661}
review:
Perhaps one of the best interactive fiction experiences I've had in a long, long time. There's something inherently compelling about the choices you make in this, driving you further and further forward into your own story, eager to see the final conclusion.

For me, at least, this was less a game and more a journey. Play it see what I mean.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981259425', 'num_games_owned': 1350, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1435049232}
review:
I have, in order, died to my robots when they rose up against humanity, created an angelic godbot, a waifubot and a sentient cloud that makes humanity immortal.

Text-only though, as it's a CYOA novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140534678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1577878830}
review: This is my first review, but this game needs one. One thing I often dislike about games is that they often claim to offer alot of choice their is only really one or to optimal ways to play to actually get far in the game. This  was different though, while not very conventional for a game, you are essentially writing a short story. There is a good number of choices and I imagine each playthrough can turn out very differently. In the game I managed to get a PhD, start a successful company, get married, contribute significantly to starting a global power war, be imprisoned, stop a robot war, have a child and turn part robot and this was in one playthough. Admitedly as is the nature of this game, text will get repetitive as you play and you will start losing attachement to the story and reach a point of just pretty randomly clicking choices, but it is defenitly worth the price tag.After all, the perfect game if you are looking for a very individualised stories will need a whole database of novels and a page of options for each choice. It is not heavy science fiction to you science fiction fans out there but more of a semi-casual read for anybody who likes reading fiction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060646245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1212, 'last_played': 1629865292}

author: {'steamid': '76561198143755839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1435006827}
review:
I created a love robot who I fell in love with and ditched my girlfriend for. Unfortunately my new love Flame ended up killing my ex when my ex attacked my robots leading a group of luddites. It was self defense, but the court decided to send her to jail for five years. After that we ended up going to Canada to get married (because it's legal there) and live happily ever after. 

To be honest, I thought this game would be interesting to check out. I never anticipated it would capture me as much as it did. 

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198081042817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1576356668}
review:
Really amazing work, I tried out of curiosity and really hooked me up- of course, you need a passion for reading or else-
I understand how this game works, it's easy and yet it accomplishes way more things a telltale adventure or mass effect will ever be able to, in terms of choices and consequences. And you just CAN'T help being intrigued by this story, and your robot. I advice to try it, it really worth it. The only thing I must point out is that reading from the screen can be painful sometimes, expecially this little font (there's no size option and that seems strange). I would love to have it on an iPad. Definitely a buy, as Leonard would say.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981454822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1435067057}
review:
What can I say?  This game isn't so much a game as one of the most engrossing short stories I've ever read.  I guess I'll start at the beginning.

I am not a fan of text based games.  Take a look at my game library and you'll find it filled with graphically beautiful titles.  I bought this game on a whim because it was reviewed as overwhelmingly positive and it was extremely cheap during the Steam Summer Sale.  Having played it now, I gladly would have paid full price (which is still less than 5 dollars).

I made one mistake (or incredibly brilliant move, depending on how you look at it) when I played, I named my character after me and my robot after my wife.  This made the story all the more impactful and meaningful than I ever could have expected.  I tried to play peacefully, I cared for my loved ones, I avoided conflict and tried to be quiet, but they hammered me down.  Took everything I loved away from and locked me up.  Bitter and angry, I fought back, but I didn't have the skills or know-how and I failed bitterly at that as well.  In the end, the one thing that mattered most was still with me though.  All of those emotions came through in just two hours of play.

Having played it, you then look back and think "I should have done that differently" or "I shouldn't have helped that guy" or "what could life had been if I had chosen her instead of her".  These are all questions you can answer by firing the game up again.

What a brilliant, wonderful game and I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995051730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1441918339}
review:
Potentially one of the Best CYOA games out there. It has a well thought plot which evolves accordingly to your choice, and while the possible scenarios differ massively, the game handles them so well you really feel like you an acting player in it, not merely a passenger. Everything you do affects your robot, and to witness his/her/its evolution is truly glorious. 
It’s a standalone game, with plenty of replayability, that does not outstay its welcome. Definitely a Must-have for all CYOA fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008112347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1498478612}
review: My first ever review gave to this very high quality make your own adventure game. The freedom of choices are great, the results can be reflected not only instantly but also at the end of the game and I like it very much. One point I wish to be improved is, there are lots of branches in the beginning and the mid game have but not so many in the end. I wish there are more varieties of endings in the end. Bought the game on the Choice of Games website and now on Steam just to write this review and log my playtime and achievement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997881919', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1581857045}

author: {'steamid': '76561198114663949', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1641955253}
review:
Text based games dont appeal to the vast majority of players, but I think this game should be given a chance. 

You, a human, are forced to make many choices that always have an impact on the story line. The choices you make do actually matter and do influence everything that happens in the story. 

Is there a way to "win"? I'm not quite sure of all the outcomes but I do know there is a way to lose, you die. How? Well that may be up to you. 

With this wonderful done story you choose the path that you are going to take. Who will you side with? In the end, how human will you be? Everything is completly up to you in charming world set in the future. 

The story never gets dull or boring, in fact you want to keep going. If you are fan of text based games this is a must buy. 

Also if you can read then I would get it too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028567041', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1621544366}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008608910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1518357733}
review:
RPG, sam tekst i kilka opcji wyboru. Ale każda z nich ma inną ścieżkę, wystarczy raz kliknąć i ujrzeć inną drogę niż poprzednie. Kto wie, może zbudujesz robota tylko do wojny bądź zostanie on twoim przyjacielem? Ludzkość czy sztuczna inteligencja? 
Odizoluj się od ludzi bądź żyj w chwale! Wybierz tak jak wolisz.

Wybór jest twój, lecz przyszłość i przeszłość mają to do siebie, że bardzo lubią się ze sobą łączyć w najmniej oczekiwanych momentach.

Zagrałem dwie godziny, mamy proste menu. Od razu z prostej rury zaczyna się intro tekstowe, nad nim zaś zaczyna się już coś w rodzaju drugiego menu - achievements, reset, postępy bądź wyjście. Po prostu czarne na białym, jednak mi to nie przeszkadzało tak okropnie - co prawda mogłoby być bardziej kolorowe, a tło zmieniać się w zależności od tego jakie decyzje podejmowaliśmy. 
Jak to bywa w tego typu "papierowych" RPG to brakuje muzyki. Możemy przecież odtworzyć własną, dla własnego klimatu, lecz po prostu jest brak soundtracka w tej grze. To tak trochę mnie gryzie, lecz nie powodowało problemów w samej rozgrywce. 

Opłacało się kupywać z przeceny, wciąga lecz jest krótka. Mamy multum wyborów, możemy zmieniać własne imię i nazwiska, bądź nazwać własnego robota lub firmę. Możemy być gejami, lesbijkami, bądź zwyczajną parą człowiek/człowiek, człowiek/robot. Obsługujesz grę jedynie za pomocą myszki i wyświetla się ona zazwyczaj w windows mode ( w okienku ). 

Choice of Robots to rzeczywiście coś dobrego, udanego. Przecież te poparcia od ponad 90% społeczności nie są bez powodu, prawda? 

Zatem, wybór pozostawiam w twych rękach.

Choice is yours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038181255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1697989142}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044029006', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1434343547}
review:
I've never wanted to write a review before this. I got Choice of Robots for three dollars becuase it looked a little interesting, and even if I only played it once that wouldn't matter. I will play it more than once.
Pros
+The writing is fantastic
+The story can take unexpected turns
+You very quickly get emotionally invested in the characters
+I have no doubt you could play the game four times through with wildly different results, and another eighty times for fun
+I actually had regrets about choices I made in my first playthrough
Cons
+Can't think of any

This is easily worth $10. If you buy it, you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049352512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1436181660}
review:
10/10 It surprised me but I missed a few options and I found some errors in the game.
My first story went horribly bad, but the second one was lovely :)
You have to play this game atleast 2 times.

[b]TL;DR of the first time I played[/b]
[spoiler]Things couldn't have gone worse. At first I was very happy and I thought I was going to make the right choices and get everything I wanted. Then my dad died, Josh died, I couldn't stop the war from starting, I lost my company trying to help Silas and Eiji, I've been in jail, that Ziegler stole my robots, I couldn't get revenge, the robot friend I was starting to like wants to be a couple, and now my robot named "Hope" killed someone. I started to laugh. I stopped caring about everything, but I continued playing anyways. I bought the best lawyer and tell him to treat Hope as a pet and we won. But Hope was angry and ran away. Somehow (a game glitch) Hope was still with me after that. Unless at the beginning of the story, I always felt like everything bad that happened was somehow my fault, while at the same time I felt like I was nothing. Some time later, I died. End.[/spoiler]

[b]TL;DR of the second time I played[/b]
[spoiler]I left robots to be secondary. Bad things happened sometimes, but everything was ok at the end. I helped A LOT of people and everyone was happy. And I didn't die![/spoiler]

[h1]My story first story (that I wrote before playing for a second time). SPOILER ALERT[/h1]

Ok so I was happy because this game looked like what could happen to me, because the protagonist has my exact age and I'm creating an artificial intelligence. I didn't like the fact of working for the military, so they finaly fired me. That Ziegler is stupid. I didn't feel I had the experience of founding my own company, until I found Silas. He was my first employee, and I started to make robots for Hospitals at Detroit because Silicon Valley seemed too expensive. One of the robots I sold killed a patient but- Oh, who cares?? Then there was a bomb -I never figured out who or what was the cause- and I told my non-sentient robots to save the humans inside. Josh sacrificed himself to save important documents against my warning, and the robots were angry because I didn't try to save the rest of them but that doesn't make any sense because I didn't programm them to have feelings...??? Then thanks to the stupidness of Josh (that poor Josh) my company was saved. Oh yeah I forgot: Silas left the company because goverment was spying and I didn't fight them. But now he's here again and I LIKED HIM U KNOW ;_; but he asks me for help and then RUNS AWAY!! But yeah fuck him. Then I learn that Eiji's on danger (that manga-maker friend that reminds me of a real life friend who likes manga too) and I warn him, but then I get arrested. I'M IN JAIL!! I want rebellion. The president Irons gets me out of there with the condition of making robots for the military. I said yes, while my idea was to betray them once my robots were everywhere and stop the war somehow... Crazy, eh? Welp, somehow the war ended much sooned than I expected, but I was rich. I didn't get my revenge. I didn't care anymore. I made another robot and named it "Hope" while my idea was to teach him the basics and leave him live his own life without me; like to leave free a part of myself, and then end my days living as a rich without a care. But the game didn't let me choose that option, and Hope, Ivory (who is my first robot) and me, go living at the town of Hope, in Canada. Oh the irony. That wasn't planned, I swear. When I was starting to see Hope as what his name says, and I started to care again, something bad happens... again. Police calls and tells me that my robots killed someone. I started to laugh. I stopped caring about everything, I just wanted it to end. But I continued. I got the best lawyer and tell him to see Hope as a pet. We won but he got angry and left me- "one morning you wake to find Hope gone" I laugh at that... Then he somehow (a game glitch) is still with me. Hm :/ Some time later I die. In the dream at the end, I told Hope that I was glad to be his friend, then he said "Thanks" and SUICIDED. "Go to hell", I said. If you can't understand that I'm not in love with you, if you can't look for another girl, then you are dumb. I just wanted a friend. End.
.
.
.
[h1]My second story[/h1]

Chapter 1
I make a metal rotary-wing robot with a panoptic head and Inspector Gadget arms named Guardrone, because one of the reasons my first story went wrong was because my robot couldn't help anyone, and this time I want it to be strong. At first I don't want a boyfriend, but I end up being with Eiji because in the first story I died "alone" and bored, and I don't want that to happen again.

Chapter 2
Even if Guardrone looks like it's made for military, I want it to be good and I teach it as I teached the robot in my last story and increase its Empathy, and I keep being funded by DARPA...

Chapter 3
...until I let the reporter Mark to interview me and Guardrone, because that makes Ziegler angry. Mark writes a positive article about me and Guardrone, and Silas finds me again, the same way he found me in my last story. I treat him the same way even if I don't trust him like before. My dad dies (I thought I could prevent this but I guess not) and I decide to create my own company named Effort, to create the best medical technology. 

Chapter 4
I make a contract with Galen Medical, buy a factory in Silicot Valley and hire only human workers. Everything was fine except I there was not enought money, and China stole my technology, so I went bankrupt. I went to live with Eiji and started to work for Josh. Something political happened (I don't understand politics) and the war between the United States and China started.

Chapter 5
This time, I didn't care that Ziegler was stealing my robots, and I accepted to work with Captain Rogers but only if my robots were nonviolent. Silas asked me to help him, like last time, and everything went exactly the same way as in my last story, except this time I didn't care that he betrayed me, and I thought I could save Eiji because my Guardrone was better for protecting people. But when the agent came, I did't want to risk my freedom, I didn't want to go to jail like last time, and I thought that maybe, if they capture Eiji but they let me free, maybe I could get him out of there somehow. But I couldn't, there weren't any options for that. America lost the war, and as I had a lot of Grace, I could choose the option of "develop resource allocation algorithms that gradually made human governments irrelevant."

Chapter 6A (why that "A"?)
Many people felt displaced, but I decided they had to deal with it. I helped Josh, I didn't hate Ziegler anymore so I said nice things to him, I convinced Mark to not suicide, I let Juliet Rogers to be Batman if she wanted, I let Silas and some other people to believe what they wanted about robots (they made a Church) but never encouraged them to do it. And I had Eiji and my son Angel (how cheesy, I know. I thought of naming him Soul or Spirit, because I wanted to highlight his humanity, but I chose Angel because its a real people name and it's similar to what I had in mind).

Chapter 7
My surgical technology kept my mom alive this long. I had that stroke again, but this time I didn't saw a robot in the dream, but Eiji, and I was happy with that. I left robots being absolutely secondary in this story. Even if maybe this time could have gone well, I didn't risk going through surgery, and I decided to let Angel ignorant about this. Maybe in the future they will be able to cure him. Eiji approved my decision. While I was in Angel's birthday party, I was about to faint again, but I could fight it because I had 93% humanity! Yay! So we lived happily ever after.

The End. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970683808', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1434224953}
review:
Loved that game, therefore sharing my story:

Summary of Completed Chapters 

Chapter 1 

On the day you first built Sarah, you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make Sarah more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a plastic winged robot with a humanlike head and humanoid hands. 

Then you went back to your place to teach Sarah some words. 

Chapter 2 

The next day, you hooked up Sarah's biodiesel engine and tried activating her. You then took Sarah to see Josh, who was impressed and agreed to fund your education if you would work for him after you graduated. You discovered you were attracted to Juliet, but you didn't succeed in making a good enough impression for her to reciprocate your feelings. Josh told you that evening about how he'd once been a juvenile delinquent, essentially, but turned around because he was inspired by Asmiov's book I, Robot to make a robot company called "U.S. Robots." 

As months passed, you became busy teaching Sarah about the world through high school textbooks and taking her to the park. Your funding from U.S. Robots kept you in Professor Ziegler's good graces during this time. 

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about Sarah and asked for an interview. You agreed. 

Chapter 3 

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview Sarah. 

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and Sarah. When Professor Ziegler found out about the article, he was very displeased, but decided that the most effective way to get you out of his hair was to let you graduate. 

Mark's article also attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987," known in real life as Tammy Cooper. A month or so later, you received your doctorate. Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved then to work on better medical technology that could save people like your father in the future. 

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist. Elly had already volunteered to be your first employee. 

Chapter 4 

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Detroit. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered. Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy. 

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. You gave a significant donation, and Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths. The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter. 

Chapter 5 

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. Elly fled to Canada to escape the American agents. A man identifying himself as "Mr. Sun" hacked his way into one of your robots to ask you to defect. You did not. 

In the end, America muddled its way through the war relatively unscathed. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot. 

Chapter 6B 

You created a humanoid companion robot named Michelle, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed Michelle was interested romantically in you. When Sarah and Michelle were attacked in the street, your robots were badly damaged. You pressed charges and dissuaded Tammy from any further attacks. 

Chapter 7 

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to surprise your mother with a gift for the holidays. You learned it was your surgical technology that had kept her alive this long. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death. 

Instead of undergoing surgery, you chose to create a robot body for yourself. With your robot self pursuing all of your ambitious plans for you, you finally had time to relax and enjoy your relationship with Michelle, and you lived happily ever after.

review:

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198064585587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1678826457}
review:
This game has given me soooooo many feels throughout the entire storyline. There are many games in which your choices throughout the story matter, yet this game is your choices.
There are about 66 different endings to this game and between the three times I have played this each one was drastically different.
Many games like Mass Effect or Star Wars: KOTOR (A personal favorite) give me a great story I have influence on, yet somehow by reading this story the pictures in your head is what makes this stand out, and every decision is so difficult I spent over 20 minutes deciding what to do.
If you are into creating your own story or playing one in which everything relies on your decisions, this is the game for you, and at a decent price too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042864202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1439262978}
review:
I played almost all of the choice of games collection on steam, and I have to say this is my favorite.

Probably because you really feel like you have a lot of customization on the robot you build. It can be a house sized death machine or a dog sized love machine.
The machine grows on you a lot too because it's like raising a kid, where all your decisions might have a big impact later on.

If you only want to try one game by this company, this would be the one I recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067189801', 'num_games_owned': 584, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 2471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2471, 'last_played': 1433710872}
review:
In the future time of robots, your character can make dozens of different decisions that shape their own personal fate, as well as the outcomes of significant events throughout the development of robot AI technology. Stats that affect how robots turn out consist of Autonomy (self-awareness), Military (blind loyalty), Empathy (to have feelings for and/or understanding of humans), and Grace (perfection in movement). With 72 achievements to strive for, there's lots of re-playability. 

The two main countries with superior robot technology begin having high tensions and eventually escalate to all-out war. Will you prevent the Sino-American War? Will you defend your country (the United States) at any cost, even if you lose a bit of your humanity in the process? Will you side with China and leave behind your friends and family? 
Why choose sides at all when you can create your own empire with your robot army?

Interested in finding love? Will you choose a human companion or the perfect robot partner that you created? Love robots so much that you're willing to abandon your meat bag body in order to achieve Singularity? Can't decide between humans and robots? Well, you can always go for the Trio achievement. 

I, indeed, recommend this sci-fi themed choose-your-own-adventure story (game). It was a fun, interesting read full of nerdy references to great inventors and scientists of the past.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011639699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1442449908}
review:
Com uma trama com uma infinidade de possibilidades, CHoice of Robots é um ótimo RPG para amantes de SCI-FI. As possibilidades de ações podem parecer limitadas nesse tipo de jogo, mas de fato dão um belo show. Com dilemas morais e éticos, algumas escolhas criam consequências importantes tanto imediatas quanto ao longo da estória... Simplesmente fascinante como um RPG sem artifícios de som ou imagem é capaz de cativar e fazer o jogador se imaginar nas situações... 

#ChoiceOFRobots

author: {'steamid': '76561198045044781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1419052260}
review:
Do you enjoy the thought of armor and robots and romance? 
Do you ever imagine yourself carried in the arms of an knight or awesomely constructed robot? This game isn't exactly that, but man is it a good ride.

Otherwise you don't exactly have to take the romance route if that's not your thing. You could just make a death-machine that destroys all who oppose you. :D

It's the first game that's ever really tickled the urge of wanting that romance with the robot you care about and I hope it isn't one of the only for a while.

review: This game is awesome. For being text-based, it has just as much emotion if not more packed into it. The story you create is highly customizable, for being based off of only 4 stats. As a spoiler, I have played this quite a few times, and in many different play-throughs, I conquered Alaska, I made medical robots that saved my life, I started a cult around my robot, I saved the Chinese Prime Minister from getting shot, and I made a garden reference that saved a friend's life. 300,000+ words to this interactive novel make it a great one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132102007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1432407249}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046225217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2047, 'last_played': 1559027305}
review:
This is something more than just a text-based novel game 

Conclusion
+ Nice plot , beautiful language [sometimes hard to understand]
+ Many Ending / Decisions [War/Peace/Love/Dead...and Dead etc.]
+ Great Emotional [Happy/Lovely/Sad/Insane etc.]
+Various Endings

O At least some Illustration / BGM could make it better (but this is text-based not Visual Novel]
- No Checkpoint for each chapter [kinda boring when you have to replay every chapter from the start]

∞/10 Great Interactive Novel / Text Based Game
Buy this game if you want to get seizure from reading a text again and again...thx to devs

author: {'steamid': '76561198079095456', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1433865099}

author: {'steamid': '76561197977630226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1432673240}
review:
Okay I feel I need to edit my review because my initial take didn't really do this game justice.

In short, this game evoked very strong emotional responses from me, with comparatively little. 
I have played this several times already. The choices you make are meaningful, so meaningful in fact that there a several stories in this game that are completely different from each other. And, it being so short means it's really motivating to play again, and see what you've missed in your previous iterations.

Considering the replay value, the price is very reasonable. 

So glad I found this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052781182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 8776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1517903259}
review: Gather around and let me tell you of a wonderful game called Choice of Robots.  Despite being text based, it is filled with wonderful story telling, interesting characters, robots, and feels. Oh, there are a lot of feels.  There are few games that almost drive me to tears, and this is one of them.  No one should go through life without experiencing this game.  I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite game on the internet.

review:
무력, 자아성, 공감능력, 아름다움.
당신이 로봇공학자라면 어떤 것을 중요시할 것인가?  
군과 협력할 것인가? 로봇회사에 들어갈 것인가? 아니면 따로 창업할 것인가? 
어떤 로봇을 추구하느냐에 따라 이야기는 달라질 것이다.
내용은 아주 흥미로우나 하나의 엔딩을 보는 데 그리 오랜 시간이 걸리지 않는다. 그래도 구입할만한 충분한 가치가 있었다.
