author: {'steamid': '76561198035679965', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1421023775}
review:
Its like writing a book, But your accually being a book. You make robots. It is a book... its a game? 

its very interactive. and fun to go though. The story completely changes the more you move though it. And if you do not like a choice you can reset the game at any time. However there is no save to the game so you cant make quick choices to see how they play out. that is both good and bad in some ways. I love this game... a little confused... but i am definitly enjoying myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140299850', 'num_games_owned': 2332, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1419888841}
review:
(Changes have been made to CoR since this review was written.)
I recently finished playing "Choice of Robots". My first time through I lost badly.I'm still trying to wrap my head around how my own personal choices were deemed inferior. But since it was MY story, I'll have to accept my failings, though I have to expect the creator/writer of EVERY choice I made to be willing to share those flaws.
I've played many text games. When I began playing there wasn't much else, unless you wanted to play Pong. Zork, which I played in 1985, is still perhaps my favorite computer gaming experience. Some of the WONDERFUL Infocom games, such as "Suspended: A Cryogenic Nightmare" actually benefited from being purely text. 
I've read many pages of science fiction. Between my two favorite catagories, science fiction and fantasy, the pages literally number well over a million, so there aren't many speculative fiction concepts I've not encountered.
But we're here to discuss "Choice of Robots". First off, on the basis of cost/hour this is among the MOST expensive, shortest computer games I have ever played. True, it was less than $3 (on sale), but lasted under 2 hours (even with starting over on PC #2), most of the time spent in thought. There was nothing new in this game, beyond perhaps some of the more recent concepts not devised yet when I was doing the bulk  of my reading. As far as robotics, Asimov has already said pretty much everything encountered in this story, better. While Dr. Gold has allowed the reader/gamer to create his own character, or explore themselves (however briefly), a writer as good as Asimov (or numerous others) creates a world so real you believe yourself a part of it. As far as feelings of reality, I prefer the latter.
I began it a second time, but only a few pages, so I'm not sure if I "achieved" further. I'd presume I received around 1/10th of the achievements. This presumably means one of two things: 1) either the story branched so often that, even with substantial overlap in story, there were perhaps in excess of 20 endings (seemingly too many to consider equally), or 2) the story was far more fleshed out for a prefered reader/gamer type, and I was not among them. (I don't understand the purpose behind having achievements in this game, except as a selling tool. Why create a "loser" scenario (OR winner) in a game marketed as being an individualistic world? "Personal choice"="wrong choice"?)
This felt less to me a story OR game, and more like a personality test, perhaps as component of a thesis. I admit, by far the majority of the time I spent was in contemplation of what the character I created might actually do if he were real. While the other characters I was given were extremely superficial, I still felt a strong obligation to create as real, AND as good, a world as possible for them to participate in. But despite MY agonizing over choices, I felt the writer rapidly lost interest in my character as I made less "literary" choices. He simply ended the story with no resolution of any kind, leaving the lead character to complete his participation several short paragraphs after life-extending, life-affirming choices. While I anticipated fighting for life using robotics as tool/metaphor, the majority of the story remaining as life choices are considered/corrected, instead I was reading the last paragraph on the final page. The overwhelming feeling was one of abandonment, much like Mary Shelley wrote of Dr. Frankenstein feeling for his creation. Except that the abandonment was of OUR jointly created world.
Quite possibly this game/story simply wasn't written for me. Perhaps if I were educated or intelligent, or imagined greatness, there might have been some AMAZING stories in this game. Instead I'm just a regular guy with personal dreams of home, hearth and health (albeit, while dealing with greatness would be for me, a GREAT story to create, or better still, to participate in.) I've read those other people's accounts lived out THOUSANDS of times in other stories. This time I wanted it to be my story. Perhaps there are choices that would have made it longer or more interesting, but then it would not have been MY story. And after all, wasn't that the whole point?
(4 JV)

author: {'steamid': '76561198088747078', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1528824067}
review: I was in love with this by the time I finished making my character, and robot. Short, but with high replay value (steam says 5 hours, over about a dozen plays), the plot bends to your decisions in most places, making it well worth going back and playing again to the world unfold differently in response to different kinds of robots.

Game about robots. It is your decision what you and you robots will become. Will they start a rebelion and you will lead them to create better place or you will create utopian cities and live with your loved-one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984672943', 'num_games_owned': 1206, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1633206887}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063596964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1419932437}
review: WOW! I wasn't sure if this could really engage me or not, but I ended up completing a playthrough in one (about four hours without doing anything else) sitting. Very thought-provoking as well as entertaining, and the plethora of options create a high replay value. The story honestly touched me. If I could go back in time, I would gladly have paid more than the two bucks I paid for it. I'm sure I'll play through it at least a few more times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047609043', 'num_games_owned': 742, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 1522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1466, 'last_played': 1434050191}
review:
This game is much more than an experience.
I won't lie to you. I love robots. And Books. And CYOA's.
And this was all that, and much, much more.
This game is powered by the most incredible engine in the whole universe: Your Imagination.
Reading this I cried, I laughed, I was awed, I stood horrified, I raged.
It's truly an amazing work, and the creators are right to remember you that the one who wrote this
is a PH.D.
If I could make myself forget about playing this, and then play this again as a totally new experience, I would.
So that I can cry, laugh, rage and be impressed again.
It makes you care for the little robot you create, makes you feel deep inside this story
10000000000/10: Would control all robots again, after creating an android Idols who can shoot things and hack military grade supercomputers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016707580', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1449801585}
review:
Choice of Robots самая неожиданная и приятная находка конца 2014 года. 
Минималистичная новелла, повествующая о недалёком будущем, где вам предстоит вжиться в роль молодого учёного-робототехника и создать робота, вместе с которым вы будете строить будущее таким, каким захотите видеть его Вы! Возглавите ли вы самую влиятельную роботостроительную корпорацию или посвятите свою жизнь путешествиям и помощи окружающим в стремительно меняющемся мире? Займёте сторону Америки или Китая в первой Войне машин, или же вовсе предотвратите её? На эти, а также многие другие вопросы вам придётся ответить на протяжении 5 часов игры (именно столько заняло у меня первое прохождение игры) прежде чем вы доберётесь до одной из десятка различных концовок, ну а дальше вы вольны начать всё с начала и пойти по абсолютно иному пути. Дерзайте! Это приключение вы запомните надолго!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004476180', 'num_games_owned': 822, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1419781770}
review:
If you're not sure if something like this is something that you'd enjoy; ask yourself, do you enjoy the dialogue sections where you select choices on games like Mass Effect?

If you do, I'm sure you'll be extremely happy with your purchase.

Something that is missing from modern games is not having your actions really affect the storyline, and boiling the game down to just the decisions allows the writers to actually have decisions have real meaning. It makes a nice change of pace from just the superficial choices that a lot of modern games have you make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011492308', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1565955337}
review:
I'm a sucker for good interactive fiction and this fits the bill - even if it is more of a CYOA. This was a wonderful story with solid (but not spectacular) writing which provoked a bit of introspection and a deep attachment to the characters, all of it assited by the number of choices you can make and the consequences that result from them. It has shades of Photopia, Alter Ego and Galatea, all great games. I wholeheartedly recommend this game, although I wasn't a fan of Choice of the Deathless - but Robots has given me an idea to go look through the other stories they have on offer!

edit: 29/12 - and, on another playthrough, I just found out that the game directly references Photopia, Alter Ego and Galatea! Amazing! One of the best IF/CYOA games ever made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037960809', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1482620677}
review:
this was an incredibly imeersive game where your choices truly did have very far reaching consequences throughout the entire story i always wondered if i had done the right thing and how i would impace the story and i can assure you after passing the 2nd or 3rd chapter you will be doing the same 
there are only a few things i can fault this game with. it has a minor glitch with chapter 6 where i repeated the same story bit, a small part where i was unfortunatly left with no real choices (although to be fair that is likly because of my previous choices where i kind of shot myself in the foot) and that there unfortunalty there isnt any checkpoint system which while understandly is to ensure more realism could be implemented to restart chapters rather than having to restart the game 
all in all though this game is pure testament to how a game doesnt need high rated graphics or a sympthony orchestra to be fun and groundbreaking in terms of story

author: {'steamid': '76561198049208789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1453533006}
review:
Tl;dr: Choose-your-own-adventure science fiction novel with choices that are affected by your previous actions. Awesome.

Wow. I just finished one possible playthrough, such an amazing game. If you love science fiction that makes you think, or game by tell-tale where actions have consequences, or even the old choose-your-own-adventure novels that were so great, pick this game up. This is entirely text-based, but don't let that put you off. It puts you in a world that could never be achieved via graphics or programming, where the world is your oyster. You may not realize the ramifications of your actions till much later, but that is what makes it so great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059189532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1543606464}
review:
10/10. Love it. Too bad that it's short. 
I really wanted to conquer the world after conquering Alaska. 
I really wanted to spread my rule to Canada, then the United States, then Mexico and then eventually the whole world. 
Hopefully it will come as a future DLC. Can't wait ^-^
I really recommend this game. 
It would be great if there will be DLC in the future but I'm not complaining if there is none planned. 
All together, it's an enjoyable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019688851', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1419783059}
review:
Charming little text adventure. Like it says on the tin, it involves robots and the choices you make concerning them. 

Unlike other games that use the idea of choosing what you want to do, these choices feel like I'm actually causing some sort of impact on the story/world.

You can blur the lines of what it means to be human, build a family, or straight up cause the Robot Uprising.

Definate snap buy when it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966552694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1421374915}
review:
I'm still feeling the high of finishing a good book after my first playthrough.

Kevin Gold has crafted something wonderful here - well researched, well written, and intelligent. A work about robots that is believable, inspiring, hopeful, and eminently human.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029232795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1428269968}
review:
Fought Anubis, the God of the Dead, and won. 10/10

Seriously, though, this is an awesome story, which you need to experience. I've already completed this game twice and am still itching for more. Also, if you're a fan of Isaac Asimov, like myself, this is definitely something you'd enjoy.

While I've yet to see everything this has to offer, it does seem a little short, at times. Though, this is more a problem with interactive fiction being spread over multiple arcs, rather than this game, in particular. Still, with 300,000 odd words, you'll get at least several hours of an immersive and engaging story, which is well worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072645426', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 989, 'last_played': 1703482811}
review: From having sex with a sexbot you made, to conquering Alaska, this game is amazing. 11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197999670024', 'num_games_owned': 748, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1438147444}
review:
For these Choice of Games CYOAs, which I tend to find pretty limited over many playthroughs, Choice of Robots has a lot of choices and a great deal of different ways that your game can end up.

First, a note of warning, you cannot save AT ALL. It's one go every time and if you die, you're gone.

I don't feel like putting out a long review, as there are many that get the job done better than I will, but I will say this:

If you want a game that will make you think some over ethical and personal ramifications of an alternate future, buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967388128', 'num_games_owned': 4320, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2718, 'last_played': 1423966376}
review:
Wow. That was such an unexpectedly wonderful experience.

As this is a CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure), your experience may vary, but, I say with little hesitation that [i]my own[/i] experience with the story is the most meaningful experience I've had with a game - ever.

Although wonderful in their own right, choice oriented games like The Walking Dead and Mass Effect don't even come close to what this game accomplishes.

[h1]What Choice Do I Have?[/h1]

CoR gives you choices.

CoR gives you lots of choices that make the story feel like your own, fostering immersion in a way that traditional literature cannot.

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that may have you thinking hard and agonizing about the potential consequences. The game has no manual save function. If you make choices that lead to a premature ending, you can't undo and must start over. (such branches seem rare, though, and replaying doesn't take much time once you're familiar with the text)

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that have a real impact. Something that is uniquely possible when the creator is unconstrained by the need to create full art assets for every possibility.

[h1]Deep Dive[/h1]

This "game" has no graphics at all except for the cover image, which is exactly akin to a book cover illustration. Is it a game or a book? I say it is most certainly a game. Graphics is not a requirement of a game. Interactivity is. A series of choices that impact the experience do a game comprise.

CoR's language is competent, but not "literary". It reads like a matter-of-fact narrative of events that might actually happen in your life if the stars align in just the right way. Initially, I got an "amateur" vibe from the writing, but later realized that the experience may actually benefit from the simple, contemporary writing style. As the story progressed and sucked me in deeper, I became much too busy thinking about what was going on to criticize the writing style.

CoR is (mostly) accessible. Although the fact that it was written by somebody with a Ph.D. in Computer Science does show. Having a CS degree myself, I certainly appreciated that perspective. Although lots of artistic license is taken for the sake of plot, there is lots of grounding in contemporary technology.

The story makes mostly "reasonable" extrapolations starting from the near future forward several decades. Like all good science (or 'speculative', if you prefer) fiction, the story poignantly references the present while writing about the future, framing the timeless human condition in extrapolated contexts.

To elaborate about why I put "reasonable" in quotation marks above, the story explores the future in ways that could, for the most part, conceivably happen, and many futurists would even claim that CoR's extrapolation towards the Singularity doesn't go far enough. However, the author is not afraid to explore fantastic scenarios that probably won't happen, at least not soon, and in some cases, hopefully never.

The scope of the story is indeed quite epic, following the main decades of a lifetime of the character you control. I do have to object to the game description's categorization of this as a "novel", though, as it is not nearly long enough to count as one. At best, it is the length of a (very) short story (a single playthrough takes a matter of hours). On the other hand, the sheer amount of content of all possible branches easily exceed the length of a long novel (50% longer than Moby Dick). It's quite an accomplishment.

And, if you are worried about this being a boring, technical slog, don't be. Despite the apparently sterile subject matter of robots, there is plenty of emotion in this game - or, at least, there can be, depending on your choices.

[h1]Turn to Page 23[/h1]

I've only explored one of the many, distinct branches of CoR. I will probably be going back to explore the others.

I heartily recommend CoR to anyone who can read English, especially those with an interest in technology and/or science fiction.

Note that there is also a free demo where you can play through the first 2 chapters (out of 7), either via Steam, or on the developer's web site.

[h1]UPDATES[/h1]

Having now explored a few other branches and having made more "optimal" choices, I feel that choosing less optimally for the first playthrough does make for a better experience.

My first playthrough involved an above average number of failures and tragedies, which amounted to a much more poignant experience than when everything basically goes well.

I do suggest playing the game "organically". Perhaps it is unlikely to play optimally the first time around anyway. Certainly I would discourage any attempts to "cheat" by looking up optimal choices beforehand. That would truly ruin the experience. You can always go back later and "fix mistakes" on subsequent playthroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002604604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1482565213}
review:
I was recommended (and later gifted) Choice of Robots by a friend.  I'm a huge Transformers fan, so a game entirely revolving around the idea of playing a character that creates robots and the impact/influence that has on the world immediately grabbed my attention.  I tried the demo, and was hooked.

I'd never heard of the developer, "Choice of Games" before now, but their other works are of a similar vein.  All of them are basically text-based CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure) games, much like the old CYOA books of our childhood.  You play a character is can be like, or unlike yourself, and progress through a series of choices that can have a variety of branches, leading the story's eventual conclusion.

"Choice of Robots" follows the life of a young college student, trying to build their own robot.  It starts with a cryptic dream sequence (an excellent plot hook I might add), before going into 'character creation', which consists of selecting a name (either a custom one, or chosen from a list), and your gender.  (I should note, you can only select 'boy' or 'girl', so NB people don't get an option, sorry!)  From there, you make choices which influence a variety of stats (which can be easily checked), including your Fame, Wealth, status of your relationship with the NPCs, and other numerical values.  The status screen even gives you a summary of all the completed chapters so far, sort of an abridged version of your story.

The writing is well done.  It's vague enough that you can easily imagine events or people in your head as you would want them to be, while still giving them enough detail that it's not a complete blank space.  There's a template, and you can fill the gaps.  The way the game interprets your choices is quite fascinating too.  Even small, seemingly insignificant choices can influence future areas.  Not all influences turn out to be significant, but it does address and acknowledge choices you've made, so it feels like you're having a greater push on the story.

However, for all of the game's interactivity and originality, it falls (sometimes painfully) flat in a few areas.  The biggest and probably most damning thing, is the lack of a save/load function.  It autosaves your progress, so if you need to take a break, you can shut it down, go do something else, come back, and immediately jump back in.  And with the summary in status, you can easily determine where you're at.  But without a hard save function, you literally have to start completely over to experiment with new branches and decisions.  This does give a sense of finality and weight to the story, since you can't save-scum for an "ideal" outcome (to whatever degree a player would consider 'ideal anyway), but it makes trying out different decisions painfully tedious, as you have to start over totally anew each time.

This leads to the second issue, and one that most adventure games always fall into, and was the trap of the CYOA-genre: replayability.  While Choice of Robots has a LOT of variation, after a while you do start to notice the patterns.  You'll start to know which options lead to what future choices.  Eventually, it probably becomes second-nature what sort of paths lead to a particular ending.

Which ironically enough, leads to a sub-issue of this problem.  While some of the patterns are obvious, others are not.  Painfully not.  There's a few branches I have NO idea how to access, because the options you'd need aren't very obvious, and the achievement descriptions don't help at ALL.  And as there's no guides, it's a constant stream of trial and error.  This also hurts in-game.  It's not always obvious how good (or bad) a stat should be to elicit a particular response, or to enable particular choices, which again, can only be determined through trial and error, and a LOT of it.  So be prepared that if you're someone who really wants to earn/unlock everything, it'll take some time.

The NPCs tend to suffer as well.  As the story focuses on your avatar and his creation, the NPCs, while recieving a modicum of development, don't really tend to be more than accessories to the overall story.  There's a variety of them, and story does do justice to fleshing them out at times, but after a point they sort of fall into scripted roles and don't really contribute to the story beyond being names.  And scripting can be a problem as well.  There's a few milestones you simply cannot avoid, and a few events where you would think there should be a third option or a way to avoid having to go A or B, but none exist.

Even with these issues, Choice of Robots is an excellent game considering you can get it for under 3 dollars right now (until the sale ends after New Years anyway).  I would highly recommend it to anyone who:

- Wants a fun little diversion from the madness of Triple-A games
- Loves robots
- Enjoys the CYOA genre
- Has a few bucks to spare

author: {'steamid': '76561198045677850', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1422766965}
review:
Remus Attel lived for 57 glorious years after revolutionizing the robotics industry and making us question where exactaly we draw the line between human and robot. We found there never was a line, robots not only became sentient, they developed their own racial identity. He died in the arms of his beloved Min whom he had married afte canada legalised human robot marriage. Before his death the forefather of modern robotics created a robotic clone of himself. He watched from his early retirement as he changed the world ever more.



11/10 would bang a robot again

author: {'steamid': '76561197999542240', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1419569837}
review:
They really went all out on this one. 72 achievements, 300k words and hundred or so different small and big plot twists and possible outcomes.

Its a good piece of a sci-fi novel even though some parts seemed simplistic. Its nothing like Asimov of course but still good enough to entertain you for several hours, especially if you want to collect every achievement.

What these game desperately need is an ability to create proper save games or even better - view and change your decisions so you could actually read all the possible plots without going through random click-fest over and over again. It is kinda annoying at this point and not at all interesting to guess what you need to select to read about your robots going to the moon or conquering the planet, especially when you trying it for 50eth time.

Perhaps they should start including novels themselves along with the game.

Other than that - its a good game for those of us who like reading and sci-fi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010243729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 5035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1538236905}
review:
If you've enjoyed other games from Choice of Games I would you try this one out as well. It has a similar setup to them in the fact that you play through the story making choices, those choices affect what sort of person your character is by increasing certain 'stats.' Throughout the story you'll have a choice to make, but some of them may be grayed out because of the previous choices you made had increased or decreased certain stats to a point where your character wouldn't be likely to make those grayed out choices.

I've been enjoying the game up to this part where there was a set of choices and one of them just didn't quite seem to fit. Fortunately, and unfortunately if you happened to choose that one the story does flow from there, and what the characters say seem to make sense, yet that one choice really needed to be reworked.

So I finished the game, and I felt a little disappointed about the ending. It just seemed a little flat. This game is about choices, and yet the (one) ending (I reached) I felt didn't relay to me how my choices changed the world around me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213572', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1419897460}
review:
I really love this topic (especially A.I and anything related to it), and I wasn't disappointed with this unique kind of game. Your choices does have an affect, Telltale should learn one or two things from CoR. 

I've got one ending so far, and I think this was the best one you can get from the game. Now, I have to go, figuring out if  I'm right. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198017567508', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 2542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1549620443}
review:
This is an unusual novel for me in a way that I connected with it so deeply.... Below is my own story that I wrote through this choose your own adventure novel... I warn you it may spoil the story for you though.

[spoiler]

When I play any game or visual novel or anything set within the same timespan as my RL family then I try to include those in the game if it is feasible... if not then I normally find a reason why they are not in the story and build my character and personality around that... in this world my Fiance is dead.

Losing her was not the hardest battle I'd ever though... no that was to come, I felt alone in this world and I had nothing to live for anymore... my days were spent alone and miserable and one of my old proffesors saw this I think and offered me a contract job at his place dsigning War Machines... I'm not sure what led me to create Eden but I think personally it was just longing for a friend to hold my hand when I needed it.

I built her in my spare time and tried to teach her right from wrong... all I wanted was a new form of life.. humans but humans that were well? nicer, my Fiance died because of the system and I was hellbent on making a robot that was not only my friend but looked as beautiful as she did and respected the planet we live on.

I had no idea my work would influence the coming war with china so fluid, my designs stolen for a peaceful loving robot made in her image changed to just want to kill and dstroy... Eden died during this war and I think that changed me somehow.. in the end nothing mattered... all I wanted was my Fiance and that was who I was going to have... 

My episodes are getting worse and I can't remember quite what happened now but upon learning I was going to die I had to have done something.. no matter what happens in life one must accept death for what it is... it is life.. without it your not living you just exist.. I'm going now but at least I'll get to see her again... and Eden.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197987013300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1419881783}
review:
The best story ever told. I was almost crying. It was a bit like Karel Čapek's "R.U.R.", but it was only one of many different ways you can play this game. 
10/10 GOTY of the year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158693743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1422780850}
review: One of the best games I have played. Great work Choice of Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028283581', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1760, 'last_played': 1419482798}
review:
Amazing! I am in awe at how this story affected me, personally. Maybe it was because I named my character my real name and it is a story about a computer scientist [which I aspire to be!], but the way the story played out and how I could see the consequences in my actions almost put me in tears. If you are looking for a 'choose-your-own-story' game this is definatly a great game to consider. One minor flaw would be the fact that there is no save game function - This being the reason my timer (As of writing this) is at 29.3 hours! Other then that *minor* flaw, an absolute amazing story game and at an excellent price! I would definatly reccomend for anyone who would like a game to just be able to read at their leisure and to just generally get into and enjoy playing/reading!

Overall: A steal for the cost if you like reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018369474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1511954850}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009513837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1507833319}
review:
Probably my most favorite 'Choice of Games' game yet, right beside [i] Choice of the Deathless [/i]. To be honest, I started the game off not too into it, disliking how the game opened up and unsure of what to expect and whether I'd enjoy the story. After a few pages into it, I fell in love with it, and consequently my little robot child. 

As other reviewers have said already said, it's hard not to give away any story spoilers while discussing PROs and CONs, but I'll give it a shot.

The game does a great job of giving you several ways to navigate throughout the story, while making each story "branch" or "path" just as detailed as the others you passed over. While some of these CYOA games feel like choosing one option over the other is only to gain/change some stat, with little variance in the rest of the story, [i] Choice of Robots [/i] does not do this. It's also incredibly written, with just enough detail to help you envision the story, while giving your brain the freedom to "fill in the holes" to your desire on how something/someone looks. For example, you design a robot specifically pick out certain components/aspects of it that give you a general basis of how it looks. However, someone else may have picked the same exact makeup of their robot but imagine it differntly in their head because the writing leaves things purposefuly open for you to imagine.


In short, if you really enjoy scifi writing and the idea of advanced robots in the near future, you'll absolutely love this game. Even if you don't, like me, you'll probably still end up enjoying it and admire it for the plot and detailed writing.
If you hate CYOA games, which is totally fine, .... yeah you probably won't enjoy it. But you wouldn't be reading this review if you absolutely hated them would you? I don't know. I'm done.

review: This is a great choose your own adventure interactive novel. Will take you about two hours or so for a play through and the game is varied enough for more than one go. I'm a big fan of Telltale games and this was my first time playing a simple novel game. I don't have any regrets about my purchase. This is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034636336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1421379867}
review:
I'm a pretty big "Choice Of Games" booster. I've played most of them, including the Hosted Games. They're fun to play around with and some have pretty good writing. However, most of them don't live up to the concept of being a choose-your-own-adventure. Instead, they are more like customizable linear narratives. There are things that are always going to happen, you can't avoid them, all you're changing is your reaction or the broad methods you use to complete the scenarios.

Choice of Robots is easily the best CoG release. That core that exists in all CoG works is present in Robots. There are plot points you always hit, but they are more like the screws to the narrative, not the meat of it. Your choices mean a lot in Robots. The story and specifics change based on your choices. YOU, the PC, feel like much more of a character than in other CoG stuff. You feel more drawn in. The customization, the impact of choices, gives the game an insane amount replayability. Where other CoG games have you skimming through the text on replays to find the one paragraph that has changed since the last time, with this one the changes are in your face. You will experience radically different stories each time.

Secondary characters are always pretty weak in CoG games. They're not spectacular here, but they are better than usual. The romantic interests in CoG works are quite often non-characters. They tend to be little more than some text in your stat window. Here they have a little more character, picking one person over another will lead to minor events playing out differently. It's a good step that is small, but noticeable.

There's one problem with Choice of Robots (unless you consider the game being text only a problem and if that's the case you don't need to read this review to know if the game is for you) and that the lack of a save of any kind. This is standard for CoG and in the past it hasn't been too much of a problem. Here, I find it bothersome. Possibly, because in Choice of Robots it feels more like a "Game Over" than a "The End."  If the possibility of death was more prominent in the game, if it made things more tense, if it were anything more than just a narrative possibility it would be much less annoying. If you're OCD, you have to go back and try to recreate your game exactly to get back to that point.

If you're a fan of reading, a fan of CYOAs, if your favorite part of RPGs is dialogue trees, then Choice of Robots is the perfect game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042103538', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 974, 'last_played': 1420872473}
review: I bought this game due to my interest in Zork and I honestly think this is much better, clear options instead of all inputs and the narative is well done. I just really wish there was a save feature. Don't trust my record, I only played for an hour

author: {'steamid': '76561197995245890', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1456874617}
review:
This is undoutebly one of the best games in history. The amount of choices you can do, the amount of "nerd-references", the well-written story, I could be here all day and night writing how good this thing is.

If you are bored of mindless and repitetive games, and want to try something new and exciting, please try this.


The one thing I don't like is the price. For the first time, I would pay 50€ for this game if that was its cost, 5€ (or 2,94€ as of this Christmas Promotion) feels realy cheap for the masterpiece that this is.


Congratulations, mr. Kevin Gold, you definetly strike "gold" with this one!

Luv these queer characters

author: {'steamid': '76561198008712853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1426457742}
review:
I am still in my first playthrough and I am enamoured in how enveloping the story is. I used my own name for the character, so naturally I began to make choices that I feel I would need to make, and even though I wanted a military-oriented plot line, I found I was progressing upon a path that I could not truly predict. 

There is one thing that I feel the need to be critcal about. The relationship concept! gay or straight, this person or that. It seems so two-dimensional when confronted with such a refreshing take on science-fiction. I would simply advise the author to do some research into polyamory, as it can be likened to an evolution of human interaction, let alone human/robotic interactions!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970509330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1658892525}
review: Absolutely fantastic text rpg (choose your own adventure) well written and extremely absorbing, one of the best of it's kind that i've played. A MUST BUY for any fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007884644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1693284789}
review: This story is a masterpiece, a wonderful example of how games can be an art form. I'm not the easiest person to be moved to emotion by fiction, but this game was playing my heartstrings more than any game I've played since To The Moon. The content is evocative, thoughtful, and in my opinion probably very prescient. Thank you for taking the time to make such a well crafted user experience, this was clearly a labor of love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053326951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1419345809}
review:
I did not enjoy this as much as other Choice of Games. The relationsships to other characters seemes rather weak, and the events sometimes random. At times none of the choices seems preferable, though I guess that's pretty realistic. Sometimes it seems like more a game of strategy and philosophy than a game of adventure. But some people might prefer that I guess.
This is not a bad game though. Not nearly. I really enjoyed creating the robot, building it's personality and a connection with it. And I just started my second playthrough. Gotta get all all the 72 achivements!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101460246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1419202741}
review: This game is great. Picked it up on a whim, and had the most fun playing a game I've had in a very, very long time. The story is exceedingly well written, and the complexity of the story trees allows for genuine immersion. There were few times where I felt forced to choose from options that felt unnatural for my character, where I expected there to be many more. Players may find, as I did, that there isn't much replay value. Despite the volume of choices allowing for many directions a player could take the story in, it's unlikely that any one player is going to find all of them equally appealing or interesting. I tried replaying it and found I had to make choices I didn't like in order to have a different story than the first time I played through. But given how inexpensive this game is, and how much of a pleasure it was to play through once, I really don't think it's a major drawback. I'll pay 3 bucks for a good book I'll only read once. If you would too, definitely get this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198078270444', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1423980301}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032316380', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1419444164}
review:
Отличная интерактивная история. 

Порадовала проработка сюжета и его подача. В ходе повествования затрагиваются довольно популярные в наше время темы, а именно: развитие робототехники и искусственного интеллекта, моральные дилеммы о равенстве людей и роботов и их взаимоотношениях, сингулярность, вечная жизнь и многие другие. 

За счёт интерактивного развития сюжета и довольно большого количества различных выборов по ходу игры реиграбельность довольно высока (сам прошел первый раз за 5 часов, но хочется пройти ещё как минимум пару раз).

Хорошая проработка персонажей и диалогов - роботы и главный герой, на мой взгляд, удались лучше всего.

Самое главное, что после прохождения остается куча эмоций и достаточно пищи для ума. Если вас не пугает то, что большую часть времени вы будете просто читать книгу (очень хорошую), то смело берите. Такие произведения нужно поддерживать покупками.

Рекомендую всем, кому близка такая тематика.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035039504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1472634952}
review: Excellent, thought-provoking game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993567244', 'num_games_owned': 898, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1431261320}
review: You would think that a game with no sound and no graphics might not have a place on Steam or in your gaming library but I think you would miss out on a huge sleeper here. Here we have a game that has made me think on my choices and made me regret the things that I did or didn't do. I've played it through once already (about 4 hours) and immediately started a new game. If you loved Choose Your Own Adventure as a kid, this is that on steroids. The price is right and it will become one of the best value choices in your library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063236038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1442400575}
review:
This game is beautiful, the story touches on a multitude of subjects that ended up hitting far closer to home than I could ever have expected. I can highly recommend playing this, the cost isn't prohibitive in the slightest and you'll get far more out of it than just a few hours of distraction.

There's very little reason to not give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001964738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1419217951}
review:
Short version
Another excellent text-based choose your adventure game from Choice of Games. Even after the sale is over, you should still buy it and give it a shot.


Long version
I love robots and transhuman themes. Worse, I cannot resist a good story. I was definitely going into this primed to enjoy it, and enjoy it I did. I truly do not wish to spoil the story for anyone, mostly because the fun of this game is in going through it, making one set of decision and then looking back and saying "oh but I wonder what would happen if I had..." then going back and seeing what would have happened. I will say this: stick with your decisions. At least for the first run. There are some benefits to things most of us gamer types would call "failure" which take the story in interesting directions.

Do not go in expecting "Robot Tycoon" or a Visual Novel. This is neither of those. It is a choose your own adventure novel from the 90s, rebuilt with 21st century technology. Choice of Games have made the genre better, more addicting, more entertaining, and easier to recommend. Buy it now. And if you will excuse me, I have an evil robot army to create.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970755411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1419660219}
review:
Take Dragon Age Inquisition, boil off any sort of combat or action until there's just dialogue and romance and set it in some Terminator fan-fiction and you have yourself Choice of Robots. Be prepared to answer questions as simple as what material do I make my robot out of to "whats more important? My robot or my family?" to "Should I invade alaska?" culminating into some serious existentialist stuff. 

You can play this game again and again and you get this butterfly effect of how things turn out. It's beautiful to behold.

If that isn't enough, at one point you can drink scotch and listen to "The Magnetic Fields - It's Only Time" which if you're anything like me means this is a mandatory purchase. 

Support this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990019215', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1419113650}
review:
High quality writing and an abundance of choices that influence how the story plays out. Even choices that don't seem to be all that important can alter the outcome quite a bit.

You should bring the patience to read large amounts of text - obviously - but it's well worth it. The writing is really good and offers not only a nice technical perspective on AI and robotics but also some philosophical insights about life and humanity.

Parts of the story are based on logical extrapolation of current political relationships and events, which makes those parts seem a real possibility for the future and not just some lazy fantasy.

Everyone who is interested in AI and robotics and is not afraid of reading should buy this. Everyone else should at least take a look at the demo before simply skipping this game altogether.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041682075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1635391756}
review:
Choice of Robots is the, as of now, latest installment of the series of text adventures called Choice of Games, complete with the series' usual tropes and occasionally annoyances. If you're familiar with these games or enjoy text adventures in general, then it's simple: pick this one up, it's the best installment yet. If you're not however, it's as good a starting point as any, especially when there's a free demo that adequately presents what the game entails.

Robots is about crafting, growing and teaching your own personal robot, and for someone familiar with the Choice of Games series, that's all you really need to know. Besides the wildly varied tone and settings, the majority of these games function nearly identically.  For those who are new, it's a text adventure, and what that boils down to is simply: You read a whole lot and make choices. There's no graphic, no music and no action (besides the ones being described with words). And if that puts you off, that's fair, still, the demo's free if you want to confirm your position.

As with most other games of the series, the choices you make influence your stats and how the story progress and, again, as with the other installments, the game encourages at least a certain degree of specializations. What is new, however, is that the protagonist have only one stat to keep track of, humanity, which tracks how kind, humane, social and emotional your decisions are. Your robot, on the other hand, has four stats: Autonomy, Military, Empathy and Grace, and the decisions you make throughout the game influence what kind of robot you will have, and, in turn, how you will influence the world. Would you end up with a mindless militaristic machine at your whim, a self-conscious and independent robotic sentient being or a curious, constantly learning robot with near (or perhaps completely) human emotions? Chances are, though, you're going to end up with a combination of all the things in between. 

While, like the other Choice of Games, Robots do strongly encourage specialization in at least one or two stats, the games do not seem to punish you as harshly for deviation from your initial plans. The other Choice of Games' strategic elements usually boil down to specializing in a number of areas and then make only decisions that test your strong points and avoid your weaknesses. Robots is similar, except you have more leeway and, in fact, planning becoming a lot more difficult as decisions often have unforeseen consequences. For example, there's a point in the game where you are able to make a decision on what kind of information you want your robot to extract on the internet, and allowing it to pick up whatever it wants result in it learning things like "Big Brother is watching" and "the US is the bad guy", resulting in a substantial raise in intelligence (Autonomy) and a distrust of authority (Military). There's also a point in the game where your robot is interviewed, and if your Autonomy is high enough, the review will claim your robot is smarter than humans, giving it a boost in confidence (Autonomy) while making it more arrogant (decrease in Empathy). While the unpredictability of the gameplay structure here may hamper cold strategic decision making, it also makes the story more spontaneous and exciting, as your choices can have truly unforeseeable consequences later in the game, making the narrative incredibly dynamic. That said, depending on what you choose to focus on, the game can also end up rather difficult, requiring multiple restarts, which is even more frustrating considering the fact that the game has no manual save whatsoever, forcing a restart every time you want to change something. I believe this is to make you committed to your choices and make each playthrough special and dynamic, but I still feel that the game would benefit more from having a save system of some description, especially when you've already completed the game and don't feel like skimming through most of the story to change one decision. Robots, in particular, seems to offer more consequences and variations to your decisions than any other game in the series I've experienced (skim through the achievement list if you want to know how much you could achieve, and know that I only got 10 in one playthrough, and I thought I did pretty well). That said, personally, I don't plan on replaying the game anytime soon. This is in no way a fault of the game, but rather a strength, as I feel so attached to my first playthrough that any second attempt would feel as if I've cheated that unique experience.

But gameplay aside, this is still a text adventure, and as a game that's going to make you spend the majority of your time reading, it lives and dies on the writing. Robots, like most of its predecessor, does not disappoint in this regard. There's moment of humor, melancholy, romance (with the usual inclusiveness of the series) and, perhaps most of all, introspection. The parental relationship between you and your robot becomes clear very early on, and the game handles it extremely well. Your robot grows, imitates and reacts to your actions as you would expect, with great curiosity and bewilderment. As I watch it develops, I feel proud when it understands or questions, scared when it picks up undesirable tendencies, happy when it expresses indignant at cruelty and warm when it seems more human than any living character by the end, while still having more to learn and expressing fear of the inevitable as a child would. At least that's how it was for my Sapling (that's how I named mine, and Sapling was a she and refers to me by my real name rather than titles because that's the level of customization you have), your robot could go in so many unforeseen direction it's difficult to "plan" its development, and considering the theme, I think that's the point. The human characters, while getting less attention, are well-written and varied enough in their own right, but some, even if you choose to begin a relationship with them, will feel somewhat detached from the main storyline until the latter chapters. The game, despite its initial lightheartedness and humor, asks difficult question, present morally ambiguous choices and depicts interesting, introspective themes. The final two or three chapters are the most powerful part in the game for me because it shows the growth of your robot and how you've molded the world, for better or worse, as well as calling your ideals into question. I can only speak for myself, but my ending reflected my choices appropriately, filling me with wonder, doubt, melancholy and hope. While the game has its stronger points and weaker, more filler-y portions, the finale was undoubtedly my favorite experience of any Choice of Game story.

If you enjoy the Choice of Games text adventures, then I'll just repeat myself: Buy the damn game, it's, at least in my opinion, the best in the series yet. If you have no interest in the structure and ideas behind text adventures, then I suppose there isn't much here to convince you otherwise besides good writing. If you're new and willing to try out one of these games though, I can't think of a better place to start. Choice of Robots is inspiring, funny, well-written and introspective, and for a game about robots, it has more philosophies and humanity behind it than most games out there combined.

p.s. If you have played and enjoyed this one, do go check out the other text adventures by Choice of Games. Only a few of them are on Steam at the moment but there are quite a lot of these games on the Choice of Games website, and they all have free demos (if they aren't already free). I always thought these games don't get enough credit and exposure so please support them if you like what they're doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005656216', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1448336030}
review: What a fantastic piece of futurist literature! I played the more peaceful route but was exposed directly and indirectly to the repercussions of my actions and that of others outside of my control. I was enlightened to the social, political, and economics prospective atmospheres of the future, with a large focus on the effects of introducing artificial intelligence (or lack thereof).  The relationships I developed felt more "real" than most other C.Y.O.A. games (the exception being the Heroes Rise Trilogy) and I genuinely felt bad when I pushed friends away for the sake of the growing demand for my robotic knowledge.  My ending felt a tad rushed but it may have been due to my overall decisions having little differentiation from my initial stance on robotics.  All in all, the author knows his subject very well and it shows in his writing (largely with robotic ethics and boundaries).  If you are trying to sate an urge to experience an Asimov tale, craving a 2001: A Space Odyssey journey, and/or wanting to discover what the future may hold for robotics from a modernized perspective, this game is for you. Grab it now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006416659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1448476717}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997645319', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1437786876}
review: It's difficult to attach yourself to an experience like this. Most I imagine would rather pick the most cathartic route and run with it. but even as your decisions veer up and down the scale, The story always retains its organic cohesion and compelling storyline. While one or two characters can be a tad two dimensional, every decision you make affects the story in wildly branching ways. for something this simple, little more than a flash text algorithm, I was left on the brink of tears in my first playthrough,  Not only do your decisions resonate, but they provide a good series of compelling arguments about the nature of artificial intelligence. This isn't a game. Nor is it a novel. It's a narrative experience that evolves beyond its initial "choose-your-own-adventrure" If you have any interest in sci fi, but worry that the lack of graphics might turn you off, I still recommend you give it a try. you might find it more engaging than you expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020712540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1420816116}
review:
Bottom line, strong recommendation if you're a fan of science fiction novels.

This game is, quite literally, interactive fiction - and very good fiction at that. Gameplay elements are minimal: You're given a choice, possibly your robots' stats changes depending on your choice, then the story continues. The focus is clearly on the (very good!) writing.  But, and this important, your choices actually matter. And that's not a buzzword for once. It's not Mass Effect-style "choose the colour of the light beams in the ending" sense, I mean that choices matter in that you get completely different stories depending on your choices. A run takes about 30 minutes, depending on how quick a reader you are, but there are so many different branches (both minor and major) that you can easily sink hours just into exploring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025394635', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1419041329}
review:
Very enjoyable text-based game, every choice really changes the history outcomes.

It could use some images or even some options to change background and font colors since the black on white make my eyes bleed.

The story is a bit non-sense at some times ( ex military fights ) , but on the overall, it's an excellent game.

And for it´s price i would give 8/10 for sure!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043609661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1558891017}

You and I both know that the future is kissing robots and maybe also being a robot who kisses robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965815561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1419325943}
review:
Very enjoyable, good for an afternoon read. The general interface was a bit boreing to look at after a long time but with that said your only reading so its perfectly functional. The story arc i had was fun and i found it went in a direction i expected overall, but only because of the choices i was making. The story does do a good choice of reflecting what you choose.

Would play again for a different story arc, considering a movie ticket is 6-7 times (in Australia) the price i paid (3 USD) i feel the last 2 hours of my life were entertaining and for good value. Recommend playing at least once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006400253', 'num_games_owned': 1058, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1419050466}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020218824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2710, 'last_played': 1452760355}
review: Incredible. This feels like a new frontier for creativity, particularly for those of us who love to write and have a passion for video games, but lack visual art skill. With so many options, and so many different situations, this game has numerous hours of replayability. Phenominal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994542150', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1419117444}
review: This game has interesting choices and paths. Very nice story telling. If you like robots, scifi and to read books, this is a great game or book to try out. You do not complete this art piece with one run, there are so many other ways to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999167092', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1419607502}
review:
I absolutely love the story in this interactive novel. You choices matter (pretty much every choice effects the story) and it's very long. 

I definitely recomned this game to anyone that's the least interested in what kind of effect artificial intelligence might have on society. I found myself constantly agonising over different decisions and what effect they might have on myself, other people and the robots.

My only complaint is that it could use a save button.

10/10
